description:
Awesome tacos!  They had about 10 choices of meats, many of them I had never heard of.

Taqueria Vallarta on 24th used to be my favorite, its also good, but La Oaxaqueña has just dethroned it in my opinion!
author: Marc R.

description:
I went there this Tuesday afternoon.  It was closed.  I came home and doubled checked their hours as published on its yelp page and its web site.  

Yelp said for today it is open from 11 am to 2 am
La Oaxaqena's web site says it is open from 6 am to 2 am.
I called the restaurant.  A man assured me they are open from 5 pm to 9 pm.

One of yelp's pictures shows a sign that says they are closed on Wednesdays.  That sign was no longer there today.

Yelps shows great reviews.  It's a shame their hours of operation are so very wrong.

My rating irrelevant since I have not eaten there.
author: Micky L.

description:
Simply AMAZING Tamales! I work nearby and each month have a morning meeting for my staff. I bring different foods each time, but the most popular request is for these Tamales! Pork, Chicken Mole, and Raja Queso...they are all Great! I order in advance and they are fresh and warm! 

My staffer from Colorado Springs says it's one goodie that reminds him of home. 

All my staff, including some from South America, all agree that these tamales are pure happiness! They all work a little harder when powered by these tamales!

I've ordered them twice and the first time my staff wrote chef Roxanna a thank you card! Muchas gracias Roxanna!
author: Christina D.

description:
Tacos are so bomb after drinks and a night out - especially in the Mission! 

Their tacos are greasy and perfect for the late night munchies.  Slices of onions and jalapeño for the spice kicker, is delicious! 

Small seating area.  Not impressive or anything.  

Pretty much a typical taqueria in the heart of the Mission neighborhood.
author: Tiffany D.

description: picked this spot based and reviews. Trekked 30 minutes and it's closed. Yelp says it's open for time I arrived
author: Maritza S.

description:
I'm currently sitting in this establishment and I just had to take a moment to write them a review while I sit here trying to let the food settle as I ate in in about 10min. 

I got 4 tacos. Carne Adana and pastor. The pastor was so bomb. With every bite I was like "why are there not more people in this place!?"

Well I'm your hero. This place is a jem. The food is so damn good. Or at least they're tacos are on fucking point. The pastor has a slight but so delightful pineapple taste. This is a first for me and I love pineapple so this was a major win. 

And the gentlemen who helped me is a sweet dude and gave excellent service. 

I would most definitely come here again.  

I only managed to snag a single photo of the amazingness that are tacos but just trust me. I know good tacos. And this place has em. 

Excited to come back for some other goods. 
Thank you Los Oaxaqueña!c
author: Monica R.

description: Came here with my boyfriend for the first time and decided to try some new things. Had our first Pupusas, which were great, and then switched to tacos. We hadn't had lengua before but I'd always heard it was delicious, so we got 2 lengua tacos and 2 carne asada. We loved the lengua so much we got 2 more and demolished them. The food was delicious and super affordable, and the guy running the restaurant was wonderful. I'll definitely be coming back.
author: Amber B.

description:
Is one of the best street tacos in  San Francisco..
Open at night only ... all the meats r so tender n tasty.. few salsa to choose from.. pile up the vegi on tacos .. wow exploresion in ur mouth..n licking ur lip n fingers while eating lol..
author: Crisy G.

description:
God, this place is so damn authentic!

Ever since La Taqueria closed on Mondays, I've been doing Taco Tour, visiting a new place each Monday for tacos. La Oaxaqueña was our lucky ticket this week. The helpful server suggested tacos el pastor as his favorite, but I went for the chicken mole. It was served on two small, heated tortillas, the kind you would find all over Mexico, with onion, cilantro and lime. The chicken was tender and seasoned perfectly. It was a tad expensive at $2.50, but so good I had to go for another, and this time I opted for the pastor. It was superb as well, if not a tad greasy. My only qualm is that there were no beans available, meaning no veggie options whatsoever, so my friend in arms on this Monday night taco tour had to go elsewhere, but, that, my friends, is a different review.
author: Brian J.

description: My favorite tacos in the Bay Area. Can't eat enough cabeza. If I'm out in SF, I'm gonna try to stop here late night for a plate full of cabeza tacos, and then probably get a second plate after.
author: Victor X.

description:
The tacos were just fine but the people are out of control! I was in line when i heard the person behind me say "faggot" and of course I turned around and said "don't say that". I was immediately bombarded by the white tech bro's Latina girlfriend spouting off obscenities she didn't understand. She... wanted to fight me... ?

An Open Letter to People Who Still Use 'Faggot' as an Insult
https://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/8011324

By Casey Cavanagh
08/20/2015 12:20 PM ET

Updated Dec 06, 2017
I understand that terms like "fag" and "gay" are often used in a "joking" manner. When you use them, you probably don't do so maliciously -- and certainly not in a way to purposely offend or insult homosexuals. You, like many, may use the words without even thinking twice about it. Sometimes it just slips -- it's an easy, long since accessible insult. It's almost a habit, right? Well, even if this is the case, it doesn't make it okay.

First of all, let's start with the obvious fact that "gay" often doesn't even make sense in most contexts in which it is used to describe something or someone. Take for example when you are hanging around with your friends and you say something along the lines of, "Why won't you come out tonight? Stop being gay." There is nothing gay about staying in. You mean stop being lazy? Anti-social? Lame? Is there really no better adjective you can find in your brain to use -- one that is not only more politically correct but also more accurate for the point you're trying to make?

Justifying your use of these words by saying "I didn't mean it offensively," doesn't make it okay. Not only does it show ignorance, but it also shows a concerning lack of intellect. Yes, context is important.

But it's the implication behind it that is the problem.

If you are calling someone a faggot or gay, you are still using the term in a condescending, demeaning and often insulting manner. You never say, "This new guy I am dating is so fun and sweet! He always acts like such a faggot."

"But it's just a word!" Some people argue that by rejecting the word you could potentially give it more power, making it taboo or more controversial, and that they choose to use it as a means of "reclaiming" it. I am not suggesting you ban these words from your vocabulary; I am suggesting you don't use them if you are doing so with the intent to insult.

You don't get to impose your own meaning on words and use them on, or against, other people... at least not while holding the ignorant belief it will go without ridicule -- that the context you're using it in is excusable. You can't reclaim something without a thorough understanding of where it came from and the problem surrounding it. And the fact that you use it so carelessly leads me to assume you don't have that thorough understanding.

To you, it may be "just a word." If so, you are fortunate. A lot more fortunate than others who have a lot of pain and suffering tied to it. Sure, it's not a big deal to everyone, but just because it doesn't affect some people doesn't mean it isn't your obligation to care about who it may -- and why.

The best depiction of the problem with this word, and one that forever changed the way I view it, was a scene from comedian Louis C.K.'s show, Louie. The particular scene is of him and his friends playing poker, poking fun at their gay friend, and asking a number of questions about "gay things."

Louie asked him if he thought he shouldn't be using the word "fag" on stage during his routines. His friend responded by saying:

I think you should use whatever words you want. When you use it on stage, I can see it's funny, and I don't care. But are you interested in what it might mean to gay men? Well, the word 'faggot' really means a bundle of sticks used for kindling in a fire. Now, in the middle ages, when they used to burn people they thought were witches? They used to burn homosexuals, too. And, they used to burn the witches at a stake, but they thought the homosexuals were too low and disgusting to be given a stake to be burnt on, so they used to just throw them in with the kindling, with the other faggots. So that's how you get 'flaming faggot.'

... You might wanna know that every gay man in America has probably had that word shouted at them while they're being beaten up, sometimes many times, sometimes by a lot of people all at once. So, when you say it, it kind of brings that all back up. But, you know, by all means, use it. Get your laughs. But, you know, now you know what it means.
Be responsible. Hold yourself accountable. Pay attention to the words you use, the way you articulate yourself, and be aware of how the things you say may affect people around you. At the very least, take the time to...

https://m.huffpost.com/us/entry/8011324
author: Nikki E.

description:
Why is la oaxaquena open so late, you may ask? They always seem somewhat annoyed to see customers arrive after 11, yet they diligently stay open far later. 

Whatever the reason, I'm glad they do. Their late night menu may not be as expansive during the day, but it is more than enough to blow you away with flavor and variety. Usually it seems to consist just of tacos and sausages, but unlike you might expect, quite a variety of meats are still available. 

Most noteworthy, cochanita pibil is still around. Let me tell you, after a later-than-I-probably-should-on-a-weeknight adventure, few things taste better than a delicious cochanita taco loaded up with spicy salsa. It's just the right amount of grease for a solid late night without being too harsh on the digestive system. 

I need to come back sometime at normal hours and get tlaiudas. But, somehow, I always end up here well past "normal close" during their late night menu only. 

Here's to amazing late night food near several of the best bars/clubs/haunts in SF.
author: Chris S.

description: This place is one of the unassuming gems of the the mission food scene. Their tacos are fantastic, and come with a delicious stir fry of onions and peppers. It's great to discover chefs who have a passion for their craft.
author: Gunther P.

description:
I shouldn't be telling you this but maybe you already know: if it's the wee hours of the night (past midnight), I recommend trying out their tacos. 

Great seasoning overall and the salsas and grilled onions are great. We arrived at 2am after a Friday night of hanging out with friends and the tacos were great. Favorite chicken tacos so far in the mission.

I want to point out I was completely sober when I ate here, so this is not one of those places you go to and taste great only when you're intoxicated. Not to say tacos aren't great for that occasion ^^

Bring cash, or kindly ask if you can pay with card. $10 minimum.
author: Lupita D.

description: Was excited to try, thinking authentic oaxacan food. Tried Chipotle Chicken Quesadilla, was full of onions. Took a long time for the order, though the place was not busy at all. The quality was questionable. I have eaten in lots of shady taquerias, but for first time the food did no sit well at all. Will have to pass next time
author: Pramod G.

description: At first sight, it looks like a dinky little hole in the wall. But don't let that fool you! This mom and pops restaurant offers fantastic food and great service. I had two tacos (pastor and asada) and it was a very generous size with lots of goodies! But what takes the cake is their chicken mole. I am still dreaming about it. I can't wait to go back again!!
author: Marta M.

description: Terrible, really rude service, and cheated me on the price... there are so many great taco places around here. At least have some courtesy to your customers?
author: Grace L.

description:
If you only care about food quality  and don't care about the ambience, this is place to go.

Very very simple place but food is super delicious.
author: Maryam V.

description: Great tacos. The cochinita ones were delightfully lip smackingly rich with a mix of meat and fat that was basically ideal. Definitely get at least one, though if you got 3 it might be too much. Luckily the lengua is great too.
author: Misha T.

description:
This is by far the best taco I've had in San Francisco. The chipotle chicken taco is amazing, but the carne asada one blew my mind. The carne asada has incredible flavor and was finely minced, which you can't find everywhere. The grilled onions on the side were cooked to the perfection of street meat, and the green salsa was 10/10. Lastly, the staff is so incredibly friendly and kind--I love supporting businesses with good food and kind people.

I've definitely found my taco place in San Francisco after two years. Would highly recommend!
author: Erica Z.

description: What you're looking at right here is my absolute favourite late night taco stop in the Mission. Open late, they serve hot dogs and tacos out of a stand near the front of the store. Each taco is $2.50, and there are a variety of different meats (although I always go with pastor now). The tacos are very filling, and have a nice taste to them. Been here countless times, and will definitely keep coming back. They have serve Mexican coke out of their fridge. Haven't tried any of the other food on the menu to the best of my knowledge, as the last 10+ times I've grabbed the tasty tacos.
author: Rajeev S.

description: Unfortunately, last time I attended this place, it was a disaster. Never mind the continuously declining quality of the restroom, it was the food quality and well... it's just not what it was at all before. The place needs cleaning and renovation. Seeing they have received a poor quality grade, I feel pretty grossed out because I wanted to still like this place, but I also feel disrespected as a human to be served slow quality cleanliness.
author: Eff B.

description: This place has the best tacos - authentic and low key. It's one of those hole in the wall kind of places, very casual. It's a great place to pop in and eat, after a night out or after work. Definitely one of the best spots in the Mission
author: Noora L.

description:
We came here on a Thursday evening and ordered the carne asada tacos as a late night snack. The proportion of ingredients was lopsided - too many onions and barely any meat.  Not a lot of sauce on the tacos either, which made them very bland.

The only upside is that this restaurant is open until 2:00am, so you can drop by if you have a serious case of the drunchies. Otherwise, I would explore other options. These are a ton of amazing tacquerias in the Mission, but La Oaxaqueña just isn't one of them.
author: Miko B.

description:
I don't understand how this place has such rave reviews. My experience wasn't even close to 4 stars, let alone 1ish. 

Tried three types of mix and match burritos here (vegetarian, chicken, grilled steak). Each ingredient that gets rolled into the burritos were independently bland, flavorless, and just...blah. All very much lacked a fresh component of cilantro or lime. 

The ratio of ingredients was also uneven and pretty overwhelming. The tortilla was super chewy, probably steamed after it had been rolled instead of before. Rice was mushy, beans were hard. No. Just. No. 

The guac was more like a puree and the salsa was super watery, also lacking a fresh component.

Complaints, complaints, complaints. sorry! Usually there's an upside but can't figure out what that would be here. 

1.5 stars I guess.
author: Shereen A.

description:
I've been here twice before. Each time was pleasant. First time was to get tacos at the taco bar on a date, and it was delicious(the date wasn't as good). The second time I got the chicken mole, and it was phenomenal! The price is pretty good, and the service is excellent -- the cashier was very pleasant and was gracious is giving extra boxes for food and salsa.

Best of all: this place is never crowded. A gem of the mission!
author: Kevin J.

description: Stupid me for not reading far enough into the reviews to realize that these people have zero respect for their potential customers.  After coming back from a trip to Mexico in October we were craving some supposedly authentic Mexican food and something a little different.  We found La Oaxaquena on Yelp and drove over an hour from San Jose on a Friday afternoon to try it.  After looking for parking for about 10 minutes and walking for another 10 to get there, we were greeted by a locked gate and no sign explaining the random closure.  Guess these people don't like running a respectable business that adheres to regular hours or making money.  Don't waste your time.
author: Sarah G.

description: Grasshopper tacos! They weren't on the menu - I asked at the counter. Salty, but good! I also had lengua tacos, which were quite good too. Great, attentive service. No beer sold in the restaurant, but they allowed us to bring beer from the liquor store next door.
author: Amiya D.

description: This is probably the only Mexican place in the mission that will add real veggies to your meal (peppers mushrooms) that make it so wholesome and good. Highly recommend for vegetarians. The mole sauce was out of this world as well as the chips and salsa. Even though it's a little bit away from the Bart stop I would encourage vegetarians to walk the extra block and check this place out. You will not be disappointed. Simply delicious.
author: Siddharth D.

description: Unreal. Best taco in San Francisco, and some of the best management as well. Well worth the visit.
author: R G.

description:
Somehow I always run into the best gems in the Mission in the hunt for late night munchies.  And I promise, this wasn't the alcohol talking.  I think this place basically ruins all other tamales for me because their banana leaf tamale with the chicken and the mole sauce is the bomb.  I don't know if it's the banana leaf or just their recipe, but something about it made it so rich and moist.  I feel like normally, the masa in the tamale tends to be a bit like dry cornbread, but this one was so buttery smooth and melted in your mouth.  The mole gave a nice velvety complement to the masa.

As bonus points, the friends I went out with were both vegetarians, and there were ample options for them to choose from.  I'm a pretty avid carnivore, but I would definitely go back to try their ratatouille-like banana leaf tamale.  More bonus points, we got coconut water which came in a full coconut, complete with a spoon to scoop out some of the coconut flesh!   This place is definitely a hole in the wall authentic Mission Mexican restaurant, so probably not suitable for a fancy date or anything, but perfect to satisfy your Mexican food cravings.
author: Jenny C.

description:
My parents, husband and I tried this place. We all have different tastes but all enjoyed what we tried. There were plenty of halal options for my husband and I even though he prefers to eat meat. 

I had the sun dried tomato and goat cheese pupusas. The variation in pupusa from my neighborhood pupuseria was pretty nice and the flavors were interesting.  It would have been cool if they could have had one more ingredient for a little difference in texture, but it was still really good.

I also had a banana leaf tamale which was pretty delicious and I was excited to have one that wasn't made with lard. 

The salsa was also really good. It was strong on oregano and just the right amount of flavor and salt. 

I really appreciated the murals on the wall that provided some information about Cinco de Mayo and Maria Sabina. More people should learn something about Mexican culture and resistance and not just consume the food and stuff.
author: Ramona R.

description:
My god.  Almost 20 years of eating at dozens of taquerias in the Mission and I finally discover La Oaxaqueña *now*?

Best tacos in the Mission.  In SF, actually.  And they are open late.

Big, juicy tacos with piled on deliciousness.

Perfect.


I will admit that every 20th visit or so the meat has been dried out and that makes the taco not terribly exciting.  I do wish they'd keep it from getting overcooked, but so it goes.  If you had a bad experience, go back and give it another try, because it's so damn good it still gets 5 stars even if it's misfiring 5% of the time.
author: David M.

description:
Great for late night snacks/meals or if you're feeling spontaneous and courageous for some grasshoppers or brain.

But they open till late at night and is perfect after drinking and etc.

The more outgoing food menu is not for me (which includes brain, grasshoppers, tarantulas (seasonal), ostrich, venison). You'll never catch me willingly eat a bug. But we did order some tacos and tlayuda trio with 3 meats. The tlayuda reminded me of a mexican pizza with a fried tortilla topped with refried beans, lettuce, meats, sauce and some avocados and a couple tomatoes for garnish. It was ok, probably wouldn't order it again, but it's a huge and great to share. The tacos I'll definitely go for again. They were delicious, I recommend getting the carnitas and chipotle chicken. I really like that they give you roasted peppers and grilled onions to go with your taco.

The tacos are 4 stars, but with price makes it 3.5 star and wasn't impressed with the tlayuda. 

Price are more on the expensive side, $2.75 per taco and the tlayuda was $13. They accept credit card.

It's a small joint with a back area that makes dirty dogs, which I want to try next time! Maybe I'll update when I try their mole and dirty dogs.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Holy cow this place is amazing! And I'm not referring to Oaxaquena. I am actually referring to a separate stall/business INSIDE this restaurant! There's this guy who has a separate stall inside this same restaurant, and you pay him separately. HIS tacos are to die for!!
author: Sun T.

description:
It's been too long since I've felt your loving embrace, Oaxaquena! I forgot how delicious your tacos are. I swear they're even better than before too! 

Suadero (Braised Beef) - 5 stars
WOW! The meat was crisped at the ends and juicy/tender in the middle. The flavor was amazing. The tacos fresh and soft. This comes with exactly the right amount of salsa and toppings -- and seems spicier than before, in a make-your-eyes-water a little but not painful and still delicious kind of way. 

Pastor (Pineapple Pork) - 4.5 stars
Also great, but not as juicy as the Suadero. Not as much crisp as I remember from before. But still really up there. The Suadero really set the bar high.

Mexican Hot Chocolate w/ Guajillo Chili Powder - 5 stars
Oh yes! Just as amazing as always. A thick layer of foam on top that adds volume and texture, and the drink itself - I don't know what it is (maybe there's steamed milk?) but it's just perfect. And the chili powder one is so tasty!
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The food here is delicious and cheap.  I got a banana leaf tamale (their specialty) for $4.50 and a oaxacan corn tamale for $2.75.  That is great pricing!  I had trouble finishing both because, altogether, this was a lot of food.  The banana leaf tamale, especially, is quite big.  

I'd recommend trying at least one of their banana leaf tamales.  The masa is amazing, nice and smooth.  The filling is hearty and satisfying - I got the chicken mole one.  This is a different kind of tamale, and I think I even like it better than a regular tamale, which is saying a lot because I really like tamales!

Although it's not absolutely necessary, I think it would be VERY helpful to know Spanish when ordering.  It would make for a much easier time for you.
author: Vivian C.

description: Tacos tacos tacos tacos tacos tacos tacos tacos tacos. What more can I say this places has really good tacos it's authentic. Don't blow it up tho it's my favorite spot can't have any lines.
author: James S.

description: The man wipes his face as he makes tacos. I ask him why he wouldn't​ wash his hands. He gives me an arrogant response. I leave.
author: Bhanu V.

description: Great tacos. Wish they had guacamole though. That said they are as good as they can get without it
author: Josh C.

description:
Came here to try the pupusa and the ostrich tacos but they don't have ostrich anymore and they were out of pupusa

Not a good start but at least they had the last thing we wanted that they are also known for the tamales

They have two different styles one with baba leaf which is double the price the corn lead but gotta try them both

They also have blue corn quesadillas and I love blue corn so hard to find!

First came the huracha which was huge and it was great
The tamales are the star though...
After some debates with owner they found some masa to make the pupusa 

Value 4.5/5
Atmosphere 2.5/5 hole in the wall not the cleanest 
Service 3/5 average and slow
Quality 4.5/5 yum

14.5/20
author: Nina S.

description: Grasshopper tacos! They weren't on the menu - I asked at the counter. Salty, but good! I also had lengua tacos, which were quite good too. Great, attentive service. One of my go-to spots for quick Oaxacan Mexican food without the wait.
author: Wyatt S.

description:
Chicken mole kinda rocks here, even if most people are getting their delicious pupusas and tlayudas (tostada on steroids, and it looks like a Mexican pizza).

I've heard about grasshopper and fish tacos, but haven't ventured that deep into the food here yet.

Little tables for eating in, though there's a takeout window for tacos on the go. Kinda pricey as tacos go, but everything else seems to rest at a good price point.
author: Kevin L.

description: Absolutely delicious. Stopped in around 1 am after flying into SF from Houston and was no disappointed!
author: Lizzy D.

description: I went to another place to get ceviche for lunch before I had to head to the airport but the portion was smaller than I thought, so I decided to try La Oaxaquena tacos to fill me up since I saw such good reviews. I walked a few blocks and saw that it was gated closed even though it was a Thursday around noon. Wasted my time walking here and then to another place that I would've just gone to initially had I known La Oaxaquena was going to be closed.
author: Stacey E.

description:
Trying to order from these guys for pickup is a nightmare.  Here's why:
1) they don't list the correct timings.
2) they don't answer their phone
3) they don't have a full menu sometimes, but you won't know until you arrive
4) on "limited menu days" they will just serve tacos, and they won't start cooking until they feel like it.

They haven't earned the right to be this elusive, but they've definitely earned this bad rating!
author: Maulie D.

description:
Everything here is just okay.

Except for the banana leaf tamales which are astonishingly good. Especially the mole ones. These are worth any downsides.

Just don't bother eating anything else. Also the banana leaf tamales are great take out -- tell them you're going to steam them at home.
author: Jane M.

description:
We came here a few times for late night tacos after stopping by bars in the area. For $2-$3 each, the tacos are pretty bomb. The cabeza is best! 

It's a really casual, hole in the wall place but the food is good! They literally wrap your tacos from a small cart by the window. 

But don't worry, there's some small tables for you to sit and enjoy your taco! :)
author: Connie Y.

description:
QUESTION: Does this spot still sell hot dogs at night?

-

By day, they're a bakery/restaurant combo.

By night, they're a purveyor of hot dogs. And not just any hot dogs, but bacon-wrapped hot dogs. Add onions and cilantro to make a savory snack in-between bars - assuming you're bar hopping.

This hot-dog cart is cash-only as near as I can figure.
author: Dave L.

description:
Your review helps others learn about great local businesses.
The ting a pollo tacos are delicious other than the hot chocolate ...
Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.
author: Mariana J.

description: Excellent mole dinner and one of the rare places with vegetarian tacos and burritos containing more than just beans and cheese. Also really good salsa
author: Eric M.

description: The presentation was superb. The avocado was fresh. This is my first time having mole. I am not used to the flavour. It reminds me of herbal medicine. The chicken was tender and the Mexican rice was delicious. The only reason why I gave this place one less star is because there was one fly hovering around my food.
author: James S.

description:
Chips in a plastic bag from a store... Enough said.

Why this place sucks -
- Guac is old and they mix in the brown parts
- Asked for extra guac, did not get any extra
- Use frozen veggies
- The guys working there give zero craps about anything / terrible service
- Gross food
- Meat in my VEGETARIAN veggies (pieces of steak)

Overall - rude, cheap, not to order food.
author: Ninja R.

description: Going wrong with a Mexican restaurant in the mission is like going back wrong with a dim sum restaurant in Chinatown. It will almost never happen, but still it's always good to test the waters. This place is typical of a Mexican restaurant in the mission: pretty rundown, friendly waitstaff, and delicious food. They are also open till 2:00 AM for the drunk crowd that loves street tacos, amazing! However, what makes me love this place are, hands down, the tamales... I've never had banana leaf tamales before coming here and I heard that they were delicious... I got some and they definitely did not disappoint... I love tamales so this statement is saying a lot. Next time I come here, I will probably try to explore more of the menu but it will be hard!
author: Kunal N.

description:
The MOLE IS TO DIE FOR!!! Seriously!! 

If you call yourself a foodie and haven't tried the mole there... I just don't know what it says about you as a person. 

I always order the tamale with Oaxaca mole there.  The tamale is not your standard Mexican tamale wrapped in corn husk this is a square shaped tamale wrapped with banana leaves, the masa is definitely more moist and creamier, it melts in your mouth like butter!! And with mole ... aahh the mole... the smooth, velvety, thick and full of amazing blend of roasted chiles mole just envelopes you with satisfaction and comfort like a thick cashmere blanket on a chilly San Francisco night. It gives me reason to why I slave myself 5 days a week and 8 hours per day... it's all for buying delicious dishes like this.  

(P.S I don't own a cashmere blanket since I spend my money on food, but I am pretty sure cashmere is as amazing as it sounds ^^)
author: Suzanne L.

description:
Hands down the best Mexican joint in the mission. I think there are two separate business that run on the same floor. The front-cart offers cash-only quick bites, while the back business is the main entity.

Front-cart:
- Cash-only
- Smaller tacos
- Recommend: Taco on a hot-dog bun.

Back-business:
- Accepts cards
- Larger tacos (with grilled vegetables)
- Amazing chips and salsa
- Tinga de pollo and campechano are awesome

I have been to plenty of taquerias in the mission but this one is the best I had so far.
author: Thomas L.

description: Veggie burrito had zucchini and broccoli. One of the best I've ever had (and I live in San Diego)!
author: Steve K.

description:
*** NO grasshopper, tarantula, ostrich, yoda, venison, et al. ***

We went on May 19 and señor said the city had made them stop serving insects / bugs / interesting animals a while back. There are still lengua and cabeza. Stuff we got was okay, but a bummed-out feeling pervaded our visit since we'd been so excited to get gross. Pretty sure barefoot hipster was there for bugs too and was likewise saddened by their absence.
author: Dan B.

description:
Great food! I had the carnitas taco which is a full size taco. It's not the street taco size. Cooked perfectly. My brother got the shrimp burrito and that was great as well. 

Very sweet lady who was our server!

I gave it a 4 star because the bathroom is super gross, but everything else was awesome!
author: Mae B.

description: If you're trying to go for the grasshopper tacos don't bother. They are closed. There's a small taco vendor inside that sells from his cart in the corner of the restaurant meanwhile the whole rest of the restaurant is closed and empty. I've visited various times excited to try their grasshopper tacos  hoping they'd be open this time only to be told the same thing over and over; somethings down and they'll be open next week. Who would have ever thought I'd  be so upset about not eating insects? I tried calling but they never pick up. I'm so bummed out. Whatever their problem is I hope they can sort it out soon.
author: Trinidad M.

description: Service is good. Tacos are small and good, not great... Only tried the late night taco stand, not the restaurant. Went because of all the positive reviews, but probably won't be back.
author: David F.

description: I love coming here for a quick bite. Every time I've gone, I'll order the carne asada tacos with everything on them, but recently tried their cochinitas.. MAN, no going back. Definitely recommend checking this place out for a fast, no frills taco craving.
author: Michio F.

description: You looking for some late night cabeza tacos? This is your spot in the mission until 2 am. A bit sloppy with the arrangement, but hey, it's the city.
author: Shawn S.

description: traditional tacos in a down to earth and relaxed setting. cash only.
author: Anson C.

description: I've been trying and tasting burritos in the east, South Bay and SF. Hands down this place is the best. Better than La Taqueria, for sure. Amazing stuff.
author: Nick M.

description:
Food meh...
We ordered the banana leaf chicken tamale, and felt that it lacked taste. The pupusas were actually a bit bitter for some reason and could not figure out why, another FAIL. I guess I have been spoiled by Los Panchos. The carne asada tostada was pretty good even though I asked for an order of spicy pork taco. After the bill the server actually gave us a complimentary flan bc he thought he knew Kris C. HA!

Mexican hot chocolate is a major WOW one order is good enough to serve two, and it tastes like Christmas in a cup. Verdict I will only come back for some bacon wrapped hot diggity dawgs and a nice cup of Mex hot cocoa. YUM now that's fine dining baby!
author: Mary Ann B.

description: thank u yeezus for this late nite taco spot. 2 delicious. checking all the boxes i had no idea needed to be checked. delicious carnitas y carne al pastor. i die. spicy. everything !!!!!!  mucho amor 2 u oaxaqueña
author: Yves D.

description:
Great Service 
Awesome Staff
Yummy food - try the corn husk tamales... my favorite is the Jalepeno and cheese.

PUPUSAS- YEASSSSSS!!!!
author: Corey G.

description: My go-to spot for some AUTHENTIC handmade Mexican chocolate...hella good with real cacao and delicious spices...simply addicting :)
author: Carmel D.

description:
This place is just a gem, I absolutely love it.

A no-frills joint with an incredibly inventive Oaxacan menu featuring such dishes as venison tortas, crab tostadas, and ostrich tacos.  All the traditional Mexican taqueria fare is there (streak burritos, chicken tacos, etc.) if you're playing it safe but if you want something out of the ordinary and want to try Oaxacan flavors, this is the place. Their corn leaf and banana leaf tamales are delicious, by the way, and if you're a papusa fan, they have quite a variety of fillings, too.

Service there is always friendly and polite if not always polished but you're not really there for that, it's all about the food.
author: Saminda W.

description:
My rating is dependent on what you are looking for. If you are in search of a hole in the wall establishment where you can eat decent Mexican food, then this is the place for you. This could be a nice place to go if it's late at night and you are drunk. This is not the place for you if you are looking for a nice restaurant to sit down and enjoy the environment.

First, it was unclear where we would get our food from. There are two chefs in one area. One man sells tacos and hot dogs, the other man an entire menu of foods. Which one you choose is your decision. 

Second, don't use the bathroom if you don't want your entire experience ruined. The bathroom was disgusting and there was no soap available. If employees are supposed to wash their hands prior to preparing a meal, how is this possible without soap??????

Third, the flies out numbered the patrons. If I had to swat away flies in order to eat my meal, how many flies were near my food while being prepared??

The food was decent, but these key hygienic facts contributed to my negative experience. If you are looking for an establishment which could pass the health inspector, look elsewhere.
author: Nike R.

description:
So, just a tip:  if you order a tlayuda, **don't order anything else**.  You might even split it.

For those new to them (I was), a tlayuda is a kind of giant tostada, with refried beans, two kinds of cheese, lettuce, avocado, salsa and meat (your choice).  The ones at La Oaxaquena are around 14" in diameter, the size of a medium pizza, and about as filling.  

Which is a shame, because the banana leaf tamales are really good.  You'll just have to go twice.

So .... full.
author: Josh B.

description:
Similar to many eateries along Mission. Kind of a small place but big enough to hold a few groups at a time.

What sets them apart? Their pupusas are BOMB. I ordered one of each type of pupusa and pretty much devoured them all (well, my husband helped me finish them). So cheap, too!

Perfect for late night munchies! Open late for tired clubbers and pub crawlers...
author: Nicki F.

description:
This place is awesome for some Mexican Hot Chocolate! I've been here two times already and I always make sure to get the Mexican Hot Chocolate when I'm here!

They give you a lot of Hot Chocolate here. In a to-go cup, it'll ended up being around two full servings. The Mexican Hot Chocolate is really good! It wasn't super hot but it was really chocolatey. I highly recommend getting some if you come here.

I also had a burrito with mole sauce. I had no idea what mole sauce was but I decided to try it with my burrito. I regret getting it with the mole sauce.. It was a little sweet, which I didn't know, and didn't taste good with the burrito (in my opinion). I ate about half of it with the mole sauce and then ended up scrapping the rest of it off the burrito. Good thing it came in a plate. 

Overall, this little store is a great place for Mexican Hot Chocolate. You get a lot for the price, totally worth it!

Pros:
-Great tasting Mexican Hot Chocolate and you get a lot of it!

Cons:
-The waiter was a little weird. My roommates said that when he was taking our orders, his tone was as if he was questioning if we really wanted each thing we were ordering
author: Paul U.

description: Suuuuper tasty! And such a great price for the food given! Their enchiladas are solid and you can get them with different meats- not just chicken or beef!
author: Liz F.

description:
At some point in the recent year and a half, the food here changed.  It happened right after they were closed for a little while, then re-opened with a slightly different interior, claimed they were still the same place, but didn't have my favorite items on the menu, including that caesar salad I loved so much!  And the tres leches cake has never been the same :(

Also, the two times I've been here recently, I experienced terrible, super-slow service....the kind of service where you have to keep asking over and over again to have each item you've ordered brought to you, and they STILL get it wrong :(   

This makes me really sad, because I had just started loving this place before this change.  I'm not sure if the management changed, or what happened.  But now it's just another mediocre late-night taqueria-type place that has a LOT of unsavory elements hanging out in front.  

In the future, I'll pass :(
author: Amy L.

description: It is amazing that they are open until 2 a.m. I ordered their tacos and boy were they awesome for the time of night next time I'm going to try their bacon wrapped hot dogs definitely worth coming to you and very delicious
author: Bryan P.

description:
GRASSHOPPER, COW BRAIN and TARANTULA Tacos?!?!?

Life is not worth living it in a bubble, neither is being a foodie not willing to try new things. Ox Penis, Durian, Pig Eye Balls, 1,000 Year Old Egg, Alligator, Blood Sausage....BRING IT ON!!! As long as it doesn't make me sick, I'm down for anything (well, almost).

I HATE bugs and I normally get a bottle of hairspray to kill them just to avoid any contact. However, when I heard about the Grasshopper Tacos earlier this year on Yelp, something made me want to try them. 

On Saturday, 12/4/10, I finally tried the Grasshopper Taco. My friend and I came to La Oaxaqueña Bakery and Restaurant at 11:50 AM and they were still in the midst of opening shop. 

DO NOTE: The business hours on Yelp are INCORRECT. On the weekends, they are open from 12 Noon to 3 AM and they have a food cart outside until 5 AM. 

F O O D:
*GUAC & CHIPS ($5.95): I told the waitress that we wanted guac added to our tacos but we somehow managed to get guac & chips instead. The guac was made with ripen avocados with an ultra buttery texture. It was lacking heat, so I had to slather hot sauce on it. The chips tasted hard and stale. 

*GRASSHOPPER TACO ($2.75): Meh, salty and dry! Fellow Yelper Heather C. had previously tried it and she told me they were super salty and she was right. The friend I went with compared the grasshoppers to eating dried shrimp which was a good comparison. 

The corn tortilla was dry, then to add fried overly salted grasshoppers that was equally dry tasted like I was eating the Morton Salt carton with prickly legs. I literally had to douse guac all over the tacos just to add some type of texture contrast. It really didn't do much b/c in the end it was still too dry to eat (comfortably that is). 

*CHICKEN MOLE CORN LEAF TAMALE ($2.75): DRY AND BLAND! We originally wanted the much hyped banana leaf tamale but the waitress said the wait was 2 hours! So instead, we got the corn leaf tamale. The edges of the masa were hard and crunchy and the chicken was dry and stringy. There was very little mole sauce and what little of it looked like it evaporated into the dry chicken. Hmmm, was the tamale from the previous night's batch?

*PUPUSAS ($2.95 ea):
The thick corn tortillas was crisp on the outside and soft in the inside however the fillings were very skimpy. 

-Beans and Cheese: The beans were creamy and rich and the cheese added a savory saltiness. 
-Pork: Dry and stringy. 

*TRES LECHES CAKE ($3): OVERHYPED! Don't hate me, but I honestly don't understand the hype around this cake. The cake was a sponge cake filled and topped with a light buttercream frosting. It looked and tasted like any white cake I can get from Safeway except the bottom layer was soaking in evaporated milk. I guess I was expecting the cake to a have a distinct "milky" taste and to me the only distinctive taste was butter and sugar. 

S E R V I C E:
The waitress was very nice but the food took forever to come. At the time, we were the only one there and it took over 20 mins to get the tacos and another 10 mins for the papusas and the tamale. I can't imagine how long the wait would be if the restaurant was packed. 

P A R K I N G: 
Difficult metered parking on weekends but not impossible. 

Aside from the Grasshopper Tacos satisfying my need for adventurous eating, the rest of the food items were meh. Maybe we came on an off day or at the wrong time, who knows but I can't justify coming back for mediocrity. HOWEVER, as much as I hate bugs esp spiders I DO want to try the Tarantula Tacos! This is where their 3 AM closing time comes in handy...

Yes, I plan to come here after 2 AM filled with enough liquid courage to believe that I'm the female version of Andrew Zimmerman, one with long hair and strutting in stilettos of course!
author: Cherylynn N.

description: We got office catering from this place and everyone had a hard time eating the food. I ate the Al Pastor, which was mostly pineapple and few chunks of gristle. Looking at the photos it seems that what they serve at the restaurant is identical. There are so many good taqueries in the city, I would skip this one.
author: Artur R.

description: I was craving for a tlayuda , it was really good big enough for two people, I also tried grasshopper tacos ,, quite exotic experience I really like it .... And this place is  ok But I wish they could remodeled with authentic Oaxacan theme atmosphere !!!!
author: Mayrah C.

description: Banana leaf tamales. That's all you need to get here. Everything else is pretty mediocre and you can probably get better elsewhere in the mission. But those banana leaf tamales are awesome. Horchata's pretty good too.
author: Derrick W.

description:
The super burrito was super filling and super delicious.

What it was missing:
+Its cape
+Its ability to save me from a debilitating food coma

What gives, Super Burrito?

Toward the end of our meal, we were served free Mexican hot chocolate. Just because.

Friendly busboys, great service, all around happy about this place. Glad to have found another excellent Mission Mexican food joint.
author: Adena B.

description: Some good mole negro chicken enchiladas. Definitely appreciated the delicious sauce on top of some alright chicken enchiladas. Definitely better when eaten with bean/rice/lettuce. I feel like you probably should share it, though, as there's a lot of food, and even more sauce, probably too much for one person.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
Pretty good hot chocolate, small
Location but if you want a late night taco it's open till 2
author: Rebecca C.

description: The torta with carnitas was great. Carnitas had a ton of flavor. I'd pass on the atole though; a bit expensive and wasn't really to my liking. Location is pretty close to the BART station. Should definitely go if you're in the area.
author: Krishan M.

description:
***Update***

I checked with my friend who also had the grasshoppers and he's sick today too. We were served bad grasshoppers.

********

The grasshopper tacos at $7 each are not only over priced but as someone who has eaten grasshoppers many times I can say with some authority that La Oaxaquena does not prepare them properly. 

Before you eat a grasshopper you should pinch the head and remove it pulling out the guts and unless you like the legs sticking in your teeth they should be removed as well. 

I suspect the grasshoppers used at La Oaxaquena are not meant for human consumption but ones purchased at either at a pet store meant for feeding other animals or at a bait shop.

The taco I had gave me the worst indigestion I've had in years.
author: Manny F.

description:
I love this place. This is my favorite place in the Mission! 

The first time I went here, I was with some friends. One of them suggested it mainly because of the insect dishes and the amazing hot chocolate (which was most definitely amazing). 

This was the first time I had every tried papusas so I bought 3 of them and shared. We also got a tlayuda, a torta, and a taco with crickets (although I think the crickets are banned now).

The pupusas we tried were BBQ chicken y queso, queso y loroco (Salvadorian flower), and zucchini with basil pesto and mozarella. All of them were so delicious! My favorite was probably the zucchini one. Be warned though, if you're ordering pupusas you should be aware that they are super filling!

The tlayuda was amazing although a little hard to tear apart. They used authentic mozarella from Oaxaca which was super good. The torta was also very good although super big and a bit hard to eat. So good though! They also serve the coca cola bottles from Mexico or something. The glass bottles that are made with cane sugar instead of refined sugar. You can taste the difference!

I suggest this place to everyone I know. The prices are pretty good for the amount of food you get, the place itself is very small and cozy, and the staff is friendly although sometimes a bit reserved. 

Street parking is kind of hard to find though so good luck.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Pretty good Pupusas and shrimp quesadilla.
I also had the chorizo and egg breakfast which wasn't on the menu but I asked for it anyway. 
The Pupusas weren't filled with maize like I've seen on many around the Mission. There were actually a good proportion of meat and maize. 
The rest of the food was typical of what's in the area. Overall solid meal.
author: Max G.

description:
My review is only about the food.   I ordered delivery thru a different app. I ordered the grilled chicken quesadilla.  The quesadilla looked nothing like the picture they advertised.   They put beans on a quesadilla.... Really?   I had to pay extra for sour cream and guacamole.   They put a drop of sour cream.   They put white and dark meat chicken and some where big chunks.  The food slid to one side and it looked awful.   I ended up throwing it away. 

I also ordered pupusas.  I know big mistake ordering Salvadorean food from a mexican restaurant.   They were tasteless.   The curtido wasn't done right.   Very dissapointing experience.  I'm definately not ordering from here again. Gross!
author: Molly M.

description: My friend told me about this place a few years back. First time I went I hesitated because it truly is a hole in the wall so you don't know what to expect. But hands down one of the best place for tamales. I love the classic corn tamales and the banana leaf tamales. Very delish!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Smells horrible. NOT authentic Oaxacan food!
Smells horrible. NOT authentic Oaxacan food!
author: Sandrine B.

description:
This is a very solid place to run to when craving a solid mexican fix for dinner. When your friend comes to town and wants that "authentic mexican fair from the mission", this is the place to go. 4 stars because the service could be more organized, but this is not an issue if you come ready to deal with a delayed service.

Value: 5 Stars, you can feed a party of 5, to fullness for $37... enough said
Quality: Authentic, solid home-style mexican fair (Oaxacan Style) dishes. No frills, just solid, tasty dishes.
Ambiance: Chairs to sit in and tables to support the food plates, not much else.
Patience: Please be patient, this operation is not optimized for wait time. May be 15 minutes for you food to come. Go to the counter to order and understand that these folks are multitasking to make you and their delivery service happy.

What we ate:
Talapia Tacos (Great!)
Shrimp Tacos (Great!)
Pork/Salsa Verde Corn Tamales (Great!)
Banana Leaf chicken mole (Good,not great; Maybe La Jalisco is better for mole?)
Cheese and Bean Papusa (Exceptionally good; we should have ordered the pork version)
author: Moses A.

description: The food wasn't too bad, and the people were quite good.  I would come here again for a late night.  However, it did take a while to order it.  It is also a bit heavy, so would recommend you not have any additional streneous activites afterwards.  This is definitely one those spots that is really awesome for late night drinking, but should be catious to go with others that are friends and not someone you want tot impress.
author: David L.

description:
LATIN-AMERICAN FOOD CRAWL IN THE MISSION: Fried grasshopper taco, flan, Mexican hot chocolate with chai spices and guajillo chili powder

The last stop on our Latin-American food crawl was actually unplanned. We were craving something sweet to top off the night and this place happened to be nearby. Unfortunately, the only dessert they had left was flan. The portion seemed a little small to split for our group, so I added a pitcher of what turned out to be the most insanely delicious Mexican hot chocolate you will ever drink. And of course, a fried grasshopper taco. 

The taco wasn't the best and not because it had fried bugs in it. I've had grasshoppers and locusts before, so I'm not averse to eating creepy-crawlies. Unfortunately, the spicy sauce that accompanied the taco was one of those "all we did was add pepper and no other flavor, so the sauce tastes like SPICY BURNING and nothing else" kinds of sauces. Not a very good sauce in any context, but especially with a flavorless tortilla and crunchy, flavorless bugs (grasshoppers are really bland on their own). The upside was that my friends clearly trust me with their lives in agreeing to eat fried grasshoppers for the first time with me. You can't buy that kind of confidence! :D

The flan was really good: a firm yet soft texture, sweet without being sickeningly so, and the right amount of caramel flavor without tasting like burning (as flan sometimes tastes). 

But the real winner here was the Mexican hot chocolate with spices and guajillo chili powder that I ordered on a whim. This hot chocolate deserves 10,000 stars. It is the most unique hot chocolate I have ever had across all cultures. It was thick but not viscous like American "gourmet" chocolate (cough*Ghirardelli*cough*), rich with the taste of natural cocoa, and most importantly, had a powerful "smoky" flavor that I've never had in a hot chocolate before. It was that smoky quality that had us pouring mug after mug, eyeing each other suspiciously while we tried to sneak in a little more for ourselves when we thought the others weren't looking. 

The staff here, like everywhere else, were really nice and brought us the hot chocolate in a big, heat-retaining metal pitcher without being asked. I'm fairly certain they gave us extra too. :)
author: Josephine L.

description: One of the most underrated places in the Mission. It's super cheap and if you are looking for authentic tacos, it's second to none in the Mission. You can get a great meal for $10.
author: Sebastian M.

description: We've come here a number of times over the years, and while it has been a bit spotty at times (the suadero (Braised Beef) was really dry, the al pastor was kind of weird), overall, we enjoyed it. However, going back tonight, it seemed that things had changed since we'd been a few months before. The rice seemed worse, the tamales were not as well assembled, and although I'm not a stickler for stellar restaurant hygiene, there were so many fruit flies that we gave up trying to get rid of them. The service was also really slow - there was only one person working, it seemed, and although she was really nice, everything took a long time to come out, despite the fact that for most of the time, we were the only people in the restaurant. I still love the tlayudas, but I think in general we'll probably go elsewhere in the future.
author: Lisa K.

description: Used Grub Hub for my order and specifically stated on my order that I am allergic to beans yet my first bite of my burrito was full of black beans! Pretty disappointing, could have been a delicious burrito but I can't say.
author: G G.

description: Totally authentic.  Just like Mexican street vendors.  I wish I lived closer.
author: Steve F.

description:
Bad place to eat.
After seeing that this place had 4 stars I wanted to try it, but I regret it. The service is  very slow and rude, took an hour to prepare our food (we were the only customers eating). When the food finally arrived it was bad, the popusas were flavorless and the tamales were salty. Also the place doesn't look clean at all, when we got there the tables were dirty and a waiter cleaned it with a dirty rug and the tables were stinky.
author: Jorge V.

description:
Racist staff.  
Horrible customer service.  
Delivery 3 hours late.  
Wrong food.  
NO REFUND!

I ordered over $100 worth of food from La Oaxaquena on Friday night for a dinner party.  We ordered at 8:15 and GrubHub said the order was expected to arrive between 9:15-9:25.  At 9:25 we called and they said our food was on it's way, it would be here in 15 minutes.... Well, we continued to call every 15 minutes for the next 2 hours and each time were told "15 more minutes".  The food finally arrived at 11pm.

When the food arrived, we opened it up and it was ALL WRONG.  There were tacos and tamales in there, but not the ones we ordered.

I called the restaurant to complain and was stuck on the phone for 25 minutes with a guy who said he couldn't really help me and he couldn't get a hold of his manager.  Finally he gave me his manager's number and told me to call him myself.

I got a hold of the owner (Harry) on the phone.  I explained to him that we had waited 3 hours for our food, and that I had been waiting to speak to him for the last 25 minutes because the guy at the restaurant couldn't give me a refund.  
Harry:  "I will speak to my staff about this, not you."
Me:  "Well, will you at least promise me that you'll sort this out and give me a refund?"
Harry:  "No, I'm not talking to you about this"
Me:  "So you won't promise me a refund?"
Harry:  "Did I say I wouldn't?!"
Me:  "Well, you didn't say you would."
Harry:  "Well, I didn't say I wouldn't!  I'm not talking to you about this!"
Me:  "Is this a f***ing joke?"
Harry (screaming, now):  "YOU DON'T SAY F*** TO ME ON THE PHONE".... more screaming...  he hangs up.

Meanwhile, on my other phone I'm still on the line with the restaurant.  At this point, we hear the female chef from the restaurant on the phone with Harry.  She's speaking in Spanish, calling me a "WHITE AMERICAN DEVIL", and laughing about the fact that she knew she put the wrong food in the order, but didn't think it would be a big deal.

I contacted GrubHub the next day for a refund and they contacted the restaurant.  Harry refused to give me a refund unless I apologize to HIM.  Really?  He's the one that called me a "White American Devil".  He's also the one who failed to provide the service that I paid over $100 for.  What a joke.

I tried to contact Harry but of course a woman who answered the phone told me I wasn't allowed to talk to him.

GrubHub offered me only $25 worth of free grub for this experience.  Hardly makes up for the $100+ order.  I would have expected GrubHub to be more helpful in this scenario as well, as clearly Harry knows my phone number and where I live, so I'd like to avoid any more direct contact with him if possible.

STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE!!!
author: Michelle F.

description: Dropped by after the bakery closed - but I was still able to get a carne asada taco and flan. The taco came from the late night hot dog cart and it was packed with savory goodness. The steak bites were a mouthful - unlike some other taquerias where they mince the meat up so it's just little pebbles.  The flan was dense and custardy with a strongly caramelized sugar taste. Yum!
author: Lydia N.

description: Ordered the pupusas and sopes. Pupusas were the star order. The Salvadorean flower with cheese was delicious.
author: Apolonia M.

description:
I will not be ordering from here again.  I placed a sizable order for delivery for myself and a group of friends. The food arrived over 2 hours late.  It was luke warm and half the items were incorrect (e.g. there were a few chipotle chicken tacos which I did not order and pork tacos that I did order were missing).

Since there were multiple glaring issues and I had already paid and tipped by credit card I called to complain.  The first person on the phone was unhelpful and seemed uncomfortable dealing with the complaint, so I asked to speak to the manager.  The manager was rude and unrelenting.

There are so many delivery options in SF; no point in bothering to deal with one like this.
author: Zack F.

description: Every Valentine's Day, hubby and I do taco night.  We pick a taco spot, usually a spot we haven't tried yet.  I've been to this place but I wanted to take my husband here because I had great experience the last 2 times I've been here.  Unfortunately, this last Vday, their food was off.  We got tacos (carne asada and al pastor).  Flavor was bland and disappointing.  Service was good though.
author: Claire J.

description:
Last Night's Birthday Dinner Party was Epic. I'm always out for a good time, but last night's dinner was soooo yelp-worthy. Happy Birthday Olivia! 

I can see how you could not know of  La Oaxaqueña, it's a small place on Mission near 17th, not the greatest neighborhood to go exploring. It looks like one of those places you would just pass by, but I highly recommend you give it a try.

The prices are so reasonable, we managed to feed a party of 8 for under $80.00. That's just unheard of. The staff was very accommodating and went above and beyond our expectations.

The guacamole is great. Usually I have to doctor it up, a little lime, salt or hot sauce depending. Nothing was needed. 

I ordered the Crab Enchiladas, which were served with Rice and Beans with a green tomatillo sauce. They were a bit spicy, but I like it like that. The crab was fresh tasting and everyone wanted a bite. 

I usually have the Chicken Mole Tamale which is wrapped in a banana leaf and is under $5. It's a meal in itself. The masa is really good and the flavor of the mole is subtle yet delicious. I've been making tamales for years, so I would like to think that I know a good when when I have one.

My highlight of the night was that I had a bite of a grasshopper taco. Yes, real GRASSHOPPERS! For me, it was like an episode of Fear Factor, icky. One little girl in our party was taking bets for money to eat them and made up to $10. Haha, smart girl. They were pretty crunchy and a little too leggy for me. I needed to wash down the little feelers with a few Coronas.

They also have Vension and Ostrich Tacos, if that's your thing. I just can't. I'm surprised I had the grasshoppers! Do I have cooties now? LOL. 

We had good times, lots of laughs and an excellent meal. I highly recommend this place if you want a good hot meal, maybe something a little different from the norm and in-expensive.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
I had worked up an appetite from dancing, and I wanted nothing more than some mouthwatering tacos at 1:00 a.m., and La Oaxaqueña delivered. I had the tacos de pollo desabrado with everything. 

Damn, they tasted like someone's Abuelita had made them with all the love in her heart and soul. You know, the kind of grandma whose grandkids are all chubby because she makes the most delicious food ever.  Yes. 

I can't speak to the other dishes, but those tacos were the best, and cha ching, the least expensive meal during my SF trip.
author: El L.

description:
I haven't been back for ages since having a baby shortly after my last review in 2012. I was craving the mole tamales again today, so I checked their hours on Yelp and went in eager anticipation.

The chairs were up on the tables, but the door was unlocked, so I went in and they told me they don't open until 5 pm. Sad! But they saw my face fall, and when I asked if there was any way I could buy something from them, the man at the front asked Rosa, and she came over and pleasantly agreed to make me my mole tamales! They were so nice! They also made me some of their awesome Mexican hot chocolate to go, told me I could eat there, and chatted with me. Totally made my day and gave me warm fuzzies about this great neighborhood :) Thank you!

BTW, the chicken mole tamales were as good as I remember.
author: Carol C.

description: YUM. So many good options for Mexican food in this area but im so glad we decided on this one! My friend and I each got a taco and pupusa, and then shared a chicken mole tamale. I had the Al Pastor taco and i thought it was pretty good. It wasn't my favorite though because there were pieces of pineapple in the taco and it made it a little too sweet. Al pastor should already be marinated with the pineapple so it became too sweet with the added pineapple. The revuelta pupusa was good. A little bit more bland than ive had at other places but still really solid -- i just love pupusas!! My favorite was probabaly the chicken mole tamale. I've never had a tamale with mole sauce in it and it was definitely interesting! Made it very moist. This was a great eating experience! :)
author: Isabella L.

description: Favorite place after a long party!! I like their super burritos with grilled chicken... One bad point,  the staff is pretty harassing when you are a girl,  I think it's pretty rude.
author: Lino M.

description:
We stopped here late at night while feeling peckish, making a slight detour to get here based on the reviews. We thought we were ordering a light snack: nachos with carnitas meat, and a Mexican hot chocolate for my friend. The nachos were a huge plate of crisp chips, melted sharp cheddar, mild jalapeños, and meltingly tender chunks of pork. 

And the Mexican hot chocolate...OMG. We understood immediately why every review mentions the hot chocolate. 

The hot chocolate came came as a pitcher of steamed chocolatey, cinnamon-infused warm goodness. The base is steamed milk--steamed milk as it's supposed to be but rarely is, with a creamy, foamy feel to the milk itself despite having only a moderate amount of foam on top, so the light, creamy, airy mouthfeel lasts till the very last drop. 

We did not try anything else, and we took half the nachos home to eat the next day. I will note that they also have bacon-wrapped hot dogs, for anyone needing one after midnight. Enjoy.
author: Cage H.

description: Tried the pork pupusa and the chicken tamale with mole sauce. So good!!!!!!!!!! Pupusa was the best I've ever had hands down
author: Roxy M.

description: They have really good burritos that will stuff you! I ordered a chipotle chicken burrito which had many exciting flavours. I was suprised.
author: Robert G.

description: As of 7/19/2015, La Oaxaquena does have chapuline (grasshopper) tacos, but no tarantula or ostrich. I asked about tarantula and was told that it's very hard to get, they will have it again in the future but, no, they don't know when.
author: Robb S.

description:
This place was pretty gross. 

The burrito was eh, and the place itself was eh. The customers were a mix of folks on laptop and folks that haven't showered in a couple of weeks. The owner was nice but the food wasn't that amazing. It's a stressful place to eat and the ambience is 1 star. I wouldn't dine here again.
author: Michael S.

description:
We figured that the fact the place felt dirty, catered to strange characters, and reeked strongly of bacon would be offset by the great food.  We were wrong.  My steak burrito was a bit bland, and I felt queazy the rest of the night.  

There are many excellent burrito places in the Mission - skip this one.
author: Don T.

description: Living here my whole life and never dining at this spot was a crime. This spot is tiny, a bit rough around the edges, but the food and hospitality of the staff is top notch. Such a very delicious meal made but lovely people! Will definitely become a regular here.
author: James I.

description:
That was tha BEST Veggie Burrito, I have ever Had. Ok so what it's late and I ate it in entirely. Ok let's not down play that...Oh M G I can't even process what I just did cause me eating the entire burrito is greed plus greed yet that was EXCEPTIONAL! NomYumNomYum
Have to add since my life was changed sat evening by eating here. I had to have one Sunday. I tried to call to place an order to go and was told they were closing as it's not busy. I was a block away and was turned down. I told the so not empathetic chef or employee I drove from across town and I was going to cry but he wouldn't budge. As I drove by I did see a couple inside. No gold stars for customer service!
author: domenique c.

description: I like La Oaxaquena! Good chicken mole. Kind service. A great deal because of the low prices. Not a spiffy date place, but a place to good for quick, inexpensive eats. More of an authentic decor and comes with a Mexican client base to boot. Open until 9:30pm.
author: Ted R.

description: Really good hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint.
author: Heather R.

description:
I initially wanted to try the grasshopper tacos here, but alas, they have stopped serving them. Actually, I'm relieved, because some of the pictures don't look that appetizing.

If you find yourself in the Mission, stop by this place and try the chicken tamales wrapped in banana leaf. It is so delicious! I'm not really a fan of mole but the sauce inside the tamale was not too sweet or bitter, it was perfect. I was scooping it up with the tortilla chips! The masa was super moist, I could just eat that with the mole. I think the banana leaf gives it an extra level of flavor and juiciness. It's hard to explain how tasty and juicy that tamale was.  As I'm writing this review, I'm thinking about driving over there for lunch.

We tried a few different tacos - carne asada, tilapia, longaniza and pastor. They were all good but I'm going to stick with the chicken mole tamales. 

They don't service alcohol at La Oaxaquena but they have a bunch of different aguas frescas to choose from.
author: Mel P.

description: Best (spicy Mexican) hot chocolate & mole in SF. My only complaint is that they're really only open late. I keep coming here to eat and forgetting they're not even open until 5pm. Give or take bc I don't think their hours are as advertised or that they're strict with them. I wish they would open for LUNCH. And BRUNCH. Was there a breakfast burrito on the menu? I may recall incorrectly but it doesn't matter you couldn't have it for breakfast anyway?! :P I'm hungry :(
author: Leah T.

description: I love the lengua and grasshopper tacos!
author: Patricia G.

description:
Wow, this place was really good...

We tried the following:

Banana Leaf Tamale with Chicken and Mole - fantastic...a flavorful corn masa filled with tender chicken with a very savory and rich mole sauce.  This is great as a meal or appetizer to share.

Blue Corn Quesadilla - not exactly what you'd expect...a fairly thick, bright blue-green (nope, don't think it's natural) tortilla topped with cheese, your meat of choice (the braised beef was amazing) lettuce and spicy salsa.  Very good and satisfying.

Mexican Hot Chocolate - a sweet and warm drink with the flavor of chocolate, cinnamon and some light spice flavors.

Tres Leches Cake - a pretty light version of the popular Nicaraguan cake...this wasn't too heavy and was perfect for ending the meal.

I really enjoyed my experience and can't wait to go back...yum!
author: Ken G.

description:
Got a office lunch catered form them and I was happy with their catering. Their Churros was awesome. Nice food and they had labels defining the ingredients and if they are vegetarian :)   

I wish to see them more and more.  Definitely would recommend them for catering.
author: Pooja N.

description:
This place is hella delicious. Tamales. Mole. Mole with tamales. Papusas. And he gave us free tres leches. 

Ignore the bullet holes in the wall cause this place is painted in Jarritos colors. Legit.
author: Mary L.

description: Literally waited for 45 minutes for a Burrito and a quessadilla. Do not waste your time. Way too many other and much better places within walking distance.
author: Rish T.

description:
Stuff I've done:

1. Wrote the first Twilight book  (but the publisher made me delete the part where Blade fucks up the entire Cullen family, hence the series. Pussies)

2. Welded the new portion of the bay bridge single handedly with the laser beams in my eyes (in your face, superman)

3. Had sex with Rihanna (Pretty awesome. You know that song that goes "Hey Na Na, What's my name? What's my name?" I'm Na Na. Yeah, she's talking to me, son)

4. Ate grasshoppers in the San Francisco

Or did I? I could be judgmentally impaired due to the fact that some of the biblical locusts that I just digested must have consumed some peyote before making it into the frying pan. 

I kid, I kid...

Joking aside, La Oaxaquena is one of the best kept secrets in SF. It's located on Mission street past the invisible line most hipsters won't cross (yes, you , stay on Valencia).

They serve typical tacos, burritos, quesadillas, and also liven up the menu with sopes, tiayudas, and pupusas. 

It really gets interesting when you choose the meat filling. Yes, they have all the regular stuff, including tongue, pork, beef, and chicken, but where it gets downright epic is the offerings of ostrich http://media1.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/7c8Ca-H3t4HOdyj0XdIcdQ/l 
, cow brains, chapulines (the grasshoppa!) http://media3.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/yVqlhKHge5itXCXL4qh6Qg/l, and straight up fucking tarantula. 

Unfortunately, the tarantulas are only available seasonally, so call ahead. Until then, just order a side of fried locusts http://media3.ct.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/5kZJBqZDVlVLsKS4bfZp2Q/l and eat them with some salsa. 

If this is too much for you, don't worry, they have a fantastic bakery on site, THE BEST MEXICAN HOT CHOCOLATE EVER ZOMG, and bacon wrapped hot dogs out front. They also serve up street tacos, too. Double whammy, inside and out. They have something for everyone.

Oh, and wanna know what happened to that e-scary looking grasshopper who's photo was all enlarged National Geographic style, trying to mean mug the camera? He went into this taco http://media4.px.yelpcdn.com/bphoto/agXCC2OhW-a8NLjIAh4haQ/l . He tasted a little bit like grass (you are what you eat), but he was still good. 

So all the wannabe foodies who've seen a season or two of Bizarre foods or No Reservations, time to man up. Only adventurous eaters need apply.
author: Jason C.

description:
Home of the grasshopper and tarantula tacos and famous for Oaxacan mole and tamales, La Oaxaquena specializes in Oaxacan cuisine. They also have tamer meat choices, a case of baked goods (cookies, cake slices, muffins), espresso drinks, aguas frescas, and Oaxacan spices for sale. Take in the Oaxacan art on the bright orange walls as you wait for your food. 

* Muffin (50 cents): this was a firm, dense, like yellow cake muffin, without frosting, it was good but I'd like it a little lighter and less dense
* Venison tacos ($5.95): it wasn't worth it because it had way too many onions and reminded me of fajitas only with cubes of venison meat. The onion pieces were big (I like them finely chopped), the venison was very lean and chewy but nothing special.  I didn't think it tasted as good as a regular taco (the meat and seasonings weren't distinctive). 
* Turkey banana leaf wrapped tamale with Oaxacan mole ($4.50): I really liked this (they deserve their tamale fame), a huge square tamale, with soft, smooth corn meal, sweet yet savory stewed turkey meat. The flavors were complex and interesting.
author: Lolia S.

description:
My last real holiday was spent in Oaxaca and I absolutely fell in love with the city, which is quite easy to do.  Upon hearing about La Oaxaqueña in my own city, I made it a point to visit ASAP.  

While reading through the menu at La Oaxaqueña, I discovered that they serve chapulines!  And tlayudas, hot chocolate, and even bacon wrapped hotdogs out front!  All too exciting.

We tried the hot chocolate with chili powder, turkey tamale with mole sauce, and mole chicken entree.  

Though it was a lot of food for $10, the mole chicken (with tortillas, rice, and salad on the side) really wasn't that interesting and I doubt I'd order it again.  But the massive banana leaf wrapped tamale was just delicious.  The hot chocolate came in a metal pitcher - probably twice the size I expected.  It was very good too, though couldn't exactly compete with my memories of the real thing.  

Still, I'd recommend the tamales and hot chocolate.  For myself, I'll be back for the grasshoppers and tlayudas, and of course another tamale.
author: Joanne G.

description:
My fellow yelper Cherylynn N. told me about this place and their grasshopper tacos. 

I was feeling adventurous and decided to give this place a try after looking at their meat selections. Me and the boyfriend met some friends at the restaurant. Parking wasn't too bad for a Saturday, we parked only a block away. The restaurant itself is pretty small, approximately about 6 tables. Thank goodness there weren't a lot of people when we went.

The lady who took our order was really nice but ordering was confusing, because we ordered so many different tacos. I ordered the grasshopper and ostrich taco, the boyfriend wanted to try the tarantula taco but they didn't have any. We also ordered the horchata and tres leches cake. As our orders started to come out, it got even more confusing because we didn't know which meat was which (we ordered 9 tacos all together)! 

Now onto the taste, the grasshoppers were super salty and I wasn't able to finish the whole thing! =[ On top of that they didn't have any ostrich meat, which was really disappointing. The horchata was really good and so was the tres leches cake (best tasting thing we ordered). I tried some of the tacos the bf ordered like the venison taco, which was the best one we ordered in my opinion.

Overall every thing was pretty good (except for those salty grasshoppers) but I was disappointed that they didn't have ostrich and tarantula tacos. *sniff*
author: Heather C.

description:
I hope you'll still respect me in the morning even though I am being loose & free with my five stars card. I'm giving La Oaxaquena the coveted "perfect score" after just one visit (well technically two-ish) because they made a lasting impression on me with their home cooked offerings & hospitable service. 

It all started on November 1st, the day the Giants won the World Series (what a wonderful way to start off the month.) Apparently driving around, celebrating & high fiving other fans really works up an appetite. I suggested the boys stop for a bacon wrapped hot dog since we were in the Mission & lo & behold, we drive right pass the cart (situated in front of La Oaxaquena.)

I don't eat hot dogs (insert your own joke here) so while the guys were chomping away lovin' life, I was sipping on a Guava Jumex. (They let you eat your hot dogs in the restaurant.) There was nothing for me to do so I looked over their menu. Everything looked so good that I dragged the bf here for lunch the very next day.

The bf ordered tacos & I had:
-- chicken mole corn leaf tamale ($2.75): I'm not usually a mole fan, but LO's is very edible, not at all overpowering. Chicken was a mix of white & dark meat & was juicy. Masa was flavorful.
-- rajas corn leaf tamale ($2.50): tomatoes, jalapeno & cheese: slightly tangy & a little spicy. Get it!
-- champurrados ($1.75): similar to the filipino version except in this warm horchata/chocolate drink, there are no pieces of rice; it is completely smooth, silky & foamy. Get it!
