I never noticed LO before but now that I've had it, I've been thinking about it constantly. I'm a little embarrassed at how smitten I am after just two brief encounters...don't judge, a girl's got needs.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Finally, some good authentic Mexican food!  La Oaxaquena, is comparable to all of the good Mexican food that I get back in San Diego.

I had the banana leaf chicken mole tamales, lengua taco, and guacamole.  All were very very good!  The Mexican hot chocolate was a great way to close out the meal and is the best I've had yet.  La Oaxaquena is clutch- I'm totally going back.
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
No, I didn't come for the famed grasshopper taco, though I hear they don't serve it anymore. Regardless, I wasn't in the fear factor mood, so I kept it traditional, or traditional compared to eating grasshopper. Lengua and cabeza tacos please!

...and there were FANTASTIC.  The meat was tender, and the tacos were served with peppers and grilled onions on the side. And I've been on a grilled onion kick lately so that was nice.

My girlfriend ordered a pupusa, and I've never had them before, so I have no point of comparison, but the one here was pretty good. Finally, they had a bacon hot dog cart inside the taqueria. And really, who doesn't love those bacon hot dog carts around the city?

I'll be back for more, right after I visit the 4314 or so taqueria I've also been meaning to hit up in the city.
author: Stan A.

description:
TaMehles anyone?

I've been in some pretty sketchy hole in the walls in my time, La Wa-Ha-Kin-Ya is definitely on their toes but not touching the bar. 

Over the years I've put up with smelly banos, old leaning buildings, sticky floors, staff eating MceeD's when they're surrounded by food etc... These atrocities can be easily forgotten in the event that you have some killer recipes that transcend time. 

Unfortunately for these folks they're mehking it hard for meh to wanna come back. 

What's the good?
- Hot dogs wrapped in bacon with pickled jalapenos.
- Banana leaf tamales that are huge and cheap and better quality than the yellar.
- Open till 2 a.m. because you'd be swooning over a burnt cracker smeared in cheese whiz after enough alcohol.
- The folks running the place were really nice.

What's the bad?
- The yellow taMehles are strangely greasy, dry, yet mushy? I know tamales aren't all that easy to make but how in the head scratching hades can you mehke something that is greasy, mushy and dry all at the same time?
- Squirt bottle salsa was nowhere near a chile that I could see. Its some kinda tomatoeey concoction that comes in sweet red tomato juice or sour green tomato juice.
- Chill out on the pork fat bro a lil' goes along way but too much and your patrons are running home like a wounded dear.

If I do find myself back in your hole you can rest assure the beer convinced me.
author: R J.

author: Nicholas F.

description: This place is either closed or about to close.  We have come on three different days in the middle of the day and it's closed with no signs or notice about its status.
author: Jorge C.

description:
Hm, I was a little disappointed with the food here. We came in on Saturday for a late lunch. I had already checked out the menu on their website and I was so excited! Grasshopper tacos? Banana leaf tamales? Venison? Ostrich? Hellz yea! 

First if all, the staff here is wonderful & so accommodating. There were 6 of us & we tried cramming into a table for 4 but it just didn't work. The place is small so it's difficult if you have a large party. But the lovely waitress rearranged a bunch if tables just so we could all fit. How sweet! Then she helped up with out orders, letting us know if we were ordering too much or too little. 

I tried a bit of everything on the table (except for the grasshopper tacos, nope, just couldn't do it). The only thing that blew me away were the pupusas. I could've eaten 10 of them. Even the simple bean & cheese pupusa was amazing. The tofu mole banana leaf tamale was just OK. I guess I'm just not a fan of their mole sauce. The venison taco had good flavor but the meat was very chewy. It made if difficult to eat as a taco so I ate it open-faced. The guac was good & I liked the tri-colored tortilla chips. 

They were nice enough to give us a slice of tres leches cake & flan on the house for dessert.  Sweet!
author: Erin S.

description: Kind of pricey, but if you want to be a little adventurous, try a grasshopper taco. Very crispy and flavorful. I was kind of worried they would taste a little gamey, but not at all. Delicious Horchata as well. And if you like tamales, I highly suggest the Banana Leaf Wrapped Tamales. The sweetness of the banana leaf really adds to the already deliciousness. The wait staff is very friendly, and really wants to make sure you enjoy your meal. YOU GO NOW!
author: Ron Z.

description: The food here is fantastic. Great prices too. I highly recommend the banana leaf tamales.
author: Gabriel M.

description:
Don't be fooled by Oaxaquena's website! Sure, they may advertise such crowd-drawing delicacies as venison, ostrich, and -- my favorite -- chapulines (grasshoppers). But they don't have these things and, from the sounds of it, haven't had them for ages. 

What's worse, they seem totally unaware that advertising such things and then not having them is problematic. When I asked the waitress why they don't seem to have any of the really cool menu items they so prominently highlight on the website, she said -- with no apparent irony -- "Yeah, we get a lot of people who come in just because we say we have those things ..." In other words, they're even totally aware that people come in specifically for things like chapulines and ostrich, and yet show no real concern for the fact that they don't have them or for the fact that the online menu says that they do. 

And besides, the food that we did have -- plainly traditional, wholly unremarkable, Mexican staples -- was certainly nothing special. Not particularly bad, but not particularly good, either. And nothing really at all that spoke to the place's supposed Oaxacan roots, except a smattering of mole dishes and a few tamales that were supposedly "authentic Oaxacan".  (The waitress didn't seem to know what made them so, and didn't seem to know very much about Mexican food more generally.)

So, why did we go here instead of to any of the other 100s of Mexican places in the Mission? Well, clearly because those other places aren't willing to lie about their offerings. That makes Oaxaquena more than a waste of time. It's also a wasted opportunity.
author: Ethan H.

description:
I came to La Oaxaquena for one of their most well-known dishes: the chicken mole tamale. And it's well-known for a reason! The banana leaf flavor in the cornmeal nicely complemented the mole filling. I'm also a self-proclaimed chicken hater but this meat was really tender and un-fatty, something I don't typically expect from Mexican joints, so I'll have to make an exception for these tamales. They're also huge, so even though I hear they raised the prices from about 3.75 to 4.50, it's still a great deal.

If I were bold enough I'd try the grasshopper. Though I hear  the owner is actually being asked to stop serving it, which is a shame. At least there is still one (non-insect) item on the menu worth trying!
author: Clarice W.

description: We waited for 45 minutes while everyone in the line got their orders. After that we had o ask to get a refund. Making a burrito ain't that hard. Get your act together.
author: NB K.

description:
Very tasty mexican food! Had their chicken, steak, and spicy pork. Very flavorful. I also really enjoyed their salsa.

Looking forward to eating here again.
author: Mark D.

description:
Their food was so horrible neither myself nor my boyfriend could finish it. That never happens since we're both not  particularly picky eaters and to be quite frank, my boy can eat!

Food was tasteless,  their sauces for the enchiladas had an odd taste, and their sopes tasted rancid.  Also, they didn't have grasshoppers when I was here. 

Alas, perhaps growing up with Mexican/ latin food for dinner every night was a curse as nothing can compare to mom's cooking..OR perhaps I just might know what I'm talkin about, just sayin.  Anyway you've been warned!
author: Gabriella C.

description:
Awesome food.  I tried the grasshopper taco.  It was more of a novelty.  

Try the chicken mole tamale in banana leaves.  That is the best.
author: Alan M.

description: First time trying this restaurant and the last. We came all the way from Lake Tahoe Ca. We saw that this restaurant had 4 start, and we wore excited to try it. I've never had a bad experience in a restaurant in San Francisco. This is the worse experience I had in my life. Service was horrible. The waitress was super slow. It took an hour for our food to arrive. And only to be the worst food that I have ever tried. Even my brother in law who's not a picky eater, couldn't eat his food.  I gave it a star because the Mexican hot chocolate was the only good thing that I tried.
author: Ana B G.

description: Worse service, took 45 minutes to get a burrito and it was cold. There was hardly any business either. Will never come back here again. Very disappointed
author: Riley M.

description:
I am ready to go on Survivor because I've eaten grasshoppers!

...OK, so maybe not quite Survivor, but I'm really proud of myself for trying out the grasshopper taco at this little gem in the Mission district!

La Oaxaquena is a small, hole-in-the-wall restaurant and bakery and I'm so glad I stumbled upon it while checking out the mural alleyway! They have a pretty awesome selection of food to choose from, ranging from banana leaf tamales, tlayuda (pizza-like dish!), and the aforementioned grasshopper tacos! The walls are painted a bright cheery color and you instantly feel right at home!

My friend and I decided on the banana leaf tamale with chicken in a mole sauce, a grasshopper taco, a venison taco, and the Mexican hot chocolate. Can I just say that the hot chocolate was AMAZING?! It definitely IS one of the best I've tasted! HMMmmmm!! So delicious!
The venison taco was OK...kinda sparse on the meat; however, the grasshopper taco was pretty tasty! The grasshoppers were light, crispy, slightly salty, and lemony! Heck, I would buy a bag of them and eat that instead of chips!
Banana leaf tamale = delicious! It's fun to unwrap it :) There was a choice of chicken or turkey, so I think next time I'll try turkey!

The only downside to the meal was the SUPER spicy side of onions and jalapeno peppers that they put on top of the tacos. Be warned! Even though I pushed them off to the side, the spicy-ness was still on part of the taco :( I was literally tearing up and perspiring.

The tacos were kinda expensive ($5.95 each!), but I mean, venison and grasshoppers?! They're so unique! The Mexican hot chocolate was definitely worth the price. There's A LOT...easy to share between 2, maybe even 3 people. The tamale was very reasonable too and it was a generous-sized portion!

The staff is very nice and helpful! After my friend walked around a bit, I had to use the bathroom, so I went back to La Oaxaquena and the guy let me use the bathroom again! Whoo hoo!

Will DEFINITELY be back for more! :D
author: Kei H.

description: DO NOT ORDER DELIVERY FROM HERE. EVER. Almost 3 hours late, and the order was 100% wrong. Not a single thing was correct. Reaching the restaurant by phone after was VERY difficult (took 45 minutes because they only have 1 line) and they were VERY rude about the entire situation. Never supporting this business again.
author: Maximus M.

description:
This is a place I want to love but aside from the street tacos cooked outside on the grill one time, nothing I've gotten here has been good. Tried the goat stew once, and it tasted like warm soap. Got a spicy pork super burrito (I know, wrong venue...but it was 1 am and the night had involved drinks), and it was pretty much cold on the inside and had nothing really going for it....tasted like mushy dressed in sour cream. The chicken mole tamale was okay, but didn't stand out for me. The size of it is pretty impressive though. The pupusas are sort of sad little thin things here. 

BYOB is great though.
author: Carolyn F.

description:
*Veggie Burritos - 3 stars
-Decent burritos

*Bean and Cheese Papusa -3 stars
-I've ordered this once here and LOVED it
-I've ordered this once here and HATED it
-hit or miss

*Mexican Hot Chocolate - 5 stars!
-Best hot chocolate ever
-HUGE serving (can serve 4 very easily)

*Nachos w/ the works - 4 stars
-We devoured them
-Lots of toppings

*Sundried Tomato Papusa - 1 star
-This guy tastes really wierd.
-Avoid getting, if you can
I think the goat cheese isn't exactly goat cheese or tastes incredibly diferent after being heated up that much or something....

Overall, they have a delicious hot sauce + salad that comes with every dish
author: Neeharika B.

description:
I'm happy I finally got around to La Oaxaqueña. I checked off a few of my life's to do's in one sitting.

1. Eat a Papusa - they have 4 kinds. You can order them individually, or have an order of three. We didn't know which ones to get, so we left that up to the kitchen to choose for us. All were all tasty.

2. Eat their 'infamous' chicken mole tamale, wrapped in a banana leaf. Soooo goood. One order is huge! Something about the corn masa, expands in your belly and suddenly you're about to pop!

3. Ate my 'happy food',  guacamole + chips - their large is true to its word and tasty.

Other notes about this eatery - cheap, large portions, delicious, and the service is friendly and helpful. More unique offerings including ostrich meat and grasshoppers. Taco cart outside. They also have a bakery, but we were too stuffed to try.

I look forward to coming back hopefully soon.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Worst. Service. Ever.

We came in. We ordered. We waited. Fourty minutes. We saw people come and go. We saw people get their food. When I got up to ask for our food I was told "This is not fleur de lys", you don't have four or five waiters, if you want service, go somewhere else." Actually, I don't care about the service. I just want my food. And what did I get slammed down on my table? Someone elses order. Cold. Like, frozen. Not what we ordered. We tried to get it worked out. And got yelled at.  So we got up to leave. 

Harry, I think who is one of the owners, did apologize, and asked us to stay. But with the service we had recieved? I am sorry, I don't need service, but I also dont need to be YELLED at. Or wait forty minutes for a GLASS OF WATER or MY FOOD when other people come and go with theirs. 

One star for Harry trying to make up for his incredibly rude staff. I'll try it again for lunch sometime. I hope that the incredibley rude waiter will not be there. I think I will be able to write a more positive review then, as this place seems to have really positive things going for it.
author: Danielle L.

description:
Personally, I'm not a big fan of mole...so I wouldn't have wanted to try this place out. However, I walked by this place earlier last week when one of the employees was making bacon wrapped hotdogs...oh, how I miss LA! The employee convinced me to check out the menu and it looked appetizing.

The staff here is really nice. You definitely feel welcome. A lot of the local mission people frequent this place as well.

We ordered the guacamole, which was good and really filling. I definitely would advise against getting it if you want to finish your entree. I don't remember the names of the entrees I tried. One of them was basically a mexican pizza...there was meat, beans and cheese on top of a tortilla crust. It was too dry. I think it would have tasted better if there was some sauce or anything to make it taste a little lighter. I ended up putting some guacamole on it.

The other one was a shrimp dish in a tomato sauce. It also came with rice and beans. It was pretty good. The shrimp was nicely cooked.

The portions are huge and filling. If you don't like heavy food, don't come here. If you do, come quickly!
author: Margaret R.

description:
WTF? How are you people getting food other than bacon-wrapped hot dogs? I have been by here at least 7 times in the past few weeks, and many more times since June, and I have not had an opportunity for a freaking papusa. This was my favorite restaurant, and then they closed for remodeling, and now every time I go in someone bums me out by saying, "no," "over there," "only hot dog," and "cerrado." I don't speak enough Spanish to get anything more useful out of it. They don't have their hours up, their website still has a full menu
what
the
hell
I just want to have the best Mexican hot chocolate in town and eat my papusas and maybe a few tamales and some flan and be the happiest girl on earth. When the heck do I need to go there to get something other than hot dogs?!
Gah!
author: Ljótur H.

description: Rolled up here because it was open and within walking distance of where we were at. The food was delicious. I had a loroco pupusa and a vegetarian tamale wrapped in banana leaves. SO GOOD! They are also open late and inexpensive. Win win!
author: Jen V.

description:
Aliens of earth (or just San Francisco).

This place is goods. I should know. Half of my family were resident aliens from Mexico. 

This is not Taco Bell. Or any other other bastardizations of southern Mexican foods. Sorry, no "chips", not a taqueria, and not really the next hipster pop up best thing cuz it's on my blog dealio either. But they have wizened up to that American palate and offed variations on classic complex earthy flavors of southern Mexican cooking. 

That and the dudes that run this place are really cool (one is actually South Asian, so beat that nouveau fusion cuisine), they are always giving suggestions on dishes, and every time I go there they offer me a  taste of something I haven't tried before for free. Really sweet family place.
author: Hell G.

description:
It's easy to get jaded with Mexican food in the Mission given all the seemingly "this is the best" recommendations.  This place is a win in my book because it has some Oaxacan specialties like tlayuda.  So my experience here is about expanding my Mexican palate rather than comparing the upteenth-million carnitas (which I didn't even see on the menu).

Guacamole: So it's not hand hacked at your table, but despite the lack of showmanship it still tastes extremely fresh.  I liked that it had chunks of avocado instead of that nasty baby food-style purée you get at some joints.

Tlayuda: I thought I knew Mexican, but this was a new treat for me.  The size of a medium pizza, this crispy double layer tortilla is topped with refried beans, non-melted cheese, lettuce, avocado and probably other goodies.  I think it's baked, not fried, so it has a really light texture which is a good thing considering the daunting size.  This could potentially be a meal for two non-obese people!

Tinga de Pollo: Hmm, so soft and so spicy!  This is a perfect topping for whatever dish you wish to consume it on.  Way better than that asado stuff.

Chicken Mole Enchiladas: Everyone raves about the mole sauce, but I wasn't a huge fan.  It didn't taste as complex as it should and had a weird funk to it.  The chicken inside was dry and boring... maybe I was spoiled by the tinga de pollo?

Crab Enchiladas: Boo!  The salsa verde on top was awesome and pairs so well with shellfish, if only the crab was better.  This seemed to be the minced sort of crab from a can rather than fresh large chunks.  I would have gladly paid extra for the real deal...

Mango Lemonade: The lemonade base was both sweet and tangy, a nice balance.  I think I saw them use some sort of daiquiri syrup to flavor the mango so it tasted a tad artificial.  Why no mango pulp from a can?
author: Adam B.

description:
I went there for the grasshopper tacos which had a lemon taste to them. Delicious.

Tried going back there for tarantula but they said they had to stop selling both the grasshopper and tarantulas. 

Haven't gone back since then.
author: Evan W.

description: ONCE AGAIN, Showed up to inaccurate hours. Showed up at 8:45 to a closed kitchen. Manager/owner stated they "had problems" in the kitchen, their cook "left". Second time I've tried to eat here and they have not been open at a decent hour when they clearly advertise they are open. Disappointing and makes me think this place is going out of business soon....
author: Eliza F.

description:
Still hopping.

Grasshopper is back. http://sf.eater.com/archives/2011/06/08/quote_of_the_day_9.php

Venison tacos have replaced the ostrich tacos.

Soyrizo tortas have been added.

Haven't tried the first one. Skipped the second one. Devoured the third one. Spicy delicious mess that needed two hands and a fork.

Service remains exceptional. Would love to give another four stars but the $7.50 plus tax was a little on the expensive side for a sandwich.

After three visits definitely suggest you hop on over.
author: Jason B.

description:
Great tip for you party goers, drunken youngn's who happen to be in the Mission, who have cravings for oily goodness, and for the germ-a-phobes who fear to purchase food from the food carts that hang outside and you're not sure if it's legit....there's an actual restaurant/ small store that serves those damn bacon wrapped hotdogs you've been hearing and dreaming about!!

THIS rating is just for the joy of finding their bacon wrapped hotdogs. HAVE NOT tried any other dishes here. 

BLECH! Do not drink the water.

P.S. While you're at it, this is a great place to practice your Spanish. The folks get a kick out of it that you're acting a fool (esp. the drunks.) Plus it gets you extra toppings.
author: Christine F.

description: Catered lunch from here today and it was great!! Huge burritos filled with amazing, yummy ingredients. We will definitely order from there again!
author: Jaimie C.

description: My friends and I were visiting SF and so after hours of plane delay, we finally arrived at night. There weren't too many places that were still open so we chose this place to grab some quick food. After walking through the poorer streets of SF (it is still not as bad as home), we walked inside the tiny store of La Oaxaquena. We ordered several kinds of tacos and oh my goodness, they were superb. Their sauce was spicy and sour (my favorite style) top with radishes. Their tacos taste different from the tacos I have ever had which makes me sad because it will probably be a while before I return to SF. I definitely recommend this place to taco lovers!
author: Thy T.

description: If your yelp posted hours are 6am to 2am, how is it that you're closed to patrons at 5pm Monday.?  Just curious.
author: Randy A.

description:
Grashopper tacos and cured pork magic!

Thats right people, grasshopper tacos.  That was the first thing I noticed as I scanned the menu at this classic hole-in-the wall taqueria.  Now most people would be freaked out by the bugs, but my reaction was different.  Immidiately I'm thinking, "This place bleeds authenticity."  I was in the mood for a super burrito, "wet," with pork, so that is what I opted for.  THIS WAS PORK PERFECTION!  This was bar-none, the best burrito with pork I've ever had.

(+) The pork was cecina, a bit different than the standard carnitas I usually see.  If you are unfamiliar with cecina, look it up.  All I can say is dried, salted, cured, spiced, fatty perfection.  

(+) The burrito was capped off with a perfect distrobution of classic "super burrito fixins," like refried beans, rice, cheese, sour cream and guacamole, not to mention a healthy dose of fresh cilantro.

(+) The mole was excellent as well.  Much better than the average taqueria

(+) I also tried a side of guacamole to dip the complimentary tortilla chips, and that was very tasty too.  Again, no skimping on cilantro in the guac.

(+) This place is SUPER CHEAP.  6 bucks for the burrito, and a couple more for the guac and a Mexican Coke.  Not surpising prices for a taqueria, but notable considering how great the food was.

(-) The tortilla chips were a bit weak. They tasted store-bought.  

I ENJOYED THE SERVICE.  I was not vigorously attended to, but the server was friendly, informative, and I easily got in and out fast enough to return to work on time.  I tend to enjoy places that don't nag you with service, and come on people: What kind of cheap taqueria has five star, super attentive service?  You don't go to taquerias for that.  In fact, I don't even expect or hope to converse in English.  Why, you ask?  Because there is no need to.  If you've ever been to a taqueria, the whole process is pretty damn simple.  I think a monkey could figure it.

THE BOTTOM LINE:

(+) An incredible taqueria, and one of the only spots to offer cecina.
author: Matthew S.

description:
After one visit, I'm a huge fan.  I style myself a bit of a mole snob, and I've never been too excited about the mole options in this city.  La Oaxaquena does it right.  Try their mole chicken enchiladas -- these aren't your typical gross, gooey, cheesy enchiladas; they're just chicken wrapped in a corn tortilla with a bucket of mole sauce poured over it and a sprinkling of cotija cheese (served with mediocre beans and rice).  I'd mainline the mole sauce if I could.  It is rich, thick, and full of flavor.

The tlayuda with tinga de pollo was also a hit.  (Compare the tinga here versus anywhere else, like the burrito place in South Park -- night and day).  The tamales and sopes were perfectly good, but nothing to gush about.  Portions were substantial, and the prices ridiculously low.

My only nit -- and it's a significant one given that La Oaxaquena would otherwise be a sure fire 5 star wonder -- is that the cooks have a heavy hand with the salt.  Easily corrected, but it scares me a bit that the problem showed up in every dish we ordered...  I also wasn't a fan of the hot chile dust that seeps into the restaurant from their taco cart outside.  My eyes!
author: Laurence W.

description: Banana leaf chicken tamale is absolutely delicious! I would recommend this place for a quick bite for singles, couples or small groups. The space isn't large but the food is very good!
author: N C.

description:
The mark is high for burritos in the Mission and this place falls way short. 
It is super tempting when you're hungry late at night to skip the line at Tequeria Cancun but just stay in line because the service is pretty low, you'll pay just as money and the burrito is way worse (I've had both meat and veggie).
author: Ojus P.

description:
Oh it was great ... waiter was extremely friendly and even included a free piece of flan.

My chicken burrito was tasty and juicy .. chips colorful crispy and salsa has a spicy kick ... 

Atmosphere is color and they even had xmas songs playing ... all around good time I will definitely be back.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Got into the city with my girlfriend and we were starving. Searched for a cheap place and it was packed. Walked by and noticed it was food right up our belly alley and pretty inexpensive. She ordered pupusas and I got a super burrito. Turns out our starving bellies could have shared either dish. The salsa were great, the meals were great and the prices were amazing! Although the restroom was lacking a proper smell and paper towels the food made up for it!

If we are in the neighborhood and get an hunger for Mexican we know where to go.
author: Jena V.

description:
Bacon-wrapped hot dog? You can't really go wrong with that. The tacos are good, albeit a tad bit too spicy.

Good for cheap, post-boozing eats. Not sure if same reaction would be had sans the liquor.
author: Varun B.

description:
Great lengua tacos!! I wish we got to experience eating at this place but we ended up get our meals to go. My wife got her asada torta and my cousins ended up getting asada and chicken tacos. All of us finished our meals in minutes because it was that good!

This will be one spot to remember when we come back to visit!
author: Nio S.

description:
It was a busy night but not out-the-door crazy. I ordered a Mexican hot chocolate, flan and two plates of food to share. I get the flan right away because they were pre-made and packaged. 

15 minutes pass and I am done with my flan. 

At the 20 minute mark, there was still no sign of any food. We asked about our order and was told it would be out soon.

After 30 minutes, we get our hot chocolate. It was enough to share with two people so that held us over for a bit. 

5 more minutes pass and a few of the other diners start to complain. 

At 45 minutes, we debate if we should just leave but since we already paid......we stay.

We were originally going to eat there but at the 50 minute mark I told them I wanted it to go. 

After ONE HOUR from when we ordered, we finally get our food.

At home, I discover that they only gave us one of our orders!!!!!!!!!!!!

I e-mailed them the next day about how disappointed and frustrating our experience was. It's been a week and no response.

Never again!
author: Julia T.

description: Called at 8 am for some tamales for a holiday party and they were happy to accommodate my last minute requests. Gave me a great mix of veggie, pork and chicken that were all delicious! Tamales  were a hit at the party so I'll definitely be back.
author: taylor s.

description:
Our group of 11 was supposed to eat at a nearby place last week, but because of the long wait, we checked out Yelp and made our way here instead.

It's a really unassuming, hole-in-the-wall place, but such a gem. The service was awesome. Everyone was so genuinely kind and patient with us, being the big and noisy group that we were in that small space (and having to move all of their tables around). The food was fantastic and for great value, too. Huge portions for cheap, so come hungry. I'm glad I shared what I ordered. I had a sun dried tomato/goat cheese pupusa, and a pork pupusa. Bomb. 

We got free cake slices and Mexican hot chocolate (DELICIOUS)!! Again, fantastic service. 

I'd definitely come back here if I was in the Mission again. Can't wait until they get their alcoholic beverage license :)
author: Janelle T.

description:
My wife and I tried La Oaxaquena for lunch today.  

Its located on a dodgy block on Mission, and the place is small, but its clean and the staff are friendly.

I had the chicken mole enchiladas and she had the milanesa (breaded pork) tacos.  Both were delicious!  This is the best mole I've had outside of Texas.  The chicken was delicious white meat, not the tough, cheap dark meat that some places try to pass off in their enchiladas.  Prices were reasonable given the quality -- $8.50 for my enchiladas, and $2.50 tacos.

There is no beer or wine here, but the waiter told me its okay to bring your own, so I bought a bottle of Cerveza Cusqueña from the market next door.

I look forward to going back and trying other stuff on the menu.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Four stars for the banana leaf tamales.  I had an adventure ordering it.  I called and the guy who picked up didn't speak English so I had to learn how to say " Do you have mole tamales?" in Spanish.  I also brought a Spanish speaker with me while I called.  However they didn't pick up, it took five more times before I could order the tamales in Spanish but the tamales made my pre-thanksgiving dinner special.  They were moist and full of mole and chicken.  Just as others have claimed, the banana leaf tamale was large enough for two people to share.  They are 3.75 each so I brought four. 

The restaurant itself is really small and hidden away.  I had to really look for it.   I liked the service as soon as I got there.  The restaurant had my tamales nicely packed up in boxes and a receipt by the time I got there.  They even gave me a small container of red chile sauce that went super with the tamales.  I will definitely ask for extra sauce next time.  The tamales are best eaten fresh but steam them if you have it the next day.  They are hard to microwave.  I recommend La Oaxaquena for solid Mexican food for a reasonable price.  While you're there, try some flan for me!
author: Lorissa W.

description:
Looking for new flavors of Mexican food, my cousins and I made a date to try this place, and we're so happy we did! The mole' was delicious on both enchiladas and the "chicken dinner" and there were enough black beans, rice and salad to fill us up completely! A pitcher of delicious hot chocolate filled in any empty spacesf. They don't  have a beer license, but the store next door is happy to oblige with a bottle or a six-pack.

I'd like to see this place much busier; the food deserves it, and the owner seems to be a really nice fellow.
author: Gretchen B.

description:
Even when I was a kid, I don't think I ate any bugs or dirt, so when I saw that tarantulas and grasshoppers were on the menu here, I had to walk in.  

First off---there were no bug options!  Yeah, I talked to the owner (Harry), and while I was picking my "meat" option, he said the City Health Dept would no longer allow them to serve bugs.  That sucks, I was looking forward to munching on an insect.  Government jag-offs!  

[Note:  this was in April, hopefully it's still not the case.  I do see that tarantula is still a seasonal offering on their online menu.]

Oh well, La Oaxaqueña still had plenty to offer.  My mission in the Mission was to have a few tacos.  I went with:  Tequila Chicken, Coconut Chicken, Chipotle Chicken, and pastor (aka Pineapple Pork).  I washed it all down with the Mexican hot chocolate everyone raved about.

Man o Man!  This was some tasty food!  Each of the tacos were distinct and exploded with flavor.  I sat and devoured each one like a ceremony, religiously.  The lubricant for this sustenance was excellent as well.  I would definitely come back here again for some grub (hopefully, I can get some bugs though---shh, shh, even if its on the down-low!).

I chatted with a guy by the name of Harry (I believe he was the owner).  He filled me in on the restaurant (I believe he said they have three restaurants), and how business is going in the Mission (sadly, the economy is hitting them hard).  He was super nice though, and the food was excellent.  

If you want some tasty Mexican food with an extensive (and sometimes exotic) menu, this is a place to check out.  They also had some hippie options as well (non-meat).  Hmmm...I wonder if vegetarians can eat bugs?  Wait, I think I just answered my question.  A bug isn't a vegetable.  Either way, La Oaxaqueña is some good food!
author: Corey G.

description:
I don't really want to write a review because I love this place and want to keep it all to myself. At the same time, I encourage everyone I know to go, to bring friends from out of town, heck I'm even going there tonight.

There is something heartwarmingly delicious about the food here. The pupusas and tamales are my favorites on the menu, especially the chicken mole one. It's just yum. Don't ask questions, just get it.

My only warning (and it's a positive one) is if you order a hot chocolate, you have to share it! They are really big, but so tasty you'll want to drink it all. If you do, you'll leave with the happiest tummy ache ever, and you'll only have yourself to blame.
author: Lili K.

description:
Delicious sopes and tortas, but DAMN do they take forever! It is a very small place run by 3-4 people tops so I suggest phoning in your order before you take the bus or walk over. Very affordable prices and it is so authentic the TV doesn't even work right! As it is a bakery, great selection of sweet things, though I have never tried them.

The tlayuda is hit and miss - sometimes it tastes a little stale but the filing is ALWAYS delectable. If you've never tried it I haven't yet found a place that will do them just as well.
author: Josh K.

description: More like 4.5 stars. Easily the best Tamales I've had in the city. The Banana Leaf wrapped Tamale was exceptional. Much bigger than I expected. The tacos were good too, no El Farolito or Taqueria Cancun. but up there. Go for the Tamales.
author: Adam K.

description:
There are a few clues from last night's drunken debacle that lead me to believe that this was the place where, at 2:30 am, six Asian girls consumed copious amounts of hot chocolate and tamales. And if you're thinking this is starting to sound somewhat like a crime scene description then you're right because WE FUCKING MURDERED THAT SHIT.

This Morning After Yelp Review is Brought to You By the Letter 4. My (equally hammered at the time) friend's fourquare check-in led to the yelp page, where, upon a short review of the photos section, I am beginning to recall vague snippets of this magical Mexican night...

*insert, dream sequence intro music*

First Memory: Rolled in at past 2:00. Amazingly we were seated. I'm sure this had nothing to do with the fact that we were a bunch of scantily-clad young women traipsing through the Mission.

Second Memory: Someone ordered the tamales and "caliente chocolate". Yea, you heard right: Caliente Chocolate. Drunk bitches can say shit like that and be amusing, not ignorant. (Maybe.)

Third Memory: Said food was consumed...amidst the worst Spanglish conversation of my life. I recall a request for a "fork-o" followed by this question: "Como se dice 'La Oaxaqueña' en Ingles?" Dude's response, laughing: "La Oaxaqueña."  

Fourth Memory: We made mention that it was one of our friend's "cumpleanos" and were surprised with a slice of cake (followed by an inhumanely butchered rendition of "Feliz Cumpleanos"). When asked how old she was we couldn't think of the Spanish word for 25 so we told them it was her quinceanera. Again, possibly a little bordeline-racist, but they put up with us! (Heck, they even laughed. #drunkbitchesforthewin)

I really want to say that the five stars are for the food, but I can't remember much of how it tasted. I do, however, recall that the staff was FUCKING AWESOME and for that they can have all the stars they want!!
author: Valerie C.

description:
If I could, I'd give this place 3 1/2 stars.  

The chicken mole tamales wrapped in banana leaf is huge (as other Yelpers have mentioned), pretty tasty, and is probably the best deal on the menu ($3.75 if I remember correctly).  If you want a lot of mole in your dish though, choose the chicken mole enchiladas instead.  The guac & chips, horchata, and sun-dried tomato and goat cheese pupusas are also very good.  I normally don't like goat cheese but the sun-dried tomato flavor balanced it out very well.  My only complaint about the pupusas is that they are relatively expensive ($2.75 I think?) considering it's just a disc ~4 inches in diameter.

Some disappointments:  I personally didn't see what was so great about the tlyadua, I definitely prefer regular pizza.  Also, I don't recommend the venison tacos.  $5 for some overcooked venison on a duo of corn tortillas just isn't worth it.
author: Beatrice W.

description: Either I ordered the Hershey's Hot chocolate or the Mexican Hot Chocolate?  Either way, it was a bit too sweet and I didn't taste the Mexican chocolate.  They were generous to give me two big cups to go.  The pupusa with Cheese and Loroco (Salvadorian flower bud) was very good. Something different.  I can see this place is authentic.  I had the grilled chicken taco (much preferred) and the spicy pork taco which came with grilled onions and grilled chili.  I like their table hot sauce.  Got to go back for the banana and corn leaf tamale.
author: Helen L.

description:
My new favorite Mexican place. Okay, so maybe it's not super authentic. As a vegetarian, I appreciate the lard-free masa and copious options for pupusa fillings.

Service has always been quick and friendly, prices are fair, and portions are HUGE. I particularly recommend the tamal. Mmmm....

Also, their hot chocolate is perfect for splitting with friends on a cold night.
author: Renee T.

description:
Lives up to the hype 100%. I'm still dreaming about the Mexican hot chocolate and fajitas with pollo peebil two days later. I wish I didn't live so far away! 

Prices are not bad for excellent Mexican food. The staff is so nice!
author: Eunice K.

description: I had the vegetarian burrito and it was really good. The burrito was filled with rice, guac, cheese, sour cream, and some vegetables. All the ingredients especially the guac complimented each other well. Tasted fresh and it was a good portion size. Another plus was their chips and salsa. Totally heart their salsa..hands down probably the best salsa Ive had in awhile! I'd definitely come back here!
author: Avni A.

description:
I cannot praise this place enough.   The service here goes far beyond five stars and the food is fantastic! 

San Francisco usually has me missing the Mexican food in Southern California, but La Oaxaquena is an exception.  Everything I have tried, from the blue corn quesadilla to the banana leaf tamales, has been mind-blowingly incredible.  

When you first go in, it may look like all other taco shops in the neighborhood, but you will soon find that the people who work here really value their customers.  The employees are all super polite and attentive, and they have hooked it up with free mole, dessert, and AMAZING hot chocolate (!!!!!!!) on more than one occasion, usually when I was with a larger group of people.  

 
And best of all, they're open late!  Every so often after an exhausting night at work, I'll stop by to get a street dog on my way home.  Best dogs on Mission!!!!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Those damn banana leaf tamales haunt my dreams as in I wake up and my pillow is gone.  The veggie banana leaf tamale with goat cheese is my #1 with the chicken mole a close second.  The mole is NOT the best I've ever had and is a bit one dimensional in flavor, but for the price and the juiciness of the chicken, I've been known to eat 2 in a sitting.  I definitely say choose the banana leaf over the regular corn husks and do stay away from the sweet tamales.  The radioactive pink bits should come with a label that says only fun when eaten drunk.

The pupusas are solid, nothing to write home about, but won't leave you wishing you spent that money on the bacon wrapped hotdog selling outside the restaurant.   Place is small, but conveniently located near the 16th Bart station and the atmosphere is chill and low key - all I ask for on a Friday night.
author: Dianna W.

description: Delicious chicken in banana leaf tamale with mole *drool*.
author: Chris M.

description: I got charged 11.60 for an 9.25 super burrito. And when I brought it to their attention they said "sorry we haven't updated the menu" somehow, someway that a lil hard to believe because the person responsible for before me got it for 10.06.
author: Andy T.

description:
Large guacamole is enough to feed 20 people. Crab enchiladas feature green sauce and are absolutely delicious. Don't get so full on guac you can't eat them. 

Ambiance tips:
- Be prepared to get cozy since it's a small place
- Be prepared to take initiative to order at the counter if you've been waiting more than a few minutes; my sense is they do some of both
- Have a desire in your heart for chocolate; I was maxed out on the day we went, so will have to return for the Mexican Hot Chocolate which everyone raved about.

Great menu.
author: Megan G.

description:
La Oaxaquena has an impressive menu, but I found that many of the items our group ordered did not measure up to our expectations. 

The pupusas, chicken tacos, and chorizo were great. The chapulines (grasshoppers) were interesting. They have sort of a salt-lemon-vinegar taste. Not bad, but those legs are tough to swallow! 

I had a lengua taco and the meat was shredded into a mushy mess. The flavor wasn't so good. The quacamole had a creamy consistency that took away from the avocado flavor. Our wonderful server gave us two desserts on the house (flan and tres leches cake). It was a sweet gesture, but I didn't think either of them tasted good or particularly fresh. I guess it's the thought that counts?
author: Raina S.

description: I tried to try this place 3 times today, but each time I stopped in they waved me off and told me a different opening time. They definitely don't open at 6 in the morning as their webpage says.
author: Rian R.

description:
Ok, like wow!

After a scintillating evening at Sub-Mission Art Space where there was more exposed meat on the walls than on the gallery floor.  Some friends of mine and I decided to pop round the corner for a bit to eat and when in the Mission there is only one choice for a late night nibble, meat and lots of it.

With a variety of choices to be had within a 3 block radius, we listed out the variables which would help narrow our search.   
1) No Street Meat
2) No morning trots
3) No Rickets
4) No mystery Bay fish

Through a natural choice of the above, we selected La Oaxaqueña Bakery and Restaurant.  It was a cold night and almost did not go in as it was packed, but oddly enough it did not look, smell or feel like a typical Mission Tacoria.  La Oaxaqueña had a warmth that reminded me of the proper restaurants in San Pablo where locals would stay for hours ordering food constantly as new friends would leave and new friends would join them.

Anyway, we were delighted at the variety of meat types ranging from roasted chicken to Grasshoppers.  Yes, you heard it, grasshoppers.  Moving on we chose the Mexican Hot Chocolate.  Since the whole table followed suit, the waiter brought us a cauldron of the dark brown liquid which exuded deep rich smells of exotic spices and coco.  It was a perfect starter as it warmed up our bodies and loosed our laughter lines.

Next we moved to ordering a variety of tacos and enchiladas.  The thought was to try as many dishes so everyone had a chance to taste everything.  Needless to say, I ordered a grasshopper taco and an ostrich taco. I know I was showing off a bit, but to be fair I am a huge fan of ostrich as it is a meat that is liken to a cross between Filet Mignon and velvet.  It is quite hard to find in the city and is well worth the search.  This taco is worth eating open faced with a fork and a knife and it was mighty tasty to say the very least.

As for the grasshopper taco, it was actually quite unique.  What they did was toss organically raised grasshoppers with lime, onion and spices then they stir-fry them until they are crispy.  On the plate, that are unmistakably bugs, but they have the flavor of a summer fair.  They explode with lime and cilantro as long as you get past the legs. =) 

Anyway, as you can guess, we loved it and will go back again and again.  Remember, this is a place which is good enough to have a sit down with friends and enjoy a long and leisure dinner.  No worries about plastic chairs and messy tables.
author: Jai D.

description:
After a late night at Zeitgeist and Lucky 13 with a friend from Brookyln, we had a craving for some tacos.

He received a suggestion from a colleague for La Oaxaquena and I must say...EPiC!  It's a hidden "Diamond in the Rough" and let me tell ya-this area of Mission is ROUGH.  

La Oaxaquena is a small hole in the wall with a lot of culture.  When walking up to the door you can see the cook making fresh tacos and sausage(homemade) on a flat top in one of the windows next to the door(if that's not marketing-I don't know what is!).  He made 4 different types of tacos and as I said previously-SAUSAGE!  The tacos were amazing-your choice of protein with cilantro, onions, radish, and the kicker-roasted jalepenos wrapped in two corn tortillas!  Freakin' Brilliant!  We had to go back and get two more tacos, plus a sausage.  They also have two salsas in squeeze bottles that you can dress your tacos with-both were very tasty.

The staff had a laid back demeanor, but were eager to assist you with your every request.
 
I can't say enough for little food spots like this in big cities.  Truly a place I will return to when I return to in San Fran.

-Ryan
author: Ryan S.

description:
Grasshopper tacos are delicious!  Who would've thunk?

If grasshopper tacos aren't your thing, let me recommend their pupusas, tacos, tres leches cake, a pitcher of mexican hot chocolate, or just about anything else on the menu.

Oh, and they'll be cooking bacon wrapped hot dogs and making tacos at the grill out front if you just need a quick drunken bite on your stumble home late at night.  This place comes highly recommended, and it will taste just as good when you eat it sober than it does when you inhale it drunk.

Love this place!
author: Theron L.

description:
Located in a sketchy area of SF... but it's amazing! Real, authentic Mexican food. Not too spicy or salty or greased up. 

I love the pupusas (spelling?) and the fajitas. The horchatas were DELICIOUS. My table each ordered entrees and horchata drinks while sharing guac and chips and pupusas. With tax and tip, it only came out to $10 per person and I couldn't even finish the food.

Delicious.
author: Stef S.

description:
Is this place still open??? I keep seeing the Mexican guy selling hot dogs. Sorry guy selling delicious dogs, being sober at 5pm is not conducive to me supporting your business.

I just want a tamale with guac & chips followed by a Hershey's syrup I mean Mexican hot chocolate.
author: Alvin T.

description: Damn dude... the corn leaf tamales with chicken and black mole are REALLY good.
author: Geordie E.

description:
This review is for the bacon wrapped hot dog awesomeness, outside of the bakery during night time.

One word: AWESOME.

This is the PERFECT snack to soak up alcohol. I like mine with grilled jalapenos, onions, mayo, and ketchup. The buns that this guy uses are phenomenal. My boyfriend, best girlfriend and I purchased 3- for only $8.25!!!

Going to the heart of the mission, trying to find the bacon wrapped hot dog guy...this is kind of like an Anthony Bourdain experience! One of his tour guides should have taken him here after he was at the Tonga Room last night! I'm sure he would have appreciated it.  

One word of advice- he doesn't sell any sodas after hours, but there is a liquor store right next store and you can find cans for under a dollar. 

Buy the hot dog, a soda next door, sit in your car  and watch the crazies go by. It's the perfect way to end a great night.
author: Stacy S.

description:
This place is as good as everyone says it is. 4 varieties of tamale until 2 a.m.? Beat that.

The place was clean, easy to find, and the staff were friendly and fast. Prices are reasonable. Parking wasn't too hard, despite being in the Mission. There's a taco stand outside (part of the restaurant), which was manned despite the rain. 

Got 3 different kinds of tamale. I would have liked them steamed longer to be softer, but they were all good. The guy working the till/bar area was spot on with his recommendation.
author: El Huron I.

description:
I have a love/hate thing for la oaxaquena.

Pros:
I've loved pretty much everything that I've tried at la oaxaquena. The hot chocolate is a must have and I definitely recommend the banana leaf chicken mole tamales. The ostrich taco was also amazing but it is now off the menu. 

Cons:
The hours are super inconsistent and every time I've tried to go in the last month they have been closed even during their NEW official business hours (wed-sat 5pm until 10pm).

::EDIT:: Always call to make sure they're open before going. I went again recently and the banana leaf mole tamales are still my favorite menu item.
author: Tina L.

description:
While San Francisco has a whole district devoted to latin food, I've never really found any that compares to the mexican food in my hometown. And then I found it.

This is the only mexican restaurant I eat at in the mission. Other than Taqueria Cancun, I don't see a reason to go anywhere else. Seriously, I have eaten at the "They Love Us On Yelp" restaurants, but i've never been into any of them. 

The banana leaf tamales are THE dopest, and I highly recommend the tacos they make right outside.

 Love the people that work here too! The bald owner is always smiling! WHAT A GREAT FACE!
author: Raquel R.

description: Not a date place! but very good food. The tomales are healthy and tasty (doubtfully organic) but at 1am whatever. BYOB which cuts on the cost as you can get excellent IPA next door. Give a nice tip and the owner will bring chips, mole, etc. One of the better taquerias in the Mission, and I know the Mission. Enjoy :-)
author: Nip B.

description:
I have come here more than 10 times so I feel competent to review. Yes there are a few dishes that are not perfect, for example the pupusas, but this is a Mexican, not a Salvadorean restaurant. The grasshoppers are not for everyone, more of an acquired taste. 

However, do yourself a favor and order the Mexican chocolate (big enough for 2-3), the banana leaf mole tamales, the sopes and tlayudas with chicken tinga (otherwise known as chipotle chicken) and the sweet tamales. Tacos are very good, burritos are good but not their specialty. Oh, did I forget the huge quesadilla that you can order with the tinga?

Oh, by the way, you are allowed to BYOB (hmm maybe this needs to be kept hush hush).  The owner will give you glasses and a wine-opener if you need them.  Lots of people buy some beer/wine at the strategically located liquor store next door and have it with their meal.
author: Manuel R.

description:
D
E
L
I
C
I
O
U
S

My kids love their tamales. My 10 year old daughter doesn't like spicy food, but she'll eat the spicy tamales from here!

That says a lot!
author: Sheila S.

description:
This is it.  This is my new favorite Mexican place.  Everything is huge and delicious and takes forever to arrive.  Like, seriously, pounds of guacamole for $5.  

Also there is a secret that makes it even better, that takes it from AMAZING to RIDICULOUS, but I can't tell you what it is because that would ruin the secret.
author: Sam M.

description:
Excellent mole. 
Excellent guacamole. 
Chips were nice and crispy. 
Mexican Coke.
Super yummy.
Highly recommended.
author: S M.

description: hidden gem with awesome prices,awesome tacos&awesome service. props to the taco man he was very helpful and quick.
author: Julia D.

description: Went here for a quick bite. Ordered two tacos that had a decent amount of meat but too much onions, like onion overload. Maybe even more onions then meat. But that's easily fixed by removing them from said taco. Tacos are pretty standard for the mission, minus the onion overload
author: A M.

description:
My friends and I wanted tacos and spotted this place in the Mission.  The menu was large with some interesting menu choices.  Crickets were on the list along with fried tarantula.  I tried to get the tarantula but they were out but the crickets weren't.  

I would have given this place 5 stars if the crickets were not prepared so salty because it was delicious.  The lengua tacos (beef tongue) was great.  It was different than Los Angeles in that it was slightly crispy around the edges.

Based on the lengua tacos alone it warrants a second try.

The only item that raised an eyebrow for me was the tofu mole tamale.  I was there with other Asian friends and we agreed that it's a little weird when non-Asian restaurants have to incorporate tofu into their menu for non-tofu asking items.  In any case they did a good job with it.  I tried a bite and it was still rich with flavor.

Best part of the place: Asked us to place our bicycles inside so they would not be stolen.  Dang it, I think that gives them their extra star back.
author: Ashley I.

description:
Consistantly the worst, slowest service. Don't go inside (vs the outdoor taco stand) if you don't have at least 45 minutes to spare. The food is good but not worth the wait. 

I've gone here at least 10 times (my studio is across the street) and each time I'm pissed at myself for giving them another chance.
author: meredith b.

description:
Mexican Food Massacre.

It took the kitchen La Oaxaqueña over an hour to spit out three papusas and a ttlayuda with chicken. No excuse was given or explanation offered. No food was brought to the table to ease the hunger pains that threatened to consume us. Not a single employee of the restaurant said boo while we waited --and waited -- for our food.

The food itself was extremely bland. The papusas were doughy and had almost no stuffing. The ttlayuda was overcooked and the meat was almost inedibly salty. 

I have never seen Mexican food take this long before.
author: P Z.

description:
this place rules!

i love the pupusas. they're a tiny bit more expensive than most other places but they come in unique varieties that i haven't seen elsewhere. the sundried tomato and goat cheese is my favorite. they're probably the best pupusas i've had outside of costa rica. i love the corn leaf tamales as well, all my friends rave about the chicken mole one and while i prefer the pork & chile verde, their mole sauce is some of the best i've ever had. i found the banana leaf tamale a little too oily but it's HUGE and only a dollar or so more than the corn leaf one. definitely the thing to get if you're on a budget. i tried the grasshopper taco once out of curiosity. it tasted really salty and crunchy, like sunflower seeds. they have a bunch of interesting taco meats i haven't tried, like ox, ostrich and tarantula. definitely check them out if you're adventurous.

they also have whole fresh coconuts for $3.50. first they drill a little hole and stick a straw in so you can drink the water, but after you're done they'll hack it in half so you can scrape out the pulp and eat that too. awesome!
author: Jane P.

description: This is my favorite place to get tacos in San Francisco! They tacos are delicious, cheap, and they are open until 3 am. This place looks like a hole in the wall, and they make the tacos in a small crevice between the door and the window, but they make some of the best tacos in the city. Definitely worth trying, and perfect for a greasy meal after a night out.
author: Sara H.

description:
Walked in, seated ourselves at the only table available for a party of 4, which happened to have not been fully bused yet. We decided to take that as a good sign, that the tables were full and they were busy.  My friend who is a vegetarian had a little trouble with her order, as they were out of stock for what she wanted, but they took the time to make her a special plate not on the menu to make up for it. 
I ordered a big plate of nachos with Carne Asada which was great, except the meat was over cooked a bit and chewy. A Quesadilla and Banana Leaf Tamale were also ordered with much joy and no complains. Our waiter seemed to be the only one on duty during our stay, he appeared a little frantic but not rushed. Brought us extra salsa for chips just because, left us a pitcher of water even though we were finishing up and about to leave, just in case. He was attentive and came across as eager to please, especially after the issue with my friends order. 
It wasn't the most outstanding experience, but it could have been a lot worse. I would be willing and happy to go again, although it may not be my first choice. The decor was a little concerning on first impression, really wasn't sure what to expect but the food was much better than the restaurants image.
author: Jessica P.

description: This place is an absolute gem. Most people walk right past it because it's a true whole in the wall. They have an excellent array of baked goods and amazing mexican rice. Their tacos are cheap and full of flavor. The decor is adorable and the owner and employees are lovely. One of the best mexican food restaurants in San Francisco all around.
author: Alex F.

description:
Chorizo y papas Taco - 4.5 stars 
This thing was awesome

Salsa - 4 stars, very good 

Guacamole - 4 stars 

BYOB - 5 stars! 

EXCEPT 

Chicken Fajitas - 2 stars...really dissapointing/normal tasting, edible but not that good 

Waiting 1 hr for our order on an only mildly busy night - 1 STAR 

Getting order wrong after waiting one hour  - Negative stars
author: Ben B.

description:
There is nothing too too special about this place. From what I can tell it is just like every other taqueria (for the most part). 

Pork tamale was good, purpusa was also pretty good. The cod fritters were REALLY fantastic; definitely something special. The tacos just come with meat and onions and needed to be drowned in salsa to get to point of tasting delicious.  The horcahata definitely did it for me, and they gave big 16oz cups of the stuff.

This place just did not wow me, and it took forever for our food to come out (probably because they were not using a microwave, so I guess its a good thing?). Overall, I will not be coming back here before trying other places in the area (and there are many)
author: Caitlin H.

description: A real mixed experience.  The place appears a bit unclean and I received dirty silverware.  The proprietors are very nice and welcoming.  Guacamole is excellent, with a strong lime flavor.  The mole is too sweet for my taste, and there were bits of cartilage among the chicken in the enchilada - a big turn-off.  The salsa is very hot.  It would been appreciated to have a choice to get medium or mild salsa.  I get that it is a matter of taste.  Overall, my experience was marred by the greasy smell and the sense of things not being all that clean.
author: Judy E.

description:
Do yourself a favor and dont' go to bed hungry because you spent your last dollar trying to impress that girl at the bar..

Don't be that sucka .. instead..  check out  this place late night on the weekends. $3 for two tacos which.. all things considered is not a bad deal. 

I came with Teresa N and was amazingly delighted in my tacos.  They have a cart parked right outside their bakery, perfect for those late nights of debauchery serving up fresh tacos. I had the al pastor and lengua and had to go back 3x for more. 

Great way to top the night..
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Hate to break the string of 4* & 5* reviews, but had high expectations and left disappointed. Had lunch w/ 3 people had chicken tamale w/ mole' , pork tamale, tlayuda, chapoline, taco's, hot chocolate, etc. 

Well, to summarize, the Tlayuda (the big fried (?) tortilla was very tough and old), topping was OK, not great. Tamale (pork) was lacking in flavor and not enough masa. The chicken one in banana leaf with mole (not enough mole) was ok, but again was not that tasty. Chapoline (only for the adventurous) seemed like they were around for 6 months they were broken and a little rancid. The hot chocolate was ok, not great. 

Service was not good (send up a flare for more water). 
Perhaps their bakery items are good, dunno, we didn't try them. 

I can only surmise that after the initial success, La Oaxaquena is goin the direction of many small places in the Mission, IF they survive....they will be the living dead.  Food  is not even close to good Oaxacan cooking. It was over-all OK,... forgettable. $11 for the tlayuda, hmmmm, well it should be $6. While many people will visit and eat, and say " OMG they serve Mole  sauce", or "I ain't never had a tttlayuuuuuuda before" 

Not a place I will visit again.
author: Matsuo U.

description: Last Friday night it wasn't too shabby. Their salsa is spicy and their guacamole is good and they've got colorful chips. The tamale with cheese and green bell pepper is awesome too! The place is a lot smaller in person though. The one thing that disappointed me was the tres leches cake. It was literally a white layer cake that was dry. This place isn't too bad though.
author: R C.

description: Really good food. If you want to try grasshoppers, ostrich, or bacon wrapped hot dogs? then this is a good spot for you. Good place if you want to try something rare. Besides that they have really good tamales, burritos, and horchata.
author: Sonlay V.

description:
Okay, so I didn't try their burrito, or their taco, or their enchilada, or their mole, or their tamal.  So what exactly did I try that warranted a review?  Mexican Hot Chocolate.  Bomb.  Light and frothy all the way through.  Amazingly consistent from top to bottom.  Flavor - some kind of spicy, but not overwhelming.  Do it.  F'real.

Also, the staff was super nice.  I mean, suuper nice.  Go see for yourself.

I will mos definitely be back to try some of the food, and hopefully some of their tres leches cake, which they sometimes run out of.  That said, consider this review - to be continued...
author: Jaymar C.

description: So it turns out this place charges double at night.  I went in and ordered a chicken sope, which was on the menu at $3.95.  I saw some larger number next to it, ignored it, ordered, and was asked for $7.61.  I verified with him... 'For one chicken sope?'  'Yes, one chicken sope.'  I thought, oh, cool, this is gonna be huge.  I tipped a buck.  I waited. It came.  It was tiny.  I was decent.  It was a decent two dollar sope, but it's sf so I would have been fine with $3 or begrudgingly accepted $4.  Not 8.61.  No way.  So I ate it and looked at the menu again to see if there was some confusion... Maybe he charged me for the granddaddy size and the cook made the small one?  Nope, the higher price is for three of them.  This place is no good at all and intentionally gauging as well as falsely advertising prices.
author: Sean A.

description:
I've been here twice in the last two months, and the food wasn't as good as I remembered. The first time was in late August when my friend from Philly who has been living in Hong Kong visited me; he craved cheap Mexican because he couldn't get that as easily in Hong Kong. We arrived around 9pm on a Monday, ordered two pupusas and a pork-pineapple taco at the counter, and waited close to half an hour for our food. The food tasted like it's been reheated and was not hot enough. My friend's two pupusas also tasted the same although one was supposed to be chicken (just tasted like cheese) and the other was sundried tomatoes and goat cheese. The horchata was diluted too. My friend was intrigued by the grilled tarantula taco on the menu, but they said it's only available on weekends. I attributed the lackluster food to an off night since we were there late on a Monday night.

I revisited last Thursday at 7p, and was greeted by a server who sat us and took our order at our table. I'm not sure if they've always had table service as every time I've been here previously I ordered at the counter. Anyway my boyfriend ordered a carne asada burrito ($8-9) and I ordered the turkey mole banana leaf tamale ($4-5). They gave us tortilla chips, spicy salsa and water while we waited. My tamale's masa arrived very hot but when I got to the turkey mole in the middle, the turkey was still cold. Our server came by to check on us, and reheated the tamale for me. The masa was good, but I found the dark mole too sweet. I've had dark mole homemade (with chocolate) by my friend from Mexico that was delicious and not as sweet. And since both orders were so huge, we only ate half and took the rest home. Although tamale was better after I re-steamed it at home, I think it's time I try a different taqueria in the Mission.
author: Diana B.

description: Amazing, creative, and fresh food. I cannot speak of the consistency.  I've only been there once.  But what makes it 5 vs. 4 stars (as with any other place) is the personal service you receive from the glowing owners.
author: K G.

description:
This place rocks so hard, I don't even know what to write.....YUMMY!!!! And dam authentic, too!!  Their tamales with chicken mole are simply the best, and you get a choice of corn husk or banana leaf.....If you've never had a banana leaf tamale, TRY IT: the velvety, airy lightness will blow you away, and the difference from the more dense, sturdier corn husk tamal is a pleasant change.

The baked goods are, well, good.  The service is delightful, very cool folks running this place.  And it tends to be open late....good for me, bad for my food hygiene, shouldn't be eating so late.  

Although I am a big enthusiast of the taco, especially tacos sold fresh on the street or from a truck, at Oaxaquena I actually recommend you resist the temptation of the taco waiting outside the front door and go inside, sit, and start reviewing the amazing menu.  I have not had such wonderfully delicious and authentic food since I lived in the State of Oaxaqa many years ago.  

Did I mention they give you a lot of food?  They give you a lot of food, and it couldn't be more savory and wonderful and satisfying.

Oh, and if you ever have a yen for grasshoppers or tarantulas, they are served here.  I'm not much of a bug eater, so I can't speak to the quality of their fried tarantula, though I imagine like the rest of their menu it's pretty good.  Anyone who tries the tarantulas, please post a review:)  Buen provecho!!
author: Jesse Clifford A.

description:
Good food, although over priced compared to other little Mexican places I have eaten at.

After a long night of me being the designated driver, I decided that this would be a good quick place to get some food for the rest of my drunken company.

The food was excellent.  I ordered the grasshopper tacos and venison, just to try something different.  The grasshoppers were good, although a little spicy for my tastes.  They didn't taste like anything much as they were over powered by lime and chili.  The venison was a little of a let down as they tasted more like regular beef.  Over all, the tacos were good, but the price were a little steep.
author: Natasha A.

description:
You like big portions, come here my friend. 

La Oaxaquena Bakery and Restaurant has the goods for that large portion eater in your family. Maybe your teen aged son, AKA the bottomless pit. Tasty food will do you good for at least 24 hours after you eat, there is that much in the servings. Best way to get around it is to split the dish 2 or 3 ways. Especially the tlayudas, a 16" tortilla covered with refried beans, meat salsa and cheese. Huge. And do not forget the tamale, served mole style wrapped in a banana leaf. Excellent.
author: Cora P.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Lengua Taco = Holy cow. First time eating lengua. Is it always this soft and tender? Oh yum.


SERVICE:
Taco stand in front of store for late hours


ATMOSPHERE:
Came here for late night eats, loitered around with the rest of the Mexicans haha ..
author: Angela L.

description:
I came here with my sister, who no  longer lives in SF but was here for a few years  up until the summer.  Admittedly, she was very comfortable in her neighborhood and rarely made it to the Mission.  I finally convinced her to go (Tartine Bakery really does the trick) but we were really hungry for other food too so I brought her to La Oaxaquena.

She got a lengua and al pastor taco, I got my lengua taco and the same chicken mole tamale again.  last time I came I was "a bit" under the influence of alcohol, so I wanted to make sure it was just as tasty this time while dead sober.  It is!  

I ate the taco first, which is friggin' huge and delicious.  Then I attacked the tamale, also very big.  I think my sister was a little horrified by me eating all this food, and at one point also said, "You know, you don't HAVE to finish the tamale...." to which I responded, "but it's so good!"

My sister really liked the tacos, and said she misses SF tacos, as she now lives in Philadelphia.

Thehorchata here was also very nice, very smooth texture and good cinnamon flavor without being too sweet.
author: Naoko M.

description:
This place rocks!!!  Cheap eats but great quality and is soooo tasty.   Two people can easily get full for $15.

Get their tamales.  You can't go wrong with any of them.  The banana leaf ratatouille one was delicious.  The masa they used was perfect, not too soggy and held together pretty well.  Only thing that wasn't 5 stars was their regular salsa they provide with their chips.  Oh well no one is perfect.

The flavor combos were great and you can brown bag it from the liquor store next door.  Also the staff was really nice and polite and very accommodating.
author: J. S.

description: Don't eat here they have rats in the kitchen!!! We'd eaten here a few times before & the food was good but last time we went in on a Sat night around 10:30, waited 40 min to place our order, we were asked to move twice, had hot chocolate spilled on us then to top it off we saw three rats running across the ceiling beams toward the kitchen. Yes Rats!! We told the waiter and he was not surprised. The owed was there & didn't even bother to apologize. Never again will we eat there.
author: April F.

description:
Oh my gosh I LOVE THIS PLACE.

Only for one item.

The Mexican Hot Chocolate. They bring it out to your table and it's large enough to serve three people. I always forget them name of this place but I know that whenever I crave Mexican Hot Chocolate (which is often) I always go to the place with the orange walls in The Mission. For a little extra money, you can get extra chilie or soy milk in it too.

The food is good too - I usually can never eat tamales because most places use lard in the masa - but not here! It's totally veggie based. I had the most amazing chicken mole tamale the other night. They also have really great unique pupusas. I would stay away from the tres leches though, it was horrible. and the shrimp and greens tamale made my tummy queasy. 

I also have friends that refuse to go to this place with me because it is infused with the hipster pretentious crowd. You've been warned.
author: Taz A.

description:
+ yummy! I've been getting my taco fix in Durham, but I haven't been eating my tamales! This place was a great lil restaurant right on Mission! 
+ good Mexican hot chocolate. 
+ love the botero print in the bano!

+/- the aqua fresca was a little too sweet for me. But maybe others will like it. 

- the place doesn't have much seating. and not particularly clean. there was a roach crawling around our table.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
A recent transplant to San Francisco on a mission to find the best tacos/tamales, I was lured to La Oaxaquena by the unusual menu and the sensuous photos on their website.    

Unfortunately La Oaxaquena did not make my list.  I ordered the traditional banana leaf chicken mole tamale and a side of beans.  The tamale was mostly masa, with little chicken or mole to speak of.  Additionally, what mole was present was pretty bland and unremarkable. 

Overall, the presentation, atmosphere and food quality was sub-par.  I don't recommend this place. 

Also, the salsa had been left out long enough to start fermenting.  I actually don't mind my salsa with a fermented tang, but it served as a symbol of the lack of care with which the food is prepared.
author: Taylor N.

description:
The open late thing is kind of a misnomer.

I was super excited to try this place after flying in late.  Saw the grasshopper and tarantula on the reviews and was really looking forward to it.  Got here at 12:30 a.m. and only the stand outside was serving.

The selection was LIMITED to hotdogs wrapped in bacon, carne asada tacos, pig's head (cabeza) tacos, and beef tongue (lengua) tacos.  Oh, and tamales as well.

I sampled the pig's head and lengua tacos.  Tender tender tender.  Not too shabby, but messy.

Disappointed that that was it.
author: Bob C.

description:
Went to La Oaxaquena Bakery & Restaurant last night and it was fun. Food is delicious, especially the hot chocolate. Oh that is a treat in and of itself. It is served fresh and with steamed milk and cream, oh so rich and satisfying. 

It gets busy, so be patient and service can be delayed during busy times. I want to go back and try more food items like the Tlyaudas. Yet I also want to try the pastry, the bread and stuff like that. It looks so good. 

The place is small so if you go there on busy days, like I did which is usually a Friday, be prepared to wait. It is worth it. Prices are reasonable and yeah they take credit cards.
author: Jonathan F.

description: This place used to be one of our favorites but they have really deteriorated lately in terms of quality of service.  I would recommend they remember the early days and get their service back up to speed.
author: Em P.

description: Came here several times with my buddies after clubbing. Great tacos, and they have all these other items that my friends order that are also very yummy. Their salsa and chips are also very good. Friendly staff, open late so you can eat GREAT...tacos!
author: Amy L.

description:
Horrible experience here. 

My friend and I came here at 9pm. We ordered: guacamole, queso & loraco (sp?) pupusa, 2 chicken mole in banana leaf, Mexican hot chocolate. And water. The guy who took our order was very nice, initially. We sat there for 40 minutes and nothing came. We watched people who came in after us get their food. I'm timid and was not hungry so I would have waited forever more. My friend was hungry and started asking about the food, the water, the chips, anything?! 

We start asking for our food. Maybe the water and chips? We asked someone who later turned out to be the owner. Others started bringing out food. They tried to give us rice&beans, sopas; not our food. They gave us a pupusa and 1 banana leaf. I looked at it and told my friend "Touch the pupusa. Is it warm?" It looks cold. We tried the tamale, it's ok but lukewarm.  The fact it's lukewarm and other people got their food before us means the problem is not with the kitchen. They're making the food fine but it's not getting brought out.

We remind them we are still waiting for chips and another tamale and hot chocolate. And where's our water? We watch the guy who took our order. He's already giving off vibes that he's angry with slamming of cups etc.  He fills 2 cups of water. Oh goody, our water. Nope, it's for another table. The hot chocolate comes, in a good-sized silver container with 2 mugs. Foamy on top. Our second tamale comes and it's steamy hot. The fact it's delicious because it's hot only highlights how poor the first one is.

We ask for water again. My friend goes to the counter to ask. That's when the guy who took our order snapped. He initially apologized, then he snaps. He says how they're very busy and he's doing his best and if we want service we "should go to a four-star restaurant where they have 4 waiters waiting on you."  He's mad, slamming things. He fills the water cups and rather than handing it to my friend who standing at the counter, he walks around (behind a wall where we can't see him) and puts it on the table, angrily saying how they're doing the best they can for these prices. (The order of what happened may be reconstructed inaccurately, but he did say all of these things.)

I am extremely uncomfortable now. As in, I-don't-want-to-eat-here-because-god-knows-what-they're-going-to-do-in-the-kitchen-with-our-food. You have to experience this yourself to understand why it was so horrible. I ask my friend if she wants to leave without paying as we have eaten 3 bites of our food and there's still food missing. She agrees to leave and goes to the counter to tell them we're leaving and want to pay. 

Then the owner comes out with the chips; the guacamole looks amazing. He says for us to stay and eat since he was planning to comp us anyway. She pulls out cash to pay but he says it's ok.
