He's the reason why they even get a second star; he was very nice and tried to address this issue. He said the guy is normally back of the house and had to be in the front. He said for us to come back and try it in the daytime when he, the owner, is there. 

However, I will NEVER come back here again for fear of what the kitchen would do to my food. Hey, I've watched "Waiting" with Ryan Reynolds; I know what goes on in the kitchen.  Whenever I've read reviews like this, I think "God, you're such a baby. Stop whining about the service. Who cares?" I learned something last night. I do expect one thing: the food! You can ignore us, you can leave my water glass bone-dry, you can throw our food on the table, the floors can be sticky and dirty, the walls can be covered in grease and graffiti, but first, you must bring the water and food. 

And the guy's reasoning is bullsh*t. There are plenty of eateries within walking distance whose food is just as good at similar prices and they don't yell at you for wanting a glass of water. And to tell us to eat somewhere else? I grew up working in a restaurant and when food took a long time or we forgot, we apologized/lied about how it was coming, how something was taking longer to cook etc. Sure, we would lie, make up excuses, whatever it took to appease the customer but we NEVER, ever told a customer that they were expecting too much. I definitely never told them to eat somewhere else. I thought it, but I never said it to the customer. Because they will take you up on this offer. 

In SHORT, the hot food is tasty, pricing is good, sizes are large. If you sit for 40 minutes without anything coming, just leave so you don't end up getting scolded by the staff and unable to ever have a chance to try the food.
author: Yan E.

description:
Strolled over into an empty dining area on a sunny Saturday and sat right down. The owner (I'm assuming) came right over with menus and we started the negotiations in what to order. We were debating between the Mexican Hot Chocolate with chilie powder or the Atole Blanco. She brought us a giant "sample" of the Atole Blanco which was delicious but we ended up going with the hot chocolate to try that as well. The hot chocolate was absolutely delicious better then any of the other spicy hot chocolates I've had in SF. 

We ordered two Pupusa's, pickled vegetable and the cheese and Loroco, the Rajas corn tamale and the turkey tamale with Oaxacan mole. All were very tasty however I wish everything was a bit more spicy so I doused it in salsa. I would definitely come back here as there are lots of great things to try on the menu and it's not burrito centric.
author: Kacey H.

description: This place catered my wedding back in February, 2012.  It is the best Mexican food in San Francisco. The food is phenomenal, and they also do a great catering job.  If you go into the restaurant on Mission St., you can BYOB, which is always fun.   The guacamole is fantastic and so is the hot chocolate.  Enjoy!
author: Hank S.

description:
4/5 times it's been great, only so-so the other time. Great tamales, good cecina tacos. My favorite is the pork verde tamale. The mole tamale in banana leaf is delicious, but almost too intense at times. Oddly, I also love their rice and beans here, delicious creamy beans.

On many weekend evenings they seem to have a taco stand set up outside.
author: Sam P.

description:
A great place for takeout tamales! One banana leaf-wrapped chicken mole tamal is like three bucks and is gargantuan, like enough for two people. These are not side-dish sized tamales. These are meal-sized. They're also super moist, which is a must when it comes to tamales. 

Regular corn husk-wrapped tamales are also great, and they have several vegetarian options like the "rajas" tamal (with a generous filling of jalepeno chili pepper, tomato, and cotija cheese) and the spinach & cheese (this is with Oaxaquena cheese not cotija).
author: Deborah G.

description: The best tomales that I've ever had. The banana leave tomales are soooo delicious, much better than the corn husk ones that they offer. Their pupusas are good, but not mind blowing.
author: Alice W.

description:
For $3.75 for a huge and really good tasting tamale it's hard to beat.  But make sure your packing because the area isn't great.

I recommend the banana leaf chicken tamale, I like the mole (best mole I've had) slightly better than the salsa verde.  Even though it's really cheap it's actually a full meal, as none of us could finish one. They don't keep very well though, they get kinda mushy after about half a day in the fridge. They also have odd things like grasshopper tacos and other things I haven't tried. 

They are generally really packed during the weekend so if you can go during the weekday it's a bit easier to find parking and get food quickly. 

The area is bad.  No joke.  We past by at least 3 mentally disabled people with one lady yelling at everyone passing by and one guy who actually hit people as he walked by looking at the floor (who hit one of our group members).  It also smells like piss half the time on the street.  

I RECOMMEND: Call ahead, order a chicken tamale, probably the mole (chocolate) one, and just do a drive by to pick it up and get out of dodge.
author: Dr K.

description: Located in a seedy part of Mission St, I almost missed it due to its small storefront. The place is pretty small and I don't know if its usually busy, but when I walked in it was pretty much empty. I ordered the Chicken Mole Tamale wrapped in a banana leaf not knowing what to expect. A few minutes later, this huge plate comes out and I'm thinking this is fuckin great since it was only $3 or so!! The tamale itself was amazing!! The corn exterior was so soft it kind of reminded me of soft polenta or mashed potatoes. The mole sauce had some really nice depth to it and the chicken was super tender. I must have been eating the wrong tamales all my life b/c I'm used to eating tamales where the corn filling is much dryer. Anyways, mucho props to this place.. I'm definitely coming back!
author: Henry W.

description:
Ostrich, grasshoppers, crab, venison??  Well this ain't your run-of-the-mill Mission tacqueria.

Apparently the star of the show is the chicken mole tamale wrapped in  a banana leaf.  I was excited when they brought out the huge plate but was soon disappointed--hardly any chicken, soggy masa and bland mole sauce.  What's all the fuss about?

Fortunately I ordered 3 tacos too: al pastor, cecina (spicy pork) and venison.  Much better!  Cecina may be their replacement for carnitas (although very different) and was excellent.  Ditto for the chumparrado.  

Modest prices, unique menu and friendly and attentive staff.  I'll definitely be back, and next time will try their tlayuda.
author: Manny R.

description:
I tried this place based on the reviews on Yelp and the review from my friend Heather.
As a Mexican, I feel like I have a tendency to judge Mexican food differently than everyone else.  While this is definitely a street food style taqueria, they incorporate a lot of homey dishes and side beverages that are rare to find in contemporary Mexican restaurants.

I ordered three tacos; tongue, milanesa (breaded pork), and venison. I also ordered a banana leaf wrapped chicken tamal. For drinks I ordered an agua de horchata and a champurrado. 
The GF ordered a grilled chicken taco and a tamale with pork. 

The tacos were just ok, average. Nothing special. In fact, they were dry and not hot enough. However, the tamales were very good. Especially the one with pork. But the highlight of my day was the champurrado. Now, I can't go into details about how good it was but just know that several people came in asking for it but they were all sold out! I would come back again for the champurrado alone. 
Overall an ok experience. Perhaps next time I'll consider eating a grasshopper taco but I am afraid to ask where they got those from or how cold they serve them.
author: Ignacio A.

description:
Their Mexican Hot Chocolate is HAPPINESS IN A CUP. I was expecting something thick, dark, and spicy (which I do like in my mexican hot chocolate), but La Oaxaquena's cup is light, frothy, and lightly spiced. A pleasant surprise and the only cup I've ever had like it. 

I'd definitely come back again and again for this single menu item! The staff and space are full of good vibes, too. I have no idea what their food is like (yet), but already, this place is an instant Mission favorite.
author: Dianne Q.

description:
I love this place.  The best tamales in the city, if not the world.  I usually get one of the traditional Oaxaquen banana leaf tamales.  They are big and cheap and absolutely delicious.  The mole is fantastic and even the vegetarian tamales are great.  They have a very wide variety of papusas which are pretty good but technically Salvadorean.  

Tamales aside, the service is great.  Very friendly and attentive.  We were once given a free side of grasshoppers, and although I didn't love them, it was a nice gesture.  

The only think I had here that I didn't love, was a very dry al pastor taco, but it was probably just a bad batch and was still quite tasty.  

Other notes:
-Danger Dogs sold outside (Bacon Dogs)
-BYOB
-Tlayuda is supposedly amazing but I never tried it
author: Dan L.

description:
How does a tiny hole in the wall joint in the crackhead - hooker zone of The Mission get four stars?  By making slap your mama good food!  

This is the food of my family's table. . .no, my people are not from Oaxaca but the food they make here has the same colors and hues, flavors and aromas.  This place makes me giddy with joy.  

When you first walk in, you will notice that it's very clean.  You will also notice that while they did not have a lot to work with, they've done their best. . .wonderful murals, bright paint and warmth welcome you in.

Their selection of beverages alone are worth the stop.  . . every kind of Mexican soda you can think of including the medio litro size of Mexican Coke - 'cause lets face it. . .those yummy regular bottles go way too fast.  Their licuados are super delicious. .. I love the mamey but it does tend to take up stomach real estate which is crucial when you dine here.  You must dine with a partner in crime because you MUST order a Tlayuda.  If you come to La Oaxaqueña and do not order a Tlayuda, your visit is FAIL.  I am partial to the tinga de pollo which is redolent with chipotle chiles. . if you're not a big fan of spice,  I suggest the milanesa.  They do Tlayudas correctly here. . cracker thin and crisp tortilla spread with asiento and then topped with fresh and tasty ingredients. . I always ask them to go easy on the lechuga 'cause if I wanted to eat healthy, I wouldn't be here.  :)  

Other notables are their mole negro enchiladas, sopes, tamales (altho personally I am not a fan of those wrapped in banana leaves. . not that they don't do them well, I just do not like the sabor of the leaves) and torta de venado.  If they have the torta de venado or plato de venado available, do not hesitate to get it.  Venado is venison and it is a specialty of the region and it is absolutely delicious.  

If you get there early in the day, grab some pan dulce. . .because OMG it's SO good. . .the little horns with cheese. . .well, that and a hot chocolate is just about the best thing ever.  

Their hours are awesome. . 6am to 2am.  ..since I am a night owl AND an early riser I can pretty much go whenever the mood strikes.   They also set up a taco stand at night so you can just walk up and get some tacos.  

I have two quibbles. .. I wish they served better chips and the pupusas are not good. . .it's mostly to do with the curtido which misses the mark but then again, I am eating at La Oaxaqueña, not La Salvadoreña so that's what I get for ordering a pupusa here.  

Go here. . go here NOW!
author: Lainie L.

description:
I came here because I drank the koolaid that Yelp provides.

I like hole-in-the-walls. I like holes in general. I thought I would like this hole, but not so. And if you check out the last time I reviewed something, its been quite a while- but I felt the need to express to the world how much I dislike this hole.

I'll start with the positives: the only redeeming quality is the Mexican Hot Chocolate. Seriously we got enough for like 5 mugs of the frothy delicious brew. And our waiter was sweet. Incredibly slow, but sweet.

Now about the food:
-Sat down and our order wasn't taken for a good 10-15 minutes.
-We got guacamole to start. (20 minutes into the meal) I'm a huge lover of avocados, and usually that sh*t is all eaten up within minutes. But this guacamole? I don't even know if I could call it that. Reconstituted greenish mush would be closer than guacamole. It reminded me of when you buy huge bulk things of frozen guac at Costcos (did it once, never again), and then doctored it up with a bunch of junk like tomatoes and jalapenos, this would be the end-product. It was NOT GOOD. We did not eat it. Not even with the tri-colored chips (really? is it really neccicary to have vivid green and red chips?).
-45 minutes in and we get our meal. Wait... I got MY meal. A Torta sandwich. My ladyfriend person? Nope, she didn't order the burrito. So we had to wait. My torta was meh/fine. Nothing to write home about. Had 3 measly slices of unripe avocado and gristly chicken. Bah humbug.
-55 minutes in and her nachos arrive. Seriously 3 lbs of nachos. Huge. Rediculous. Unneccicary. They weren't bad, but like, its like 3 pounds of mediocre food. Super meh. 

After waiting a long time for the check, I decided it made more sense for me to just go up to the counter to get it done. At this point we had spent well over an hour in this semi-depressing joint. I have no doubt that people love this place- I mean- in the middle of our meal this crazy hipsterbilly chick came in and (IM NOT KIDDING) started CRYING about how these people closed up shop and how she could never find the perfect burrito and how COULD they have left her alone and tacoless. She was crying. She was on drugs, but still she was crying. So at least someone likes their food.

I just figure if a place has like, 4 starts, its gonna be good. I've never really been let down by yelp. Perhaps it was an off-night... but it was just REALLY off. Thought I'd warn all the other yelpers and steer them in the direction of the tried and true: Taqueria Cancun.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Jeff had another work assignment at 16th and Mission and texted me to see if I was free to meet him during his lunch break, which is dinner for most folks.  I don't see my guy as much as I'd like, so it was exciting for us to have dinner together for the second day in a row.

After I found a parking spot on 17th and Mission, I walked over to meet Jeff.  We then walked up to Valencia Street and didn't find anything that jumped out at us.  So I asked Jeff to open up his newly installed Yelp! finder on his Motorola Droid.  La Oaxaquena was the first and highest rated restaurant to come up.

Once we found the place, we looked at the menu.  Found it a bit hard to decide, but then we realized that we only looked at one side!  And saw all the choices, including frog, grasshopper, and ostrich among the meats.  Jeff had the shrimp cocktail, tamale, and carne asada taco.  I had a crab tostada and a pollo asado taco.  Before those came out, a basket of fresh chips with a pestle overflowing with guacamole came out.  This is the first place we knew of where guacamole COMES with the chips.  WOW.

Everything tasted very fresh and couldn't believe how little we paid for such wonderfully prepared food.  Thanks again to Yelp! for helping us out.
author: Lani C.

description:
I am a foodie - I eat at great places, all the time.
I also love hole-in-the-wall Mexican and taquerias.

That's why I was surprised at how truly horrible the food here was. Based on the reviews I should have loved it. I basically love all Mexican food I'm ever served.

But not here.

This was the worst food I've ever been served in my life.  It was so bad, it probably was illegal.

AVOID - "carne asade" (cheapest chewiest meat ever)
AVOID - "mole" (pure garbage, viscous with a texture of canned gravy)

The drinks were passable (tamarindo and horchata) but certainly not worth going back, not by a long shot.

I literally left feeling queasy.  We had to cut short our afternoon plans because my +1 felt she might throw up.

Also our bill came to something like $26 before tip.
2 tacos
1 wet burrito
1 tamarindo
1 horchata

The most sickening and disappointing food experience I've ever had in the USA, at an unreasonable price.
author: Eric H.

description: I love this spot! The people who work here are really great, and the mole is amazing. Try the banana leaf chicken mole tamale. Amazing!!
author: Vicki H.

description:
So if you are out late and want some cheap eats La Oaxaquena is there for ya!

They have tasty pupusas: the veggies one is great; Bean n cheddar is ok; Pork n cheddar is tasty too as well as a nice banana leaf mole tamales.  I used to like mole more than i do know but still, theirs is pretty good!
author: Gene X.

description:
Ever since I tried my first tamale here, I can't stop thinking about La Oaxaquena.
First, I had the chicken and mole wrapped in banana leaf. Delicious. And freaking HUGE for $4.
Then, I tried the spinach and cheese tamale wrapped in cornhusk. Also very, very delicious and just less than $3. I also ordered a side of rice which they didn't charge me for AND they added queso fresco on top. Are they psychic? Did they know I like to add cheese to pretty much everything I eat?
Last night, I mooched some of my roommate Tatiana J.'s chicken and green sauce banana leaf tamale, which I'm planning to getting today at lunch.
Did I mention I didn't think I liked tamales before La Oaxaquena? Now they've got a hold on me.
Go there. Now.
author: Marissa B.

description:
We absolutely loved this place.  Stumbled upon Oaxaquena after finding out that Yamo was closed.  The guy who owns the place (Harry) was super nice and kept giving us things to try for free. I think he liked that we were tourists and just happened to stumble upon his joint.

So check this out - we had chips w/ salsa and guac, all fresh and very good.  I got a bean and cheese papusa that was tasty and straight off the grill, and I got the most amazing tofu tamale I've ever eaten.  It was tofu and mole sauce in a corn tamale - so flavorful and delicious.  The mole sauce was ridiculously amazing.  My girlfriend got crab enchiladas smothered in a green verde sauce that was so good that I would have taken a bath in it. Harry then hooked us up with almond/cinnamon hot chocolates and we almost had to beg him not to give us free dessert.  He also showed us his bag of fried crickets and urged us to eat one - we politely declined.  

All of this for about $30.  What an authentic and awesome experience!
author: Michael C.

description:
3.5 stars
In my humble opinion I thought the food at La Oaxaquena was decent. I didnt find it mind-blowingly amazing, but it certainly wasn't nasty either.

Heres what we ate:
chips and salsa~ yum! the salsa seemed to be pureed into an almost creamy consistency. it had a nice smoky flavor with a bit of spice which i enjoyed.
chicken mole tamale rapped in banana leaves~ really greasy :(, i am a HUGE fan of mole but their mole just didn't do it for me. it lacked the rich complex flavors that a mole should have. there was far more mole then chicken so it became somewhat of a sloppy mess.
spinach and cheese tamale~ this was pretty tasty. had a nice hint of spice that wasn't expected but was certainly enjoyed.
fish taco~ bland
jalapeno, tomato, cheese tamale~ this was the standout to me. very, very delicious!  
As an aside I should mention that we wanted to try the guac, and the collard green/tofu plate but they were out of both. (out of guacamole? ok...) 

If I am ever find myself near L.O.B. I might consider returning for a few of those slammin jalapeno tamales. Otherwise Ill try another one of the many Mexican eateries in the Mission as I am still on the hunt for that Mexican meal that will make my taste buds sing...
author: Miss T.

description:
Came here on new year's eve for dinner.  The food was great, we ordered too much! We couldn't finish it: chips and guacomole,  some crispy quesadilla type pizza (it's HUGE), 1 regular chicken tamale, and 1 banana leaf tamale, and a burrito.   I like tamales and this one just satisfied my craving.  Too bad they didn't offer a wet tamale...that would have been the ultimate (used to get those somewhere in Sacramento)!  The banana leaf tamale was different for me because of the flavor and consistency.  I don't think I would order it again.  The burrito was good and huge, you can't go wrong with just your typical steak.  With all this food, we barely touched the quesadilla-like pizza.  However, I'm not that big of a fan because the quesadilla is crispy and a little bland.  The chips and guacomole was good...so much guacomole it felt like it would never end.

My biggest complaint about this place is the service.  I agree with other yelpers is the fact that the service is SLOW.  We waited at least 30 minutes for our chips and guacomole followed 10 minutes later with all of our entrees.  I don't know what took them so long...baking their colorful chips in the back??? There was one nice waiter who seated us, but the other guy seemed bitter at his job.  Unfortunately, we ended up with the bitter guy who was not attentive to his customers.
author: Lisa W.

description:
This place rules because:

* It's unexpected
* It's not just another taqueria in the Mission
* It's inexpensive
* It's delicious
* The staff is friendly and not in a rush (ifyouknowwhatimean)

I highly recommend the hot chocolate although I wasn't as impressed with the chicken mole tamale as the other reviewers.
author: Morty P.

description:
I have only been living in the city for a little under a month, but La Oaxaquena's banana leaf chicken tamale with green sauce is probably the most amazing thing I've eaten since I moved here...

Really. With each bite I took, I either said out loud (or in my mind) OH MY GOD. Amazing. The masa is usually a pretty boring part of a tamale, but that is not the case with this bad boy. The masa was so flavorful and moist. The tangy-ness of the green sauce worked well with the slightly sweet and salty masa. The chicken was tender and delish.

Oh my goodness, I almost forgot - the tamale is HUGE. I was nervous at first when my friend told me that one would be enough... I have a pretty healthy appetite, but luckily I took her advice. The tamale was literally the size of a magazine. Ok, maybe not EXACTLY that big, but one tamale is definitely a meal. I couldn't finish mine.

I can't wait to try the tamale with mole next time.
author: Tatiana J.

description:
I love this place.  I love various Mexican dishes in green sauce, but I'm super picky about it, and this is one of the tastiest recipes I've had.  The first time I went, I had the enchiladas verdes with chicken, and cleaned the entire plate, which was not small.  The second time, they had crab enchiladas verdes, and being a huge crab fan, I had to try it.  Same fantastic green sauce, though the sweetness of the crab was a little weird with it.

They have some tasty mole as well, though my boyfriend (who is the real mole aficionado) has mentioned, the recipe seems to change a bit from trip to trip.  We inquired about this once, and our waiter said that they buy the mole at market in Mexico and it's a family recipe, so sometimes it might be made slightly differently.  WOW!

The enchiladas come with the requisite rice & beans, which I think are fantastic and not just garnish, the way they are at some Mexican places.  I mix them in with the green sauce & eat every last bite. :)

The horchatas are giant, and taste like melted cinnamon-and-nutmeg ice cream, so be forewarned if you don't like extra-sweet horchata.  You can also get Mexican hot chocolate, which is quite tasty, and comes in enormous quantities.  The next time I'm there, I want to get the made-fresh-on-the-spot guacamole, which the folks at the table next to us had on our last visit.
author: Angela B.

description:
Holy Crap.  This place is amazing.  Let me break it down for you.

#1.  The prices are unbeatable.  A giant tamale the size of your head, plus rice and beans for less than $8?  A giant bowl of guacamole for $4?  The portions here are so generous and the prices are great to boot!

#2.  The service is wonderful.  I'm so accustomed to counter service at taquerias that it was great having a waiter who actually HAD an opinion about the things we ordered.  He came back to our table when he noticed no one had ordered the mole and told us that they were famous for it.  We just promised him we'd come back to try it... and we definitely will!

#3.  Mexican Hot Chocolate.  The last time I ordered Mexican Hot Chocolate in a taqueria, it was just Abuelita Cocoa crushed in a cup of warmed up milk.  This was SERIOUS hot chocolate... by far the best I've had in general in a long time.  It had cinnamon and almost maple syrup flavors that mixed together into a perfect symphony of chocolatey goodness.

#4.  Convenience.  It's close to BART and within walking distance of a lot of bars.  They also have an outdoor taco stand if you want something to go.

#5.  BAKERY.  Don't forget about that part in their title.  Their frig window next to the counter serves up some amazing looking Pastel de Tres Leches and Flan.  I was too full to indulge yesterday, but like I said before... I'll definitely be back!  They also have the typical Panaderia goods in the back next to the kitchen if you're looking for some pan dulces.
author: Grace K.

description:
Dropped by again and had a very consist experience. Still a great deal for the price, feels like a nice quiet place on busy Mission.

I think the regular mole tamales are actually better than the Oaxacan tamales which surprised me. I think the regular tamales are bigger and it seemed juicier to me than my previous go at the Oaxcan mole tamale.
author: Katy W.

description:
I came in for the tamales and the hot chocolate with some friends on a busy Saturday night. We were seated at the booth as this place was rockin' and busy.  I thought we'd be forgotten or ignored in a few minutes (yes, I'm used to San Francisco restaurant service). To my delight, not only were we not ignored, we were treated well and given delicious Mexican food.

Ordered:
Three tamales, including the banana leaf wrapped chicken mole tamales -- devoured!!

Rice & beans -- finished in minutes, too!

The hot chocolate -- we had to order more!

The service was nice, attentive, and polite. In San Francisco, that is hard to find!  But so are great tamales for a great price. Your portions are so generous, thank you!  And you tres leches cake was very unique and tasty too.

This place is my temple of all things tamale now. :)
author: Sari S.

description:
So, someone who grew up in Boston thinks that he can tell a native Californian how to eat Mexican and Latin American food. I stand by (So Cal origin) Kenny L.'s mantra of "the further from the motherland, the worse the food." Or something like that. Blah blah blah. Italian food is better in NY than SF. Blah blah blah.

Well. Damnit. CA has better Mexican and Latin American food than Massachussetts. Der.

And I foolishly trusted this guy to drag me here. 

He wins. What it does differently is what makes it good:

Their tamales are made the South American way, wrapped in banana leaves. And they are so moist and soothing. 

They do mole sauce well. I don't really like mole sauce. But if you like mole sauce, you will like their mole sauce. 

You can also get tacos with one of two types of fish: talapia or salmon. I got both and preferred the talapia over the salmon. Talapia is a mild fish that does well with salsa and cilantro. Salmon is too strong to really go well with the spices. 

Save room for desserts. The desserts alone make it worth the trip. The have a full bakery and also have a kick-ass flan. The flan was my favorite part of the meal. It's distinct though. If you're one of those people who like your flan really eggy and jello-like, you will not like theirs. If you like it dense, smooth, and creamy* like I do, you will like theirs.

The waiters are cool. They laughed at me when I specified that I wanted "The Mexican Coke."

They also have a taco stand that they wheel out to the street for the PBR-swilling hipsters. 

It's good. I'm not going to make a special trip back to SF just for this place. However, worth a stop if you're in the area. 

Boston guy *kinda* gets points. He'd get more points if the only men to tell me that I looked nice tonight weren't the panhandlers outside of the 16th St. BART station.
author: Zulu Q.

description: I came here on 1/17/15 (Saturday) at 2PM and they were closed. Tried calling, no one answered. I really wanted to try the grasshopper tacos (!) but wasn't able to. Had to drive 2 hours to get here, was so disappointed. Can someone update the store hours please?!
author: Isis S.

description:
We found La Oaxaqueña's food tasty enough and the multi-lingual service just fine and the hot sauce worthy of the name and the prices OK but the portions were a bit smaller than similar places.

We were extremely underwhelmed and intend to not return.
author: Swing C.

description:
This was my first real experience with oaxacan-style mexican food, and it blew my mind.  My friend that lived in oaxaca (mx) for ethnic studies research told me everything was spot on compared to the traditional stuff he had there.

If you only get one dish here ever, make it their tamal de mole negro (chicken mole, black), steamed in a BANANA LEAF.  The inside was the corn meal paste (as usual), wrapping up a dark, chocolaty chicken mole', but the banana leaf took this tamal to a whole new level.  Kinda made it taste like southeast asian food to me.  really subtle and amazing.  AND CHEAP at like $3 or so for one huge tamal.
  
The Tlayuda was like a mexican pizza.  but WAY better than taco bell's.  Nice crunchy flat "tostada" base, with lettuce, cheese, and meat of your choice on top.  And dthey ahve some great meats like the milanesa (breaded pork), cochinita pibil, and other meats that are traditional oaxacan.  Great for tacos too!

They also sell chapulines by the bag--though they will bring it out to you on a plate if you like.  These are grasshoppers, pan-fried with chili and limes.  Tip--don't eat the big hind legs. These are pretty good with beer, but definitely not for the faint of heart.

they also have a signature oaxacan drink called chamborrado--some kind of chocolate-rice-maybe corn starch drink.  a really viscous drink with chocolate flavor.

And they have a dulce de leche that rocks pretty hard.  If you come on a birthday, they will make you a birthday cake ON THE HOUSE, and ON THE SPOT, and even write the birthday boy/girl's name on the cake.  Last time I was there for Don H's birthday, it was a dulce de leche cake soaked with coffee sauce instead of your typical sweet milk.  delicious, and quite nice of the place to give a birthday gift that awesome!  :)

My only complaint about the place is the tiny tiny size, and the service is sometimes slow, though always friendly.
author: Fong L.

description:
Came to La Oaxaqueña on a Friday night and found a table right before the rush.  Had very high hopes for this place as everything about it (tiny hole in the wall and locals eating here) made me think the food would be amazing.

We started off with chips and guacamole--smart business men work here as they ask "Would you like warm chips and guacamole?" as if it's on the house when in reality it costs $5.50!  Don't mind as the portion of guacamole was large and it was probably the best thing about the meal.

We both got a Oaxacan chicken tamale and I also got a pupusa with "revuelta", pork.  Expected a bit more flavor from both of these, but overall they were just mild in taste--a little disappointed. 

We also tried the Atole Blanco, a warm rice drink.  The first couple sips were good, but definitely not something I'd order again--too thick and seems like it'd be meant more for dipping dessert into...

Worth checking out as the price is very reasonable.  Side note: when the bill came, I got a little confused that the top said "Karina's Mexican Bakery" with a completely different address--could have been an old location?
author: Christopher W.

description:
My boyfriend and I were hungry while apartment hunting and decided to stop into Oaxaquena for a pupusa to get us through the day. He is from El Salvador and knows what a good pupusa is, much like I know what good pizza is (since I'm from NYC). 

The service was great and attentive (especially when I spilled my water all over the floor). I liked the pupusa, although the maiz was a bit thick. 

I think i would head back there again to try their other dishes, which looked pretty elaborate!
author: Inga B.

description:
Wowee!!!!  The best mole I've had and it's right around the corner from me!!!

So, let me start this review by stating that I am a vegetarian and went with another of my kind.  As such, I can't rate a lot of the items here, but they do have a very good vegetarian selection and can make most things vegetarian.

The experience started with walking in and finding a surprisingly nice place for the block it's on and being welcomed by the very friendly folks that worked there.  Looking through the menu, we weren't sure what everything meant since only some things had an English translation, so we just asked the waiter to recommend something good vegetarian.  His first recommendation was to get the mole enchiladas without chicken.  Given that is one of my favorite dishes, I was ecstatic.  My friend got the spinach and cheese tamales.  We also got guacamole and chips for a starter (didn't see it on the menu but everyone was ordering it) along with a bottle of Mexican Coke.  There are more dishes there which I need to try on future visits, but let's limit this review to the above dishes for now.

The guac was pretty damn good.  Definitely not the best I had, as I prefer it a bit spicy, but overall, very flavorful and chunky which I do like.  The chips were so-so.  Not bad, but could use a bit more salt.  The tamale was decent.  Not the best I've had, but certainly very satisfying and, one was large enough to serve as a decent meal.

But, the mole, oh my goodness, the mole enchiladas.  I've had decent mole at Puerto Allegre on Valencia, but other than that, hadn't found great mole anywhere in the Bay Area but La Fiesta in Mountain View.  This, though, blew me away.  It was a bit spicy, but not too much.  A bit sweet, but not too much.  A bit smoky, but not too much.  Combine all that with the raw onions on top and the stuff was phenomenal.  The first few bites were an explosion of taste and it never let up after that.

To top all of it off, as we were paying our bill, the waiter gave us a slice of cake, on the house, to take with us for dessert later.  It was pretty good as well and given the entire dinner was $17, I felt like I was ripping them off somehow by getting this bonus.  I'm sure there's a cliche about a cake and eating in here somewhere.

Not everything here is the best I've ever eaten, but it was all good, and the mole is what puts the food here into 5-star territory.  The service is at least 4 stars and quite possibly 5.  The ambience is not why you go to a place like this so don't bother if that's what you're looking for.  I just hope I have the will power to order something other than the mole enchiladas next time I go visit the restaurant.  Maybe I should just stick to their taco cart for some variety. :-)
author: Anand M.

description:
It's been a couple years since I was last here, and 2 years too long! Love the variety on the menu. Its not just burritos and tacos and enchiladas, but tlayudas huaraches and pupusas too. I just had a venison taco. Fully loaded  with meat so flavorful, not too tough and not at all gamey. Served with roasted jalapenos and fresh chunky salsa, who could ask for more? The owner-- I should have gotten his name-- even hooked us up with some habanero salsa.

On the slight downside, the horchata was  not improved--not cinnamony enough for my taste-- and the chips a bit stale. That cost them a star. But if I lived in the area, I'd come here all the time. Will be back to try the pupusas --  aren't those salvadorean? In any case, ¡ Viva la oaxaqueña!
author: Polly F.

description:
The mole was intoxicating.  Really, I mean that.

The guacamole was okay (plentiful but a little too limey for my taste); the chips were very good (fresh out of the hot oil); beans and rice were standard fare; but the chicken enchilada mole (or is it chicken mole enchilada?; whatever it is it is the one NOT in the banana leaf) is what will make me go back there.  It was rich and chocolate-y, comforting and satisfying.  I am not from Oaxaca, but the mole made me feel like I was home.
author: rosylen m.

description:
I love tamales and horchata! I am always down to go get one, and yes I had banana leaf tamales before. When I was visiting my friend in the Mission, she asked me if I wanted to go to a place that serves Giant Tamales. My response, "YES!" (I think my eyes twinkled).

After walking a few blocks down we ended up here. I noticed a Yelp sticker at the door and extremely excited to get my grub on. 

I ordered a cup of horchata (that was giant as well), and banana leaf chicken mole tamale. I actually thought the mole was too intense and salty, but the masa was really good. My friend said the mole tasted different this time, so I'll definitely come back to try it out again just to see if it's different.

For now I give it a three star, but I will definitely be back :)
author: Tina T.

description:
Tamales were fantastic, as everyone says, especially the mole.  Tacos were also very, very good.  I would probably go with a different place for papusas, though-- I wasn't as impressed there, as the curtido is somewhat bland, lacking vinegar, and comes in too small a portion.

My real issue with the experience was that the food was 5 stars (for the price), but the service detracted from the experience significantly.  My to-go order took more than 25 min even when the place was relatively empty.   When I finally got the order, the papusas (which were not that great to begin with) were not the flavors that I had ordered; I received all cheese and bean, when I had ordered pork.

In short, not a place to go for ambiance or speed, and helpful to speak spanish if you want to be sure your order will be correct.
author: Jesse O.

description:
My friend Matthew brought me a piece of the Tres Leche cake last night....which I shared with my mother-in-law.  It was wonderful  One of the best slices of cake ever.  

I also continue to love the banana-leaf mole tamale.

And love the Mexican hot chocolate.

Open till 2am every evening.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Ate here for the first time on Friday night, and I really enjoyed it.  The place is very brightly done, in colors that could have easily been Indian as much as Mexican, giving it a very worldly feel.  It was bright and energetic, even though it was late on a Friday night.  I found it very fun and upbeat.

The menu was a good mix of Mexican fare, more so than the usual tacqueria, which is not what I'd call La Oaxaquena.  The food goes from tacos to pupusas to tamales, which is what they are known for.  So the owner pushed me toward their tamales - I had been eying pupusas after reading another review - but he was insistent on me trying the mole tamale.  How do you tell the owner you don't like mole when he is so passionate about it?  LOL  Well, I ordered tamales, just not the mole ones, and really enjoyed them.  Thanks to him for giving me the real scoop on what he thought expressed the essence of his kitchen, but please let me decide on what I'm going to eat.  :-)

The tamales were very tasty, and I'd recommend the vegetarian one over the meat ones - it had far more flavor than the meat.  And that's intended to mean how good the vegetarian one was, nothing to say negatively about the pork one.  

I will definitely be going back.  I love the menu and its execution, so far, and really enjoy the upbeat interior.
author: Scott L.

description:
I am so happy i discovered this place.
I had some late night tacos their one night that were amazing and only a buck fifty, then i went back tody for lunch and had chicken mole tamale wrapped in banana leaf, wow! just amazing, never had a tamal wrapped in banana leaf, but know i dont know how i can go back!
but what i will do is go back to this place over and over again!!!
author: dub g.

description:
Best mexican bakery in SF!

I wish i knew the names of what I was eating, but it doesnt matter because everything is so good!

I suggest getting anything with custard in the middle, its great with a side of milk.

ive been here about 3 times and each time i never experienced a spoiled or dry bakery item.

extremely cheap also, not sure how much each item was but i bought about 10 items and it was under 10 bucks!
author: Josh W.

description:
Big tamales, fine if you want "fast food"


DISHES:
Banana leaf tamale with chicken and Oaxacan mole
$4.50
The tamale is big, flat, and square. The masa is very smooth and moist. The chicken with mole was lacking and dry. There could have been more chicken and definitely more mole.

Corn leaf tamale with rajas (tomatoes, jalapeños, cheese)
$2.75
The tamale was rectangular in shape and had more filling compared to the banana leaf tamale with chicken. It wasn't spicy, despite having jalapeños. The cubes of bouncy, white cheese were tasty. The masa was slightly more gritty than the other tamale, but still quite smooth in texture and moist.

The mole dipping sauce was nice - not overly thick or watery, smooth, not too salty.

DRINK:
Mexican Hot Chocolate with soymilk
$4.25 + 0.50
This drink was ginormous! My friend and I shared this drink, but still couldn't finish it. It smelled kinda like a cupcake with a hint of spices. I prefer regular hot chocolate. This was more watery and sweeter than what I like. There might have been cinnamon at the bottom of the drink, but we sure didn't reach it. 


AMBIANCE: Hole in the wall with bacon-wrapped hot dogs grilling by the front door. Long narrow space inside.

SERVICE: There was only one lady who was taking orders, and she seemed busy. It took us a while to flag her down to order and again to correct our order. Her English was lacking, so we stumbled to ask why our tamales didn't come with sauce as indicated in the menu. After a few attempts, she understood and returned with our sauces.

VISIT DETAILS: Quick dinner with a friend. Plenty of seating at 7 pm on a Wednesday night.
author: C L.

description:
What I love about this place is that it is so unassuming, so very Mission yet at the same time probably some of the best Mexican food you are going to find in the city, without feeling like you have to eat in some broken-down shack to find the same level of food. Cute, quaint, very affordable and awesome possum - that's what this place is! This is not your typical divey taqueria. 

Yes, the banana leaf tamales are amazing. Quality is consistent. Everything else looks good. They even have deep friend tarantulas - the owner said those taste like soft shell crap (One day I'll work up the nerve to order them)

If you do get the mole tamales, ask for a little extra mole. Last time I was there they skimped!
author: Ziv S.

description:
Okay, but definitely disappointing.
Based on the reviews and a high recommendation from a foodie friend, I expected something fantastic.  Now, I know a good banana leaf tamale, and was excited to have a chicken mole tamale reminiscent of those I've had in Oaxaca and Chiapas.  The chicken was nice and tender, but the mole was too dry and clumpy---I wanted something so gooey that it'd be better eaten with a spoon than a fork.
The pupusa was just okay, and I wasn't sure why pupusas were even on the menu at a Mexican restaurant.
The guac was good but nothing to write home about.
The highlight of the meal was the chicken tinga taco, which really was incredible.

The restaurant loses a star for service... there was only one person working in the kitchen and one guy working the front of the house on a busy Saturday night.  We had to flag down the waiter several times and everything took a really long time---and he wasn't friendly or helpful enough to make up for it.  It was obvious that they were just understaffed but what should have been a quick in-and-out took over an hour.  The best part was that an entire meal for two came out to under $14.
author: Anna W.

description:
Exciting additions to their menu = excited additions to their yelp reviews! Went here a few nights ago for some comfort food, and took my friend who has never been but heard me speak praises por La Oxaquena, 
We split the "Trio de Pupusas" and el tamale platano con pollo en mole. The "trio" is a new, brilliantly bright, dish with blue corn, red tomato, and green spinach tortillas. The green is stuffed with spinach-artichoke, the red with mozzarella, tomato and pesto, and the blue corn has cheddar. MMmmmm. Each was warm, fluffy, and.super flavorful.  La Oxaquena now serves beer as well, and their menus are newly designed and laminated to show off their ever delicious- still inexpensive- items.
author: Raquel C.

description:
"I can't believe I ate the whole thing" was what I heard in my head as soon as I finished my tlayuda. 

I had ordered a tlyadua (Mexican pizza) with salmon and Oaxaca cheese for 13 bucks, and had been served a massive (16 inches or so in diameter) tostada spread with refried beans, lettuce, salsa, cheese, and many chunks of grilled salmon. 

The flavor was pretty good in general--crispy tostada, fresh salmon, but there was an odd taste I couldn't quite place that didn't seem quite right. Still, I kept eating.

Servicewise it was a bit slow...my dish took at least 15 minutes to come out, and it's not really a labor-intensive thing to prepare. 

All in all, it seems like a good hole-in-the-wall place to go.
author: David Z.

description:
SUCH friendly service.
SUCH nice salsas.
a FANTASTIC vegan tamal.
no complaints here, which is pretty rare for me as i highly enjoy a good rant.
wow, i think i just managed to complain about the lack of anything to complain about.
whatever, buen provecho!
author: Lisa M.

description:
Pretty good restaurant! My boyfriend and I went in for some tacos the other night, and they were delicious! I had the coconut chicken tacos (amazzzzing), and my boyfriend had a hawaiian chicken and carne asada taco. There was so much flavor in the taco and I cannot wait to go back to try more on their menu. Oh, and a bonus that I loved was that the guy who was working there just gave my boyfriend and I a free Mexican hot chocolate, which was probably the best hot chocolate I have tasted. I loved it, and it made my night complete.

Two downsides...one was that the hot sauce they use was way too spicy for me. It did give more flavor, but there was just a tad too much on my taco, however its not a make or break thing. I also wasn't a fan of their carne asada (I tried my boyfriend's taco), and it wasn't too flavorful. But I am excited to take a trip back to eat more of their delicious food!
author: Lisa B.

description:
Mexican swine flu?

PSHAW!

I had an al pastor taco without hand sanitizer or condom... delish! And didn't contract anything shameful. The chicken mole tamala were good and big - a meal in itself. The staff even threw in a complimentary slice o' cake (they are a bakery) for good measure. The food is cheap, except for the specials and the quac 'n'chips.
author: wayne s.

description: Best taqueria in the Mission. Don't agree? Go stand in line for half an hour for a zucchini burrito in a tomato spinach wrap. I don't have time for you.
author: Alexander D.

description:
going to have to downgrade my initial review of this place. got here at 12:30am on a wednesday night with my brother on a burrito run. got to oaxaquena and saw a taco cart outside. score. $1.75 for an al pastor taco, which was phenomenal. the lime was juicy, grilled onions sweet and caramelized, cilantro subtle, and meat succulently tender. unlike other al pastor tacos i had, this meat was more firm, but still packed with a smoky flavor, so there was nothing wrong with that.

where things started going downhill was when i went inside. i really wanted a burrito, but at 6.95 for a regular meat burrito, i could not pull the trigger; it was a bit too pricey, so i went with a revueltas pupusa at $2.50. very standard price, so no problems there. the pupusa itself was pretty greasy, but i don't expect otherwise for such an item. inside, the cheese was oozing and pushed out as i dug into this delicious item. the beans and meat tasted very fresh, and they were very soft and cooked well. the salsa was not great though, so i just left it on the plate. the curtido was super bland despite the pickling. so altogether, i'll take away one star for the prices and the curtido. otherwise, this place is still solid.
author: Danny C.

description:
If you want Oaxacan food without first flying to Los Angeles or Mexico, this is really your only choice. The wait staff is very friendly and willing to accomodate--typically Oaxacan!

But...

The tlayuda is not prepared fresh. The tostada underneath is premade, which makes it chewy, not crisp. They have quesillo, the distinctly-flavored Oaxacan cheese that helps give a tlayuda its unique taste, but the tlayuda we split (they're large) came with pinto refried beans, not the usual Oaxacan black beans, and they didn't taste like they'd been flavored with epazote.

We also split a Oaxacan-style tamal (chicken and mole wrapped in a banana leaf). It also tasted like it'd been made previously then heated before serving. It did not look or taste like a tamal that came out of a steamer.

So there's that. La Oaxaquena also serves tamal tortas, liquados, and, uh...some other Mexican food that isn't particularly Oaxaqueno. They had mojarra frito one night as a special, and advertise barbacoa de chivo on the weekends. They were out of chapulines when we were there; those things happen.

I'm rooting for this place, but Number 1 on the to-do list is fresh tlayudas.
author: Suzanne C.

description:
I have been searching San Francisco for a while now in search of some good mole. Ever since I moved out of my parents house I have never been able to find mole that tasted like my moms. Yet this place was right one. I order the enchiladas with black mole when they came to the table my mouth begun to water, the enchiladas were immersed in a pool of delicious looking mole and cheese. When I took a bit it was as good as my mothers, I would hate to admit....it was even slightly better. I washed the dish down with a tall ice cold class of Jamaica ( hibiscus water). 

And it was all a really good price, the server was really nice. 


I will definitely be going back for more.


tacos for 1.50, tamales for 3.00?  what can beat that?
author: Natasha O.

description:
I am reluctant to give this place 2 stars since I've only been once, but I must've been there on an off day. 

The service was slow, my tamale was mush in a banana leaf, and the tlayuda was stale. When I asked him if their tamales normally soup, he said they just finished cooking and shrugged it off. I could barely eat  it. Which was too bad, because the mole was pretty good. 

I may give this place another chance, but not for a while.
author: Kealie G.

description:
Yet to try anything here I didn't like, but some of my favorite things are:

banana leaf tamales - chicken mole or verde - either is amazing
mexican pizza with carnitas
goat cheese chipotle  pupusas - heck, any of the pupusas
spicy pork tacos
liquedos - sorry for butchering the spelling, but the smoothies are killer
and finally
mexican hot chocolate - OMG!

the people are wonderful here too (the people who work there that is!)

love it.  HUGE portions too. let's not forget that important fact.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Where are we going to go for lunch on Sunday?  

Mmm, I don't know I'll call you on Saturday.

Enter the SF Examiner - read a review on the Oaxaquena Restaurant.  My mouth starts watering.  

E-mail my friends - Meet me at the Oaxaquena at 2.

Get there a little late - had to park a couple blocks down.  Wait a couple minutes for a table, but no dice.  Not a place for too many people - decide to sit four of us at the counter.  

Order the hot chocolate - frothy goodness with an extra mini-pitcher for refills.  

Camarones rancheras, camarones a la diabla (an off the menu special), and 2 Tlayudas later we're stuffed, happy and talking about our next trip to this place. The shrimp dishes were mostly shrimp (they don't skimp at this place) and the Tlayudas were HUGE and could definitely be a split meal.  We wanted to try more, but were too full.  

Can't wait until next time...
author: Ixchel F.

description:
The chicken con mole tamale in banana leaves is awesome. And huge- that's all I ate, I boxed up my other food. My friend said her carne asada taco was delicious. 
Friendly service, clean place, super cheap, delicious food. Yay!
author: Shoshanna C.

description:
Our Day of the Dead Committee visited SF this weekend & found this little Oaxacan place on YELP. Well worth the trip to the Mission. We'll be back again as soon as we can!  It's a very small storefornt. With a sidewalk vendor out front. Pretty much right across the street from Thrit Town. (Remember the 17 Reasons Why sign?) 

Sadly, no chapulinas. But everything we had was wonderful. And the staff was delightful. We started with a gigantic mole banana leaf wrapped tamale and the salt cod fritters. (see photos.) We just ordered a bunch dishes & didn't know what to expect. These two dishes were really exceptional. We shared them and LOVED them! And the chef, Herbert, enjoyed with how much we enjoyed the food. We also had the papusas and huaraches and fajitas. For dessert, Herbert brought us a slice of his special cheese flan - made with Manchego & cheddar, rich and creamy and topped with the traditional caramel. Also enjoyed the hot chocolate.  Wish I could make it at home! And we also sampled another drink - I didn't catch the name - but it was a hot sweet rice drink something like horchata. And then we  took home a slice of creamy cake. We were happily stuffed. Wonderfully prepared food for a very modest price. Lost count of all the food, but I think we had 6 - 8 plates for about $50. A delicious assortment of unusual flavors. Buzzed with sugar and the excitement of a good meal. And we were ready for more again by breakfast - but we'll have to wait for our next trip.
author: Tara M.

description:
just visiting san francisco and popped into this place as a late night treat...WOWYUM.
huge pot of fresh guac, delicious pupusas and lots of other great options.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Summary:  Upset stomachs, lost order, poor service, so-so food

We came on Sunday afternoon and were pleasantly surprised to see the restaurant full.  Having read good things on Yelp, we ordered the mexican hot chocolate, horchata, the mole tamale in banana leaf, tilapia taco, and a salmon tlayuda.

The chocolate and horchata came immediately and were very good - not too sweet.  

After twenty minutes, we were wondering where our order was.  After thirty minutes and observing three parties who came in after us receive their order, we flagged down the waitress and asked about our order.  She said she would check.  After 10 more minutes, we were still waiting, with no information.  

She finally brought us the tlayuda, and asked us if we had ordered anything else?!  After somewhat testily relaying the details of our order, they switched our servers, who finally brought the remaining items.

The tamale was tasty, though not as voluminous as other reviewers had said (the leaf was huge, but there was not a proportional amount of masa and chicken).  The tilapia taco was fine, but the tlayuda was stale, and the salmon tasted old.  We asked for some chips, which were stale and oily.

Both of us now have upset stomachs.  We'll not be back again.
author: Go S.

description: Excellent authentic food. Got the sopes with grilled chicken, carne asada, and carnitas. All were delicious!
author: Jennifer K.

description: You've had those debates about best burrito/Mexican in the Mission. Go here and put the debates to rest. Veggie & gluten-free options!
author: Raina M.

description: Since I am new to this yelping thing I might as well get busy today! This a nice spot for some real tacos. Nothing fancy, but the food is good and the price is right.
author: Charles C.

description:
The Hot chocolate with chilli is unreal.

We went back the next night for some mole tomalleys, wow! The red and black mole were amazing. We filled up and it was so cheap. I will keep going back until I have finished the menu.
author: Dylan E.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the city. It's a big statement, but I mean it. 

I love their mole tamales, their chorizo, their hot chocolate, their tlyaudas. And they have the best lunch deal, around $5 for a meal and drink. And the people who work there are always so nice!
author: Tina B.

description:
Can I just say that I am in LOVE with this place!!! I went for the first time the other day..one of my buddy's has been coming here for years and finally clued me in on the place.

The tacos are soooooo good and cheap, they made me flash back to my under-age drunken days in T.J. (although this place is Oaxacan). I had 3 tacos - lengua, al pastor, and chorizo and i was in heaven...3 tacos for $4.50, dude seriously best cheap lunch ever!

The service was good too, everyone was very friendly AND it's BYOB!! I believe I have found my new taco spot
author: Roxanne C.

description: The waitress speaks mostly spanish. The tamales are $2.50-$3.50! I highly recommend the cheese and spinach tamale. Make sure to try the chapulinas~
author: Em L.

description:
Best $5 meal I can get in the area...

Tamale chicken con mole- fairly large and delicious.

Tres Leche- hit the spot, but I wouldn't have minded if it were slightly more moist

Service- I wish I knew the name of my waiter because he made my night. Very friendly and very respectful
author: Tram-Anh H.

description:
The guacamole was definitely one of the best I've had. I wanted to slather it on everything, which I'm sure I did. We ordered the chicken mole wrapped in banana leaf tamale, a sun dried tomato and goat cheese papusa,  and the dinner plate that had 2 enchiladas with mole. Since it was our first experience with mole, we were definitely overwhelmed by it. Half way through my gigantic tamale, I had to give up. The mole was just too sweet for us. We enjoyed the papusa although I'm not the biggest fan of goat cheese. 
The service was great. We had a french guy serving us and he was in to help his friend, the owner. He was very accommodating and gave us a lot of insight on the menu.
author: Lee N.

description:
Upon returning here 2 other times and I was very disappointed on all levels. Both times they got my orders wrong ,it was a struggle to get them to understand my orders even with a Spanish speaking guest of mine. I was so disappointed on all levels, I will not be returning and don't recommend this to anyone. 

Debbie Rio
author: Deborah R.

description:
The tamales really aren't that great. Trust me.

However, the Pupusas were out of this world. The guac was great too. That's all I'll be ordering the next time I'm there. Best Mexican food i"ve had to date.
author: Jon C.

description:
La Oaxaqueña seems to have changed ownership or at least cooks and servers, and unlike half a year ago when it was hard to get a table, it was now deservingly half empty at 8:00PM on a Friday night.  The flavorful masa harina of the tamales is still good, but the tamales seem to be old and reheated and the service is slow and irregular.  It looked as if one man was doing it all, the minimal cooking or reheating, serving, and everything else.  It is sad that the once excellent food and lively atmosphere has declined.  It is still OK, but nowhere near its previous quality.

This was m former review:  "The food here is amazing.  The Sopes (I had one with pineapple laden al pastor) are the best I can imagine, and the corn husk wrapped tamales (I had pork) are incredible.   The banana leaf wrapped tamales (huge) are also wonderful, with the kind of flavorful masa harina and Oaxacan moles that are better than anything I've had in similar dishes elsewhere.  The food is really inexpensive; two of us ate big meals with non-alcoholic drinks for $16.  The place is small and the service not very fast, but it is quiet (except for the 7 or so tables of people laughing and enjoying themselves, even without alcohol) with no loud music, and the staff is very friendly. The overall dining experience can't be beat, for pleasant informal surroundings and wonderful ethic food.  I didn't have to wait on a Wednesday night at 7:30."
author: Michael S.

description:
The food is good (average and acceptable), and very affordable BUT the service is extremely slow! My friend and I waited about 20-30 minutes before getting our food - we only ordered 3 things!! 

The Guacamole is ok, i've had better. 
The tamales and cheese enchiladas were great. 
I also tried the ' sun dried tomato and goat cheese' pupusa and was not impressed. 

Overall, one of the better places in the mission to grab Mexican food - IF you have the time to wait.
author: Harvinder K.

description: Solid late-night food option in the Mission.  Whatever I eat there is good.  Frankly, you can't go wrong with a quick line and a menu with a ton of options.  Go inside and try for yourself.
author: Mike H.

description:
This place was aiiiite.

I concur that the green salsa is very delicious, but based on the order I had, I would say the place is pretty average.

Cool things I noticed about the place is that they serve breakfast burritos at night, which seems like a rarity up here in the city.  Another dope thing is that their tamale's are well worth your money since are gigantor.

Next round, I'm gonna give the tacos, tamale's, and pupusa's a shot.  You should definitely eat out here if you are out in the mission and are in need of some drunken absorption after a good couple hours of knocking some drinks out.
author: Mark L.

description:
This place is so good it's absurd. The food is excellent. The prices are stunningly reasonable. They are open well into the night. The owner and staff are cheerful and cool. It's mystifying how great this place is-- Its like a portal into a bygone era.

La Oaxaquena's variety of mole sauces, fancy tamales and other specialty items easily outclass most white-tablecloth food in the surrounding neighborhood. Try their exotic meats-- if the grasshopper taco isn't your thing, get an ostrich taco--- they're great
author: Basketball J.

description:
I have only eaten the tamales from this joint.  I have eaten the chicken mole and green chile pork tamales.  I think the food is a great value, as the tamales are a huge, moist and flavorful.  Plus they always taste fresh.

Now the best tamales I have had are moms, so I have a fairly high standard.  I am ok with saying that these tamales are probably some of the best in the city, dollar per dollar. 

I would give it five stars, but the mole and green sauce are just very good, not great.  

Their Mexican style hot chocolate is pretty good too.
author: Jaime T.

description:
The way food should be: simple, tasty, and affordable. Courteous staff made good suggestions (delicious HUGE tamales) and all the food was yummy. The pupusas were pretty good too. Also try to mexican hot chocolate. A nice finish to the meal.
And in the end, you feel like you had a good meal without leaving your wallet (or everything in it) at the restaurant.
This place isn't fancy, but go there if you want a satisfying Mexican meal in a friendly environment.
author: Mercedes P.

description:
It's a tiny place on a sketchy block and it's better if you don't come so that I don't have to wait for a table in the future.

Even though we had some ordering problems, we enjoyed everything we got. I had the chicken tamales with mole and a tomato and cheese tamale. And, the refried beans were rockin!

We accidentally ordered the guac and chips when my husband ordered the coke that is cheapest and we got chips. The mole enchiladas looked amazing. And I bought pastries for the morning to share at work.

I am definitely coming back.
author: Thanya S.

description: Good food and mole. Friendly staff and good service.
author: Saul E.

description: Absolutely awesome tortas. Order any of them. They are all good. Fresh baked bread, spicy peppers, avocado, tomatoes, beans, and cheese. Fantastic. Plus they're open really early in case you wake up really early hung over and starving or are still awake.
author: Hiten P.

description:
I had the tlayuda and my brother the fajitas. We also ordered the bag of chapulines.

The chapulines were too salty. 

Tlayuda had too much lettuce and not enough beans or cheese. 

Interesting items on menu, but poor execution (at least on these dishes).

The decoration is first rate. Bright, colorful. Exactly how I want my mexican restaurants decorated.
author: Norman P.

description: This place is all the rage. It's really good. The Tlayuda is great (has everything you want on it, from beans, to lettuce, to cotija, to avocado) -- issue is it's impossible to take leftovers home -- you gots to eat it right there -- and it's huge. The horchata is also very creamy and yummy.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Last night was my second time going here.  The first was for a torta a month or two ago. I thought the torta was ok, but not amazing. (I have high torta standards thanks to my friend WVG who is a torta expert). I went last night hoping to maybe get a cookie or something light as a late night snack to soak up the alcohol and nourish my slightly hungry belly.  Harry, the owner convinced me to try the tamale.  Now, I don't really like tamales. they usually don't do anything for me and i find them bland, but he was very insistent on it and assured me i would like it.  While waiting for it to be prepared i also bought some chapulines, or fried grasshoppers because I've had them elsewhere before and liked them.  The chapulines weren't the best that i have had, however being that you can't get them anywhere else i shouldn't complain.

The chicken mole tamale was AMAZING.  as mentioned, i don't usually like tamales but this thing was super duper good. i couldn't get enough of it truthfully.  Harry was right.

He also threw in a piece of their tres leches cake.  I plan to have that with lunch today and am very excited for it.  They have other things on the menus that look great and i am eager to go back and try them.
author: Andrew r.

description:
A little disappointed. I love Oaxacan food, but the carne asada sandwich I got was really tough. I really had to fight that meat with my teeth (that's what she said).

The rest of it was delicious, though, and huge and affordable. Probably would save $1.50 next time and just get the regular cheese rather than the Oaxacan cheese.
author: Mark A.

description: I really don't know how i ended up at this spot .my memory is a bit hazy from Saturday night.. but from what i remember I  inhaled their surf and turf burrito. service was great! Ohhhh yeah i remember now they have colored tortilla chips,green and red ones.. dope!
author: Omar I.

description:
I was thrilled when I found this place because I had awesome, interesting food in Oaxaca - great moles, tortillas made from scratch, grasshoppers - and this place seemed to serve much of it!

The food wasn't bad, but I was somewhat disappointed to realize that they didn't have all those moles (yes, there are many), and that much of the menu actually was about the same as any old taqueria in the Mission. We had some grasshopper tacos, some chicken with black mole (that's the one with chocolate), and some other stuff I can't even remember anymore. They get props for having some interesting food, and for managing to serve grasshoppers in SF, but the cooking was average and the service was inattentive.
author: Lina M.

description: Fantastic place.  Try the Mexican Hot Chocolate, tamales wrapped in banana leafs, or anything with mole.  Very authentic.  Even has  grasshoppers if you want em.  The owner brought us samples and free desert just for being nice.
author: Tim O.

description: Definitely one of my new favorite spots in the Mission. It's cheap, delicious and has awesome vegan/vegetarian options. The staff is friendly and offers great service. I love introducing friends and family to this little spot.
author: Justin G.

description:
I was NOT impressed with this place at all!  We went last night and ordered the fish dinner and the chicken fajitas.  Before our meal came out, they brought us some chips and salsa.  The salsa was good but the chips were terrible.  Stale, really oily, just gross!
The fish dinner was fine, a little on the sweet side for those who might not like coconut milk very much.  The beans that came with it were really good.  Unfortunately the rice on the side was unevenly cooked.
The fajitas had good flavor, but we stared at the "chicken" for awhile trying to decide if it was real or a soy substitute.  It did not have the shape or texture of real chicken. My boyfriend thought maybe it was reconstituted chicken or something like that.   In any event, it was NOT what we were expecting.
I had a discount coupon from Blackboard Eats, so I can't say I felt ripped off.  But if I had paid full price for this meal I would have definitely felt cheated.
author: Gami G.

description:
For the past few weeks, I've been dreaming about coming back here. Tonight was the night. My stummy was aching for some tacos and tres leches cake. 

The cart wasn't out tonight because the usual grill master was out sick. Regardless, the food was still mouth watering delicious! Jeff Y. and I enjoyed tacos lengua and al pastor... with a nice dish full of grilled pineapples. I had four, he had two. Yes... I'm a big fatty. The tacos were just as I remembered. Can't wait to go back and get some more. 

MMM... now onto the tres leches cake. The last time I tasted this heavenly cake was in Santa Ana at some hole in the wall on Bristol. Wow... one bite of this cake brought back so many fond memories. The cake was light and spongy. Sweet and yummy. At this point, I felt like I gained 5 pounds, but that was okay! 

We moved onto trying some of the grasshoppers displayed in the window. Good crunch and nicely roasted. It was seasoned with something that tasted like tea leaves. I could have eaten the entire bag. 

We also got to spend some one-on-one time with the owner. While complimenting him on the food and asking what he'd recommend for us to try next time, he made us an Oaxacan hot chocolate cinnamon type drink. What a great way to top off the night. The drink was light and had just enough sweetness that finished the meal nicely. 

Did I mention that we only spent $13 on 6 tacos and 2 tres leches cakes? Yes... what a deal. We left with the biggest smiles on our faces. ^_____________________^

Mr. Owner - We hope to see you soon! Probably in a few days! =)
author: Teresa Y.

description: Great food and great service! The waitress was so helpful and I loved the feel of the place overall. Was a great refuge on a rainy day in the Mission! Food was authentic and pretty large portions! They also take credit cards which was hard to find on Mission St! Definitely a fave in the Mission! :)
author: Manuel V.

description:
La Oaxaqueña is really awesome for a few reasons:

1. It's open hella late and you get your food fast

2. They have a Torta de huevo. I'd never had this before, and it tastes like a McMuffin on mexi-steroids. It's amazing.

3. The little man outside makes tacos so you don't even have to go INTO the restaurant to get the bomb ass food.
author: Marco B.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. Great banana leaf chicken mole tamale. Excellent guac. and Cheap!!!! I'm looking forward to my next visit. 

If your in the mission, and need a quick cheap tasty meal, this is the place.
author: Keith B.

description:
So I went here because it's new, it's right there on Mission, and because so far it has amazing reviews.

I am going to go ahead and agree with everyone else so far!

As a VEGETARIAN, and after reading the menu, I didn't expect much, since Oaxaca is not necessarily known for meat-free dishes.  But I saw that they had a number of mole dishes and lots of other tasty things.  The guy we ordered with who works the counter was ridiculously friendly and helpful with recommendations.  I asked him straight up if they could make a vegetarian cheese enchilada with mole sauce.  He thought for a moment, and then said sure, even though it wasn't really on the menu.  My friend got the Tlayuda with beef. It was quite a large and flat tortilla covered in tomatoes and cheese and avocado on a giant plate.  She said she was starving, but she still couldn't finish it.  You could share it for two people.  I let her taste my delectable mole dish and she was impressed as well.

The atmosphere is cheery, simple, friendly, and authentic, not fancy or cheesy with fake murals of cacti or anything.  At the end, I asked the dude (whose name I now wish I had asked) for a dessert recommendation.  They have a giant case full of yummy mexican pastries, and he pointed to those, but then he recommended the flan, and it was amazing!  I am not a flan connoisseur, but it was incredibly delicious, cold, creamy, and sweet.

If you haven't gone, go now! But go early cause it's small if you want a table.  And get their horchata to drink.
author: Kyle T.

description: The best Tamales in San Francisco and very intimate great service best of all we ran into friends you can't miss this find!
author: Freddie O.

description: I would love to give this restaurant a better review, unfortunately my friend and I ate here last month and about two hours later she was sick with food poisoning. We ate exactly the same things the entire day with the exception of her lemonade and spicy pork taco here at La Oaxaquena. It was unfortunate, since it definitely dimmed her first visit to San Francisco. I won't be bringing anyone else here. Bummer!!
author: Katelyn M.

description:
Returned here with a friend for a second visit because I had diner envy the last time I ate here.  I was determined to try more things off of their menu.

Guacamole and Chips
A generous portion arrived to the table and it tasted like it was freshly made.  The guacamole had chunks of fresh tomatoes and cilantro.  Muy bueno!

Tlayuda
A giant tostada on steroids!  A crispy tortilla was layered with refried beans, Oaxacan cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, avocados, and chicken cooked in tequila.  Beware, do not attempt to eat this by yourself.

Chicken Mole Negro in Banana Leaf
A little messy to unwrap but inside was a delicious moist tamale with chicken in a rich black mole.

Tres Leche Cake
Took a slice home for later, and I have to say this was one of the best tres leches cakes I have tasted.  Moist and creamy, filled with pineapple and topped with cream.

This time I am bumping up my rating to four stars because of the attentive service and delicious food.
author: Rob L.

description: This place is a pretty typical Mexican restaurant.  I ordered the chapulina and spicy pork taco, and a mexican coke.  The only reason I gave this place 2 stars is because the waitress is rather nice.  However, the service is slow, especially since there were only 2 of us.  The spicy pork taco was dry and flavorless.  The chapulina taco left a lingering feeling in my mouth.  She automatically assumed I wanted a large coke (75 cents more).  On top of everything, the food gave me food poisoning an allergic reaction.
author: Dean W.

description: After seeing a show at Cafe Du Nord, my friend wanted a late night snack. She lives in the Mission and suggested we get Chicken Mole Tamales here. It was 1 a.m. It was packed. It was delish. Enough said!
author: Dennis S.

description: The food was good here. I had the Chicken mole dinner and it was great. The spices on the sauce were just right. My girlfriend had the Cabeza Quesadilla and the cabeza was very tasty, not like other places that offer cabeza, here there was no large chunks of fat in the cabeza. Wanted to try the desserts, but we were too full; next time.
author: Michael P.

description: I. am. in. love. with. this. place. Please, tell all your friends. These people have something special here. Where else can you find hipsters eating  chocolate covered burritos? Also, the mole tamale will change your life. Eat.
author: Julie H.

description: Since moving to SF, I have yet to find a place that serves me the authentic Mexican food I love. But at least La Oaxaquena gives me a little of what Ive been missing. Its not AS authentic because in SF everything has to be sprayed with organic, tofu, vegan, sustainable ect. ect.. Don't get me wrong. I like to eat well but sometimes this can become a gimmick. I love love love the chicken mole tamale wrapped in banana leaf. Its really rich though and it's good sized. Love the very friendly guy at the counter that gave us some free mexican hot chocolate. Will be back. Only negative was the pan. Given, we came at night. The pan was pretty hard, not a great selection.
author: Lauren N.

description:
Wow!  Completely fantastic, and very inexpensive!
It don't look like much on the outside (or really on the inside either - ah sweet fluorescent lighting, how I love you), but damn is the food amazing.

The mole negro is seriously The Shit.  Blacker than black, rich, intense, smokey, and with a great fiery kick.  I've never had mole like this before, so I am forced to assume this is seriously authentic.  It's available in many forms, like chicken mole enchiladas, which are most excellent, or the chicken mole negro tamale, wrapped in banana leaves, which is equally unique - the banana leaves give it a decidedly different, mellower flavor than the more common corn wrapping.

On weekends, you can get the barbacoa de chivo, which is crazy holy shit good.  The meat is fall-apart-tender, and the sauce has tremendous flavor (and tremendous kick as well - not for the faint of spice!).

Aguas Frescas are great, and served in what must be 32oz glasses.  Ridiculously large, in fact.  But who can turn down 32 delicious ounces of horchata?  Yeah, not me.

If that all wasn't enough, they also don't serve any alcohol, so you can BYO!

The only things to be forewarned about: the place is small - they can maybe seat 25 people max, and service can get a little distracted at times, so you have to be obvious when flagging them down.
But trust me - it's worth it!
author: Don H.

description: I had a turkey tamale, wrapped in a banana leaf. It was the best tamale I've ever had! The masa was flavorful and moist, the mole had complex and delicious flavor, and the turkey was plentiful. I'm a fan!
