author: Chris T.

description: Authentic, quick taco stand. Its a hole in the wall, but we wanted something quick - we just stood out on the street and got our meal.
author: dosa w.

description:
After a show at the Orpheum, this place was a few which were open late and had good reviews.
Area is a little shady and for a few seconds we felt a bit out of place in our finery but that quickly disappeared. It was plain interesting watching the passerby and customers that came in. Very colorful. 
I ordered chicken tamale, which brought tears to my eyes. So yummy. Tilapia Tacos, which were good but nothing compared to my tamale. 
Unadventurous HD ordered fajitas which were not outstanding. I guess he is used to having sourcream and guacamole and cheese on his from the mall restaurants. Service was good. The young man at the counter was super helpful. My mouth is watering thinking about the banana leaf chicken tamale...and i just had a good meal an hour ago....
author: M G.

description:
yea baby. yea.

guacamole, check
chicken mole tamale, check
tacos (cabeza, pollo asado, carne asada, lenguisa), check.

this place was deeeeee-licious. after watching a friend's show down in the mission we walked on over for some grub. the place isn't big, but when you walk in the first thing you notice is that it smells delicious!

the tacos are $1.50, and are almost double the size of those small tacos you normally get for $1.50.  not only are they bigger, but they taste great!

the mole tamales were humongo and quite tasty as well, i had 2 tacos and split a mole tamale along with some guac and i was stuffed.

super fun awesome bonus: byob! we brought in some coronas to accompany our meal. the guy behind the counter even offered to loan us his bottle opener for the coronas, what a place.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Best horchata of my life!

The banana leaf chicken mole tamale is absolutely fantastic and my favorite item on the menu. The table service does not increase the modest prices. Hands down one of the best places to eat in the Mission.

Sweet or savory, this place is a total win.
author: kari d.

description:
No review I write, be it regarding what to order or what not to order will come close to the recommendations you can get every time you stop by from the owner, harry, who is at the cash register (shaved head and mustache). He has never let me down. If I'm indecisive and leaning toward getting the mole again he asks if I've tried the (insert delicious dish here) to which I always reply, "I'll take it!"

I always leave a big tip here because I feel the food is way under priced and I don't think food should cost what they ask but what it is worth. You should too!
author: Eli D.

description:
When i got off of work, i had a craving for a lengua taco, so naturally, i headed to the Mission. I was planning on going to El Farolito, my usually go-to taco place, but i accidentally got off at 16th Street and Mission rather than 24th Street and Mission. So, i decided to go on an adventure and find a new place to satisfy my Taco cravings.
I walked my  La Oaxaqueña and saw SFWeekly signs outside the door and decided to go in. I ordered a Lengua Taco and a Cabeza taco. I sat down and waited a good 25-30 minutes before my taco arrived. I was slightly peeved by how long this took, since my taco run was supposed to be only a "quick" bite and i was anxious to hurry home to finish some more work.  BUT, once i put this taco in my mouth, i realized that it was worth the wait. There was so much flavor in this taco. Not only was the meat very flavorful, but it was also very tender. They also added a lot of yummy veggies on top of this taco like grilled onions. 

While i had been waiting for the food, i looked around at the restaurant. It was then that i realized what restaurant i walked into. I saw the name "La Oaxaqueña" written on the wall and suddenly realized that i was sitting in the restaurant that SF Weekly named as having one of Sfoodie's 92 best things to eat/drink in San Francisco: The Mexican Hot Chocolate. 

Of course, i finished my delicious tacos and go up to the register to order a Mexican Hot Chocolate. As i was waiting for the waiter to make my delicious drink, he had to suddenly go to the back to pull out a dessert. When i asked him what he was making, he started talking to me about the desserts that they had and handed me a Chocolate Flan. He handed me a spoon and told me to try it. He told me that i could take it home. A few minutes later he handed me 2 cups of Mexican Hot Chocolate. In my confusion, i told him that i only ordered one. His Reaction: This IS one order. Oh my. 
The hot chocolate had SO much flavor; i talked to my boyfriend about it and i tried to describe the taste, but it was indescribable. There was definitely some cinnamon and earthiness to it, but it was also not very sweet, which i really liked.

I called my best friend after this meal and raved about the delicious hot chocolate and the complimentary flan. I will definitely come back to try some of the other yummy dishes at La Oaxaqueña
author: Peggy L.

description: Great tamales! They were huge, cheap, tasty, and full of meat. The mole doesn't have nuts in it, just pumpkin seed, which is great if like me you're allergic to peanuts and tree nuts.
author: Liz H.

description: My friend took me here (which I admit I was kind of skeptical about b/c of the shady area of town).  The food's good, cheap & there's a friendly staff & casual atmosphere.  I was sad there was no burrito bowl option on the menu, but the food was still authentic mexican & very filling.  It might be a little spicy for those that aren't used to it.
author: Chinh T.

description: Best tacos i've ever had. 5$ lunch deals are AMAZING AND WORTH WAY MORE OF ITS PRICE. I ordered 2 carne asada tacos with cheese and sour cream along with rice, beana and a soda. For only 4.95$
author: Sarah Z.

description:
If you have ever been to Oaxaca you know how good the cheese is.  If you haven't had the pleasure you should check out this late night joint in the Mission.  Order the Al Pastor quesedilla with Oaxacan cheese.  This place is a great alternative to El Farlito after the bars close.  Even when it is crowded it is nowhere near as packed as El Farlito and the Al Pastor kicks El Farlito's ass-- chucks of savory pork and pinapple (yep, pinapple) minus the weird grissly bits, drunk hipsters, and insanely loud Latino jams.  Don't get me wrong the grissle, hipsters, and musica is great when you are really wasted. But what if you are only moderately buzzed?  Well then, this is your place.
Last night I rolled in past the bacon wrapped hot dog cart outside (they aim to please) placed my order and sat with some affable strangers at the counter.  We had some pleasant conversation and, out of nowhere, the proprietor whips us up a batch of fresh mexican hot chocolate-- whole milk, foam, the works and sets them down in front of us with just a knod.  After rolling around on another soggy spring night from a Jazz Mafia show to drinks in the Castro then gypysy jazz at Amnesia-- it was the perfect final touch to a great night.
author: Summer T.

description: I love this food!  I used to live in Oaxaca and rarely find such authentic Oaxacan food outside of Southern Mexico.  Thus, we should all really be supporting this rare gem as it is so rare.  Great service and a gracious owner to boot!
author: Sarah N.

description: In need of some late night dinner I called in a take out order to La Oaxaquena Bakery for a verde chicken banana leaf tamale, spicy pork taco, and pupusas. Got there and they had run behind on prepping it, but I decided to pick out some of their baked goods to pack while I waited. Once I'd made my selections and paid for the order the guy behind the counter made me a hot chocolate on the house and gave me a mug which was super given the really weird cold snap in the weather this week. He even gave me a to-go cup of the hot chocolate to take with me once my order was done. Its the little things like that hot chocolate that make me feel like they really appreciate each customer.
author: Marina K.

description:
I stopped in at about 1pm on a week-day to get some take out to take to the laundromat.  
There were no tamales--not made yet.  Only 2 kinds of pupusas available. 
I ended up leaving with only one pupusa--bbq chicken and cheddar for $2.95.    It came with a tiny container of shredded cabbage and a tiny container of hot sauce.   
Half an hour later, after getting the clothes in the washer, I'm sitting in my car, hungry, ready to dig into a delicious pupusa.  
I take a bite--not much flavor--another bite--still nothing...  
I open it up with the plastic fork--there is nothing inside!  No cheese at all.  About 10 lentil sized squares of chicken, spread around.  The cook used perhaps a teaspoon's worth of chicken.  Damn that lazy ass cook!
I wanted to take it back and show them, but I ate it because I was really hungry.  
After the laundry I want back on my way home.  
The woman/waitress recognized me, asked me with a smile how the pupusa was.  She was nice.  Said she would have the same cook make me another.  I declined.  (Makes me uneasy to have someone prepare me food, after I've complained.)  She asked me what I wanted her to do.  Offered to give me my money back.  I took the money.  
I might give the place another try sometime.  The food at the tables looked good.  
The fact that I got take out and discovered the empty pupusa 10 blocks later, is the reason I'm annoyed enough to write this review.   I know it is not fair to judge a place based on one item and a careless (stingy?) cook.
author: Ann M.

description:
I came here with Grace K. recently on a whim while hungrily making our way down mission street and was so very pleasantly surprised.

There are plenty of interesting vegetarian options (not just substituting beans instead of meat) i'm talking goat cheese and sundried tomato papusas, the most delectable mexican hot chocolate i've ever consumed and amaaazing tamales.  

plus, it's fantastically cheap and very generously portioned and the waiter was so freaking friendly and helpful.  it was as if he genuinely enjoyed his job and appreciated our business! 

can't wait to return!
author: Sean R.

description:
pastor taco was dry
pork pupusa was good
author: Christopher L.

description: You cannot have a taco crawl in the city without hitting the stand outside this restaurant.  Fantastico!!!
author: Tim G.

description: This place saved my drunk and hungry butt on NYE at 4 in the morning.  They're usually only open to 2 a.m., but that's no joke in this early-bird city.  The food seemed several cuts above your standard taqueria fare.  I tried it sober the next day, and still agreed with that statement.
author: Napoleon R.

description:
Fabulous!  I haven't had Oaxacan food this lovely since I was in Oaxaca.  This restaurant is in another class from the standard taquerias that we get around here, though you wouldn't know it from the prices.  

We had the chicken mole tamal (in banana leaves) and the tlayuda con cecina (spicy pork).  Our tlayuda was very crispy, and super tasty.  One chicken mole tamal is enough for a meal, and it was just fantastic.  YUM!
author: Emily S.

description:
as it's been stated already, this is hands down the best mole in SF!

my wife and i wanted to try out some other mexican joints in the mission besides our regular spot, la corneta.  i read up about this place and one day we decided to grab and early dinner.  the decor is really nice and very colorful.  the art on the wall is pretty cool but there was some weird videos being played at the time we went.

we were welcomed by the person working behind the counter and he ended up being our waiter.  i got an horchata to start off and it was very good.  they also gave free refills for it!  for our dinner i got the chicken enchiladas and my wife got the bean and cheese burrito.  her burrito didn't come out properly but they took care of it right away.  the chicken enchiladas on the other hand was outstanding.  very flavorful with the right balance of sweet, spicy and savory.  the chicken was cooked very well too.  almost as good as the mole poblano i had at frontera grill in chicago.

they have a few dishes that are authentic oaxacan dishes and can't wait try them out!
author: Swarup B.

description:
I've eaten here twice now. Almost all of their dishes are available with a variety of meats I didn't think you could get around here. Tongue, brain, and locust complement more ordinary things like revueltas and chicken.

The prices are amazing for the quality of food you get. The produce is all very fresh and nothing tastes reheated.

It's not very vegetarian friendly, but there are a number of vegetable-only pupusas available.
author: Joe B.

description:
One of my favorite casual restaurants in the city! Well decorated and cozy, a casual place that you wouldn't feel self-conscious bringing a date to. This is my go-to for brunch, lunch and dinner when I'm around 18th and Mission. 

Some of our favorites include the incredible chicken and mole banana leaf tamale and the ttlayuda with carnitas, which is more large enough to feed three people! 

Always fresh, high-quality, homemade food for very low prices. Also, you can bring in beers from the liquor store next door to enjoy, since they dont have a liquor license.
author: julia k.

description: Excellent.  Chicken Tamale with Mole sauce.  Amazing.  Tasty.  The mole is so good yet subtle...very good.  And we had a bbq chicken and cheddar pupusa.  Wow.  Really yummy.  And cheap.  Highly recommended!
author: Sage S.

description: The most delicious open faced pork taco I have ever eaten.  The south, Nashville, has a few tasty Mexican restaurants, but we are certainly lacking in authenticity topped with nearly half an avocado.
author: Natalie D.

description:
My dad found an article in the paper about this restaurant and since he's a huge fan of mole negro, we went in to try something new.

Reading up on the review, I ordered the Oaxacan hot chocolate which was creamy, frothy and had a delicate taste of cocoa. It was perfect since I dislike the sugary sweetness of the packaged kinds. For lunch, we ordered two tacos (one tongue, the other was tinga de pollo), chicken soup and enchiladas with chicken and mole negro. It was my first time eating a taco with tongue in it but it was delicious and tender. The tinga de pollo was also nicely done, with the chicken being moist and tender. I loved the enchiladas. The mole negro had a nice sweetness to it but the chocolate flavor was not overpowering. I do wish that it was more spicy. 

The only downside to my lunch was the chicken soup. It was overly salty and even though the chicken was tender, it was too salty for me to eat. 

Try the hot chocolate and anything with mole negro!
author: Vanessa T.

description: Excellent banana leaf tamales (with mole filling!) and mexican hot chocolate.
author: Marco L.

description:
okay, ignore my post about how Papalote is my favorite Mexican restaurant in SF. La Oaxaquena is rich, fresh, and delicious. The whole fried fish special was cooked and seasoned perfectly. The guacamole fantastic. The mole negro enchiladas was intimidating, and I can't wait to go back for the tamales.
Service was friendly, not pushy or impatient. Dinner for three big eaters with leftovers was $40.
author: Kely G.

description: My teens wanted to try eating bugs, so we looked up don bugitos and they were sold out of inventory and we'd driven 3 hours to get there. We googled a restaurant that serves insects and found that THIS place was right around the corner and TEN times better. The bug portions are huge, not modest as the photos shown of the other bug eatery.  The bugito place had photos where you get a small serving of insects, but THIS place had HUGE portions of thick, juicy insects. We got grasshopper tacos and I swear to gosh they were amazing. I had two and so did the teens. The grasshopper tacos are around 5 bucks each but worth it. I can't believe I can say this, but the kids were right, bugs are pretty good. I was told that the bugito place is sometimes open, mostly not and that they are usually out of insects by the time you get there. If that happens to you, go around the corner to this place where you will have the surprise of your life! And their other food is authentic and SO tasty.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Gigantic veggie tamale--like three times the size of an average one--in a banana leaf, with collard greens and tofu. Delicious. And the flan is unbelievably decadent and rich...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
wow. hands down, the best tacos i have had in san francisco so far!!! excellent grilled tilapia fish tacos, pupusas, and supposedly amazing banana leaf wrapped chicken mole tamales. i've only had the pupusas and tacos, but seriously-----these are the most amazing tacos! FULL OF FLAVOR (sauteed onions, grilled jalapenos, grilled/sauteed meat or fish of your choice, and guac/cheese if you want.) i didn't even add anything to my tacos and they were amazing. 

they also have a taco stand parked outside in front of the restaurant and they serve food til 2am (but i've actually been there at 2:30/2:45 and they've still been serving food!) and i actually discovered this place when my friends and i went to eat, expecting it to be crappy cheap late night mexican food. 

this isn't your average mexican place with average burritos, and it's not a salvadorean place with basic pupusas, the cuisine here stems from OAXACA, hence the interesting "grasshopper" tacos. they also have a large variety of tamales, and tlayudas (giant toastada from oaxaca) 

some highlights from their menu:

PUPUSAS:
SUNDRIED TOMATO & GOAT CHEESE
BBQ CHICKEN AND CHEDDAR
ZUCCHINI , BASIL PESTO & MOZZARELLA
BROCCOLI & CHEDDAR
QUESO & LOROCO (SALVADORIAN FLOWER)

TACOS:
GRILLED TILAPIA TACO
GRILLED SALMON TACO
GRASSHOPPER TACO

their prices are great, the staff is nice, and it's open late. i find this menu much more desirable than any taqueria in the mission. you can get a burrito here if you want, but it's not their specialty. 

oh, and they take credit/debit cards!
author: katherine m.

description: This place is good. Food was fresh. I had the carne asada tacos the meat was really flavorful. Food was a little pricey but worth it.
author: S M.

description:
Food was very good.  I had the pupusas (three types: BBQ chicken, pork, and vegan lentil).  All were very good.

Service/atmosphere was decent but not great.
author: Mike F.

description: Due to the high recommendation per yelpers, I gave the chicken mole tamale a try but I wasn't too thrilled. I didn't like the mole part. O well.
author: EmmettsGuRL C.

description: Had the chicken meal (forgot the name) ... and sampled the chicken tamale in the banana leaf.  I also loved the "small" guacamole with chips.  Great food, okay prices... pretty good environment... though there were a few folks on the street that came in to ask for money and food.  Portions are generous and filling!
author: Helicon K.

description:
Living in the mission for a long time I had walked past this place so many times and wanted to try it. so, for our 7 year wedding anniversary we finally did! The service was excellent and they have a lot of vegan options. We started with a banana leaf tofu tamale, which was huge and yummy. Then we had a selection of pupusas -- I would recommend the navy bean and pesto -- and my husband had shrimp fajitas. You can BYOB, too. It was all really excellent and the owner even brought me over some soy horchata, when he found out I was vegan, and gave my husband some mole to try. We would definitely go back, and recommend to all!
A great way to spend our anniversary!
author: Jasmine K.

description:
This place deserves every star it gets.

Our waiter was a French gentlemen who spoke fluent Spanish and was very helpful in recommending dishes.  Food was brought out quickly and efficiently.  Prices are not hole-in-the-wall cheap but the portions are generous and the quality of the food is so much better than CanCun's motor oil burritos.

We tried the chicken tamales with mole sauce in banana leaf, chicken with mole sauce, and a chapulines (grasshopper) taco.  The chicken was fall-off-the-bone tender and the mole sauce was delicious.  The tamale was gigantic yet well cooked - the cornmeal was not rubbery but was firm and tasty on its own.  The grasshopper taco required some tortilla coverage to shield it from my wife so as not to gross her out while eating.  It was also flavorful and spicy, with clear chili and lime flavors - the texture was similar to dried shrimp and the taste was similar to pork, but they might be fried in pork fat.  If you do get the grasshopper tacos, make sure to get your own horchata to quench the burn afterwards - neighbors may frown upon you getting grasshopper legs in their beverages even if it is an emergency.  Our waiter even gave us a free slice of cake at the end of the night, which we could barely paw at after stuffing ourselves for $25.  The menu features many items that aren't available at other Mexican restaurants including venison tacos.  I will definitely come back here and eat my way through the rest of the menu.
author: Dave S.

description:
let me start by saying that my guy basically wants to dine here every night :) He loves their tacos. Not only him but all my friends (and father) think that this is as close as it gets to real Mexican street tacos.

I, on the other hand,  am a vegetarian (sometimes vegan). Thus, I cannot credit or discredit this opinion. Yet, I have to say they do look delicious packed with lime wedges, radish slices, cilantro and  chopped onions. I have to confess it does make me want to eat me some tacos. :) I always just end up finishing the radishes off my guy's  plate.

Anyway, for the veggie lovers out there I truly do recommend all their vegetarian tamales. The Oaxacan (cooked in a banana leaf instead of husk) style tamales with tofu, spinach and salsa verde are to die for. I also enjoy the spinach and cheese ones.  there is a third kind but they have tomatoes and I do not like those.

The drinks are great. Specially the horchata.

The place is colorful and fun. It invites to stay and hang out. At least, we always do. 

The staff is very friendly, always joking with us. We like them a lot too.

One thing I have an issue with is the restroom. It could use more cleaning. A lot more cleaning.

The only other thing is to watch out when you get your tamales specially if  you are a strict vegetarian. one time I ordered the Tofu tamal and they gave me a chicken one. Of course, they apologized and gave the chicken tamal free of charge to my mother.  On a different occasion, we ordered one chicken  and one tofu tamal to go and when we arrived home we noticed two tofu tamales. So they get wacky! Watch it! :)

Still I love the place.
author: Stephany K.

description: The chicken  mole tamale makes a wonderful breakfast.  It is huge and is wrapped in this giant banana leaf. 2 can easily share this monster and it is very rich.  The salsas, especially the green, are yum.
author: Bleep S.

description: Christmas talames...YUM.  I chose La Oaxaqena because of all the awesome reviews on the tamales.  We got our (excess) order last night (my husband had no idea they would be HUGE).  They do not disappoint.  My husband just got chicken, some in banana leaves and some in corn husk.  I am slowly eating my tamal in banana leaves; it will FINALLY be done after a third seating (yes, they are that gargantuan).  The masa is firm yet moist and very fresh.  The chicken is tender and white, soaking in the mole and beans (separately, of course) in a wonderful marriage of meat and sauce. This is definitely our new go to place for Christmas tamales!!
author: Joy H.

description:
This is the fourth time I've posted about La Oaxaquena because I still am just crazy about it.  I cannot emphasize enough how nice, friendly, and generous the staff are here.  I wanted to have my birthday party with 11 people here, & they were very accommodating.   Still the best banana leaf tamales with mole sauce.  As long as I live in San Francisco, I'll be a regular here.

Oh, & the taco & hot dog stand in front is great too.
author: Tuesday J.

description: Hadn't had oaxacan food in years and this really hit the spot. I got the Pollo con mole and it ranks among some of the best I have had. Everything that everyone was eating looked great. I will be back.
author: Craig H.

description:
My BF and I happened upon this place last night after a show. It was 11:30 and we were looking for something cheap and good. 
We were tempted by the smell of the bacon-wrapped hot-dog stand outside but wanted some real food so we went in and sat down.
We were super excited by the menu.
I had the veggie tamale which was wrapped in a banana leaf and stuffed with collard greens and soy protein. It was delicious. Creamy, slightly tangy and perfectly balanced flavors. Seriously, I'm still thinking about it this morning. And it was enormous -with a side of beans and rice it filled me up.
BF had the crab enchiladas - just crab meat and salsa verde. Also very tasty. We had bottles of Mexican Squirt made with real sugar instead of HFCS and flan for desert.
They state on the menu that they use no lard and no trans fat.
We left feeling extremely happy and delighted with our find. We went in expecting a basic Mission taqueria and ended up having a really excellent and healthy meal ant a crazy reasonable price.
author: Missy F.

description:
Second visit I had the tlayuda with cecina (spicy pork).  It's like an authentic oaxacan nacho pizza.  No really.  Awesome.

*This is based on 1 visit, but i'll definitely be updating as I intend to go back, alot.  Specials yesterday included Barbacoa a la Plancha (slow cooked mutton sort of refried on the griddle with onions) and ostrich tacos.  I had the barbacoa obviously.  Tender, slightly gamy mutton with a bit of a crust from being cooked the second time on the griddle.  Beans were tasty, fresh homemade tortillas, good salsas.  Loved it.  Excellent addition to the neighborhood.
author: John L.

description:
I've been to La Oaxaqueña a handful of times and I can honestly say I'm a fan.

Of the several items I've tried, I have to say the Torta de Huevo (Egg Sandwich) is my favorite, hands down.

The Torta de Huevo is so delicious.  It has scrambled eggs, refried beans, avocado, salsa, Oaxaca cheese (think string cheese),tomatoes, all this on a toasted telera roll.  You don't even notice that it doesn't have any meat on it. YUM!

Aside from having yummy food, they have delicious Pan Dulce (Mexican sweet bread).  They have the best pan dulce on this side of the Mission.  And cheap, too!  The pan dulce ranges from about $.35 to $1 or so. 

If you haven't tried this place, I recommend you do... You won't be disappointed. :o)
author: Lorena D.

description: Pretty amazing torta. The ambiance is superb, location is absolutely exquisite, and the authenticity is second to none. The new spot to impress your date in The Mission!
author: Haz O.

description: I had a taco with chicken in tequila and it was SPICY. Yum. I recommend the codfish fritters, they have cheese in them, so if you're lactose intolerant watch out. Otherwise, it's even better that most croquetas de bacalao I've had in PR. SO GOOD! Also, the blue quesadilla is very interesting, I believe it has queso fresco on it. Most of what I ate was very good for the most part, but the drinks are a little too sweet. The service is VERY slow so when you come here don't be in any kind of hurry. And yes, it is a little dirty, but I still do like the decor very much, it is an authentic restaurant with very cheap food for what you pay.
author: Gina R.

description: Hot Damn!  This place reminds me of everything that is good and true about the mission district.  It was definitely worth navigating past all the construction noise and crazy people to get to.  Their papusa's are some of the best in the mission and I love the cute little decor.  The menu is unique and a few steps up from your average hole in the wall taqueria.  Where else can you get a sun dried tomato goat cheese papusa?
author: Emily O.

description: One of our favorite taqueria's. The banana-leaf tamales with mole are always delicious. They are also HUGE. If you're vegetarian, the tofu version will please you here. Also really good pupusas. The most unique thing about the place is their spiced, steamed, hot chocolate (you can get it with soy or cow's milk). SO GOOD!!! The people working there are very nice, and we'll keep coming back here again and again.
author: Nirav B.

description: I LOVE this place. Almost everytime I've been in the mission as of late, I've gone to the taco cart outside the restaurant. $2 a taco with everything on it. The owner has these amazing salsas and sauces that he makes...ask him if he's got any other ones behind the counter...usually it's his personal stash but he always lets folks try them out. The orange sauce is absolutely amazing and is comparable to Papalote's crack salsa...but perhaps EVEN BETTER. This is a staple for when I'm in the mission, and I'm so glad I found this place!
author: Lauren S.

description: HOLY MOLE!!!!! Wow yelp you did not disappoint again.  Thank you fellow yelpers this hidden gem in the Mission District hands down best dam chicken mole tamales ever!! I'm a sucker for anything wrapped in a banana leaf. I'm filipino so we use banana leafs alot for our dishes and desserts!!  I also tried a loroco y queso pupusa that was delish as well.  The tamale was so bomb diggity I ate it slowed to savor the flavors and decided to save half for a nice treat the next day lol.  The guy at the counter possibly the owner I'm assuming because he not only took our orders, served us but provided amazing service as if we were eating at his home lol.  At the end of our meal he even asked us if we had a little more time so he can make us some fresh mexican hot chocolate.  Of course we always say yes to freebies.  Wow even on a hot day and a full stomach that Mexican Hot Chocolate was bomb all frothy and just made with love.  La Oaxaquena you won me over I'm a believer and can't wait to stop by next time I'm visiting SF!!!
author: oNEloVE C.

description: Amazing! This place is sooo good. You have to try the mole and the tamales!! Go here :)  Ask for the mexican hot chocolate with chile.
author: Erin A.

description: Yummy, cheap, and friendly. I had the chicken mole with rice and beans. $6.50, filled me up "real nice." I couldn't believe how empty this place was considering the high reviews.
author: Stu M.

description: Tried this place on the fly - actually spun the wheel on Urban Spoon while in the area.  Very friendly, quick, and delicious food.  Some of the best mole sauce around.  We were there for a late lunch with only a couple others there.  Give it a try - well worth it!  Prices were good, too...
author: Dan J.

description: Hot chocolate was heart-warming and the huge tlayuda was very appetizing with generous portions of meat and vegetables. Service is very friendly, though the establishment was quite a pigsty. The place needs to be tidied up as some tables weren't wiped, a few chairs were toppled, and the floor was unswept.
author: Jeffrey C.

description: I love mole. My favorite dish at one of my favorite restaurants (Los Barrios in San Antonio, TX) is mole chicken enchiladas. I am always on the hunt for mole. I've had some downright awful mole. I find it hard to find quality mole. Friend recommended this place to me after we found that we both love mole. Went there a couple days later and got the enchiladas and was very please. Not the best, but if it's good, then it's quite a find. I'd like to try the rest of the menu so I will be returning. I only wish they had cerveza, but you can get it next door and bring it in.
author: Wes K.

description: Friendly staff, delicious food, open late.  All of the meats I've had there have been good, but the cabeza stands out as incredible.  Also has by far the best mexican hot chocolate I've ever tasted.
author: Daniel S.

description: This place has my favorite veggie burrito, and I've had probably over 20 different kinds. The slice of tres leches  that I got, which they gave to me for free with my take out order, was borderline soggy, but still very good. It seems like it's hit or miss though. The service has always been great for me.
author: Elle A.

description: Amazing food and great service. The owner (I think it's the owner) he was really cool and gave us a few samples of drinks that he personally made. He talked to us and made us feel welcomed. The food is outstanding. Great authentic Latin food, not like Chevy's. Definitely a must-stop place.
author: Andre J.

description: Why oh why does this place have an average of 4 stars?  I just don't get it.  I don't know if it has a new owner now or new staff or what, but my experience is NOTHING close to 4 stars!!!  So, a friend bought a Groupon from here based on the 4 star reviews and a group of 5 of us thought we'd give it a try.  The food was AWFUL!  One guy ordered venison (not my first choice at any restaurant but if it's on the menu it should be good enough to serve, no?) and it was like leather.  It was painful to watch him try to chew it.  We ordered quite a bit of food because we were hungry and it took forever to come out.  Even worse, most of us were finished eating (what we could manage to eat) before one of us even got their burrito!  And I haven't even mentioned the rat yet!  There was a rat that kept running around in the ceiling rafters.  Eek! Me definitely thinks not!  Do NOT buy a Groupon.  Do NOT even think about eating here.  Your life will be much better off.
author: Laura L.

description:
new favorite in the mission, tied with torta gorda (puebla-style sandwich place) on 24th (see that review as well).

in general: this place has the best of both worlds: cheap and authentic, but classy and foody.  the ghetto coffee-shop format/decor keeps prices down: not a "date restaurant," so if you're one of those bourgeous yelp douchebags, don't bother reviewing this place, it's a sandwich place, not a hotel lobby.  the menu is AMAZING, full of oaxacan specialties and obscurities with some standards in for good measure.

specialties and obscurities:

 - If you love nachos and tostadas, you'll flip your shit when you meet their pre-colombian granddaddy, the *Tlayuda*. this is the only place i've seen in SF that sells these.  the refried beans are nice and dry/pasty, there's good oaxacan cheese (see below), and plentiful servings of their excellent meat toppings (see below). maybe a tad pricey but obviously meant for splitting/family style eating: 12 meat/10 veg.

 - *Chapulines*: grasshoppers roasted in chili and lime were a precolombian delicacy and still a common streetfood in Oaxaca.  get 'em here before the sanitation department realizes they're selling them!

 - Good *cheeses*.  In Mexico, Oaxaca is famous for good fresh (quesillo) and dry (oaxacan) cheeses.  Both are good here.

 - Great *tortas*, including the mysteriously-rare egg torta (common in mexico, rare here) which is thankfully $3 cheaper than the meat ones, and weekly specials like venado (venison!!!!) and avestruz (ostrich) from local boutiquey sources. a tad pricey and small, but the quality justifies it hands down!

 - Tamales! Their masa (and their black mole, while we're at it) are much more suited to the Southern-style banana-leaf tamal Oaxaca is known for than the corn-husk ones: make sure to specify.

 - Rare forms of meat!!! Chicken tingas (pulled like ropa vieja and slow-stewed in slow-burning red-chili!), mole, pibil (southern/Mayan blood-orange/annatto-seed stew), and even some stuff I've never heard of (who knew you could make Tingas out of salmon? i'm afraid to order it, someone else will have to weigh in).

 - Classy beverages all around: not-too-sweet tamarindo, cans of pellegrino aranciata, achampurado, free ice water, etc etc

Go!

***Glossary:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tlayuda
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chapulines
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quesillo
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torta
author: throw a.

description: What a sweet little joint!  I had a great salmon taco, my husband had their lauded banana leaf tamale (huge size), which was wonderful, and a single order of hot chocolate would be enough for a table of 4. With the cheery bright orange walls, and the gracious, friendly service, you can't help but feel fantastic. And along with the bill, they gave us a complimentary piece of delicious moist cake packaged for the road. The waitress and owner made us feel like we were longtime customers, though it was our very first time. These are the kinds of gestures that win a loyal following-- which can be said about our friend who recommended the place to us. He goes almost every day for a tamale.
author: Kali D.

description: Stuck between 3 stars and 4. 4 for the homey-friendly feel, but 3 on the food. The pastries are what you would expect for 50 cents each. The tamale is nothing special. The black bean and cheddar pupusa: dry. But still, I would go back.
author: Mehul P.

description: Yummy and super sweet people. Was given a piece of cake and a lovely birthday serenade at 2:30 am :D
author: sarah k.

description: This is quickly becoming our new favorite Mexican restaurant. My boyfriend and I love ordering their breakfast burrito! The size is so huge, it serves as two meals. We really like their guacamole, the service is quick, seating has never been an issue, and the prices are excellent! Their bakery department isn't great though, otherwise I would have given 5 stars.
author: Debbie S.

description: Ate here for the first time tonight and was impressed.  First of all, the restaurant decor is great - lots of color everywhere and lots of fun stuff on the walls.  For food, I had a pupusa and a tamale (with chicken and mole sauce).  Delicious!  And the tamale was the biggest I'd ever seen, it was really all I needed.  I don't think we'll make the mistake of ordering chips before dinner again (although they were fresh and the salsa tasty).  Friendly, efficient service.  The only thing that didn't do much for me was the lemonade.  Maybe I'm wrong but it tasted like it was from a powder.  Won't order that again but I'll definitely be back for the food.  Not your run of the mill Mexican restaurant.
author: Cindi L.

description:
came for their version of chilaquiles verde (tortilla chips with egg, beans, etc.) but more like an omelet, but best to go to Pastores now
very reasonable prices
known for oaxacan, i.e. mole
nice tamale but was out of banana leaf
author: Rob C.

description:
Don't come here expecting good service (they didn't even wipe down the table), but the food will wow your tastebuds. I had literally the best tamale I have ever experienced (banana leaf wrapped turkey w/ mole... the masa was so moist and delicious I couldn't get enough!!)

My friend and I were feeling adventurous, and ordered the chipolines (fried grasshoppers with chile and lime) which were kinda freaky but good, if not a bit salty. I tried to order them previously but they were out of season. Other unusual things they have on the menu are fried tarantula(!), and ostrich and venison tacos.


We had a big bowl of guac, which was pretty good. Though the multi-colored chips kinda freaked me out ( Sure, blue corn, red beets, maybe green spinach, but the vibrant grassy green... how can that be natural??)

They also have quite an extensive selection of pupusa fillings (tomato and goat cheese, black bean and cheddar), which were pretty good, though my favorite for that is El Majahual (which also has much better fixins like cortido and salsa)
author: David L.

description: Best mole thus far in SF. I still miss Guelaguetza in LA, but the tamales here are darn good.
author: Erin W.

description: Mole egro enchiladas. Awesome. I love mole negro and this is an excellent rendition.
author: Stephen W.

description: Food here was delicious and fresh. The owner/host was really gracious and nice to us. A word to the wise, at other Mexican joints, a tamale is something I might get as an appetizer when I'm really hungry. DO NOT DO THIS HERE. The tamale here might be an appetizer if you split it with a party of 6! The burritos are even bigger! Great food though and tastes great as leftovers.
author: Aimal M.

description: Sadly went on Friday Sept 18 and it appears to have closed.
author: Deborah W.

description:
We went to this place and the service was slow. There was no complimentary chips and salsa (tho I'm not sure if that's standard at this place). 
We split the Giant Tostada and a chocolate milkshake. The milkshake was excellent. The Giant Tostada was disappointing. The meat was unflavored and fatty, and the shell was very hard and burnt in some places. The guacomole was decent though. And to be fair, it is giant. 

We were clearly done with our food and waiters were sitting at the counter. What aggravated me most was the waiter assumed we did not want change back. He did not ask, and we did not say "keep the change." As a result we spent an extra 15 minutes waiting for our change. 

Maybe we just ordered the wrong thing, food wise? But the service could have been more prompt.
author: Sara N.

description: This place was amazing!  Definitely one of the best authentic mexican places in the city.  Their Oaxacan Mole sauce was delicious!  Sweet and flavorful, with a hint of spice at the end.  The Chicken Tamale with mole sauce and wrapped in a banana leaf was my favorite.  They don't serve alcohol, but you can bring your own beer and drink it there (or run next door to the liquor store like I did and get yourself a big Corona).  I will definitely be coming back here on a regular basis and bringing all of my friends.
author: Jen F.

description: Their quesadillas are the BOMB!!!!!  Lots of chicken with cheese inside. Love the Bright Orange walls and display of color.
author: Diana C.

description: Yes. I love this place. It is cheap, reasonably quick and f***ing delicious. I have been to this place 4 times by my count.  I love their guacamole and chips to start. A small one is perfect for 2-3 people. My most recent visit was last week. I was craving some authentic Mexican. I ordered two tacos, with the special Oaxaquena cheese. Tequila chicken and carne. Mmmmmmmmmmm. It was extremely satisfying. The only problem I had was, in my haste and my hunger, I ate one of the whole peppers they serve on side with the grilled onions. There were tears and some regret. Fortunately, the tacos were there to comfort.
author: Natalie D.

description: This place is rocking my socks. Mexican hot chocolate and mole tamales are divine. Don't tell anyone though because it's tiny and I don't want to have to wait in line to go to dinner there.
author: Sarah T.

description: The mole negro is no joke! All that I can really say. Smokey and a lot more spicy than the red mole that I have usually had in So California, it really was intoxicating. (to steal a phrase from a fellow yelper)  The actual "restaurant" was more like a taqueria, small and unassuming, so I wouldn't go here for ambiance. The food was fantastic. I look forward to trying some of the other items on the menu. Definitely worth ducking a few crackheads on the way from the BART station.
author: David M.

description:
great variety of meats.
and vegan options too.

I'm kinda a burrito guy, but i get these tamales.
biggest tamales i've ever seen, 
wrapped in banana leaves   $4
get it!!!

Try the liquados, if yer feeling spendy.
Aquas Frescas are only $1.50
Taco's   $2.50

corn husk tamale is $2 er somthing
author: Asa D.

description: Woohoo! As good as it gets...really.  I've been to Oaxaca twice and the food here really captures the essence of their food.  They provide a number of great options from Tlayudas to Chapulines to Venison at an awesome price.  As a matter of fact, I think they could charge a tad bit more for their food given it's the City and all.  Nonetheless, I found them to be kind and helpful.  It can get busy and service can get spotty, but this place should not be judged for it's service, Food reigns here.  The tamales de pollo de mole are outstanding and huge!
author: Adrian N.

description: Five stars for the banana leaf tamale of mole and chicken, with a side of rice and beans.
author: Gregory D.

description: SO impressed with this place.  We were headed to Cafe Prague abt amonth ago for lunch and they were closed that day for some reason, and we'd parked so we went into this place.   Spektacular food - great prices.  Black Mole - no more questions asked.  Chicken enchiladas - but my hands down fave is the chicken tamales in plantain leaves &3.75 r u f*in kiddin me?  They are moister than a normal tamale, and they store fantastically, so we stock up and keep them in the frige, still perfect 3-4 days later.  Another fave is the chicken pibil fajitas (I've only had pork).  We go back at least once a week or so.
author: Enzo L.

description: Finally had a chance to try the mole enchilada. It took me a while to get used to the strong mole taste but once i'm used to it, it was heavenly. The jamaica drink was watered down.
author: M Y.

description: The food here was pretty good - I got the mole enchiladas and my boyfriend tried the three pupusa combo (the goat cheese and sundried tomato one was particularly good.)  I enjoyed my experience here but I did think the portions were very small and the prices a little too high -- enough to warrant knocking off a few stars.  I would have left happier if the portions were more in line with the price.
author: Gillian B.

description: The owner is super sweet.  He even let me try some of the dried crickets (interesting).  The food is damn good.  I had a chicken curry tamale that was the size of my face for $3.  The tacos are really good too (cabeza, etc etc), and they sell it on the street for the drunkards that walk by.
author: evan t.

description: I went to La Oaxaqueña Panaderia y Restaurante yesterday. It is a hidden gem. I got the tacos tinga de pollo and they were so good. The beans and rice I ordered were great and did not seem heavy and lardy in any way. The prices are low and the service is just fine for me. I would recommend this place if you want some authentic food from the Oaxaca region of Mexico.
author: Martin H.

description: This place just opened a month ago and they are right across from my work. I have been there now about 10 times and cannot get enough of this place. There tamales with pollo y mole is amazing. Actually , all of their tamales are great. They use the stringy cheese from Oaxaca in several of their items making everything even better. And the tortas. I thought that Farlolito and Los Picudos did the best tortas. Not any more! La Oaxaqueña puts their meat on fresh baked bread with all of the fixins. The guys that work there are super sweet and if you are nice, they might give you a tres leches hook up.
author: L A.

description: the mole' sauce is to die for. Meaning I would literally jump in front of a bullet to save the chef who makes the mole' sauce. I always thought red mole' sauce was good but THIS stuff, this stuff you could put on just about anything and it tastes fantastic. Not to mention tamales wrapped in a banana leaf. I realize now that corn husks are for suckers. To think of all the red mole' and corn husk tamales I've eaten. SO many wasted meals. -_- Go here, have a banana leaf tamale with brown mole' and have your life changed for the better.
author: Dave B.

description: 6 stars for the amazing hot chocolate especially the SPICY - gigantinormous portions. Service can be a little nonresponsive, but they are also really friendly and they may throw in a free dessert if it's slow. Pupusas are good, but the real reason to come here is the hot chocolate.
author: Ara S.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place, although I don't get to eat here as often as I'd like. The portions are enormous and the prices are dirt cheap. I've always come here with a group of friends (which makes a good place even better) and we've managed to feed a couple of hungry folks for what feels like less than a round-trip BART ride home!
The tamales (vegetarian), whether corn-husked or in banana-leafs, are a steal--really, they're enough to feed two hungry people, and could sell for 3x as much at some "upscale" spot. My meat-eating friends get the fajita plate and leave satisfied. I'd skip the pupusas. 
Although temping as they may sound (feta & sun-dried tomato, f'r instance) there's better to be had elsewhere. 
The waitstaff and folks who run this place are super-friendly. Last time I visited they gave my party a slice of tres leches cake. How cool is that? 
Sit by the windows for the best Mission st. people watching experience.
author: alejandro p.

description: I love delicious hole-in-the-wall places...I've been here the last two times I've made it out to the mission and now I want to eat there every week. The mole enchiladas are perfectly spicy with amazing cheese. The torta was really delicious but just a bit dry (like a tablespoon more beans and it would've been perfect). My brother ordered 3 different kinds of soft tacos with various delicious exotic meats.  They also feature great Mexican sodas (including coke in a bottle with no high fructose corn syrup). The staff is no nonsense and quick to offer suggestions about the menu. I want to go to there.
author: Lauren T.

description: La Oaxaquena is my favorite, hands down. Whenever I am in the Mission and am lucky enough to catch them open, there is no way possible I can resist stopping in. The Mexican hot chocolate is the best, but you know that already. Have you heard about the mole? No?! Get it drenched on EVERYTHING for just a little extra $, I swear, you'll fall in love. Great salsa and guacamole. Amazing banana leaf tamales. Gargantuan burritos with tons of tasty, sure-to-please options for filling them to maximum capacity. Satisfying papusas (try the Salvodorian flower, it's great!) There's no alcohol here but it seems to be the norm to just brown-bag beers from the liquor store next door. It can get super busy here late nights on the weekends and you can expect to wait awhile when it's like that but it's always worth the wait, just be patient! Their desserts are delicious, too. Ask anyone I know, I can't stop talking about La Oaxaquena!
author: Tessa M.

description: Being from Chicago where there are a million taqueria's that taste the same, I was looking forward to trying this deliciousness. It didn't disappoint. The mole enchilada's were perfect, best mole i've ever had. The fresh lemonade with mango was a perfect compliment.
author: Seth M.

description:
if you order the chicken mole tamale, make sure to order the one in a banana leaf (it also comes in the corn husk).  The one in a corn husk is still pretty good, but the chicken mole in banana leaf is PERFECTION - silky, delicious masa with perfectly spiced, tender chicken mole. yum.

yelp says this place closes at 10, but me and 8 friends rolled in at 10 on a friday night and they didn't have any problems serving us or dealing with our multiple rounds of orders. super sweet waitstaff!
author: Leona K.

description:
Yummy!  Best Mexican food I have had in a while.  Friendly staff and reasonable prices.  The mole sauce is one of the best that I have had.
Looking forward to trying many of the dishes.
author: c c.

description: On my first, and so far only, visit to La Oaxaqueña, I ordered a chicken mole tamale in a banana leaf and a tinga de pollo taco. Both were delicious, although I slightly preferred the taco to the tamale. The tinga de pollo was fantabulous, properly flavored, juicy, just perfect with some friend onions and jalapeno and radish on top. The mole sauce was mmm, although I was a bit distracted by the tamale's oiliness. I ordered slices of tres leches cake and flan to go, and both were good, if not great. Next time, I want to try to famed tlayuda. I salivate just thinking about it.
author: Tara M.

description: The people here are very nice and the food is very good. The fish taco is delicious -- the meat is so tender and the sauce so spicy and perfect. I had this drink that I don't remember what it was called but it was warm, thick and beautiful (it wasn't hot chocolate, it was more cinnamon-y and thick).
author: Shizuka L.

description: the mole was good, but we ordered fish with ginger.  No ginger in the dish, just a heavy cream sauce.  Probably a good place if you know what to order. Certainly an interesting menu.
author: Ann S.

description:
I think I'm in love....
I ordered a large tres leches cake at 9am Saturday and their baker had it ready for me by 1p.  I don't know if the baker had to go out of his way but it was a lot of work at the last minute.   When I went to pick up the cake I decided to have lunch while I was there. This is when I became smitten..sigh...The staff are so nice and it is clearly a family business as the staff's kids, wives, and friends dropped in and out. I always love this sort of atmosphere. BUT, the food, I had a Tlayuda - sooo good. It is a large tosada, sort of , with a large very crunchy base...not exactly a tortilla or a crust. Then the server poured me a cup of hot chocolate to try, for free, cause they are so hospitable, and I nearly cried..I think I met Jesus..what more can I say? 
oh, they open early and close late - 6am to 2am I think.
They do have choices for vegetarians like pupusas with loroco or just cheese. I don't know if the beans are actually vegetarian but they are delicious so just eat them and don't think about it damit, you are in their house!
author: Jessica D.

description: I love this place. The tamales wrapped in banana leaves are delicious, both the mole and chile verde versions.  They also import some fantastic oaxacan cheese (quesillo) from Oaxaca.  It's pricy ($15 for a ball of cheese), but it's worth and is great for anything from quesadillas, sandwiches or even pizza.
author: Anthony C.

description: Tamales Rajas. I think that's what they're called. HOT. Delicious. And I can get them til like 3AM. That's pretty much all i've gotten here. but gosh they hit the spot.
author: Alan N.

description: In brief: I had the chicken dinner dish slathered with mole and I shared a small guacamole bowl with 3 others. It was absolutely fantastic and I couldn't be any happier with my meal. The service was quality. I'm looking forward to my next trip to this establishment.
author: Brian G.

description: My new local favorite - adorable little café that serves OUTSTANDING food. The decor is bright, thoughtful and warm, and the service is attentive and friendly. I had the day's special - a turkey and mole tamale cooked in a banana leaf, and the portion is huge, a meal in of itself. The flavors and textures were incredible - warm, savory, rich, fresh. The horchata was thirst-quenching - not too sweet, and not full of ice like other places. Can't wait to take friends!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I was torn to give this place either 3 or 4 stars.  Here is why:

I absolutely love the guacamole dip.  I would totally come back just for that and the small comes in a big bowl that was more than enough for 2 people.  It has a slight spicy kick that makes it so tasty.  Their tamales are also so good.  They are hot and flavorful.  

I was really disappointed in their tacos.  It was very dry and all it had was meat on tortilla.  Their chicken mole was good if you like mole, but I think I am not so much of a fan of it, so it was interesting at best.  The chicken meat was very soft and it fell off the bone though.  As for the other items I tried, they were alright, but not memorable.

I decided to give it 4 stars instead of 3, because:
1)  The place is super cheap and you get a lot of food.
2)  The guacamole is just too awesome to miss.
3)  I have been there twice and the waiter gave me a complementary cake.
4)  They are really nice and friendly.

Now I have to try their bakery.  I heard it was pretty good...
author: A W.

description:
Wonderful service and really delicious food. It's priced slightly higher than I expected; most dishes hovered between the $9-13 range. I had the chicken enchiladas with mole--the dish came highly recommended. The mole was lovely; a normally complex recipe, the sauce really showcased the depth of ingredients and incorporated a number of flavors, plus just the right amount of spice. The guacamole is delicious and worth mentioning. My friend had the spinach and cheese tamale--also outstanding! I think her fish taco was a bit spicy, but she seemed to enjoy it. 

Our waiter was beyond enthusiastic and so excited to hear it was our first visit to their restaurant! He was a lively conversationalist and even brought us a delicious slice of mango and pineapple cake, on the house (the restaurant doubles up as a bakery and they had just brought in several trays full of nom nom looking baked goods...must go back to try those...).
author: Ashlee T.

description: They have amazing tamales, and even vegetarian ones!  Hot chocolate is great!  Pupusas are also really really good.  I have nothing bad to say about this place.
author: Aristophelius M.

description: wow - a friend of mine brought me here and I was very impressed. Ordered a good variety of foods - spicy pork sopa, carne asada and pork taco, mole and chicken tamale steamed in banana leaf. Everything had great flavor, nice and spicy like I love food, and best of all the total bill for the two of us was only $23!! Definitely recommend it, but I'm scared that others will find this little gem. The space has a great feel to it - very clean and the owner was very nice and explained the makings of the mole dips.. mmmm
author: Sung P.

description: I had the chance to stop by after a long day of walking at this great mexican decor restaurant to try their pastries and traditional chocolate beverage made in the premises, champurrado. Outside, in the streets of San Francisco the temperature was close to 40F but inside the La Oaxaquena with the warm service and attention from Harry (the owner) my body felt like at Oaxaca. I am in Mexico here and I will definitely come back. Cheers
author: Alex T.

description:
It's hard to be critical of the few places around open till 2am.  But, here goes:

I strolled by at 1am, and ordered grasshopper and venison tacos grande ($5 each), and 3 pupusas ($7): loroco & queso, goat cheese & sun dried tomato, and something that begins with "r" (regurjatado?)  The venison taco was generously filled with juicy, lightly charred chunks of meat.  Grasshoppers must be the new crunchy gold though, cuz they were in short supply.  They must have been soaked in chili oil too, as they tasted dull and spicy.

The goat cheese pupusa conquered with its contrasting sweet/tart flavor.  Loroco & cheese was almost as pedestrian as the "r" pupusa, which vanished from memory.

Somehow, the food took ~15 minutes to come out.  That blew, due to the negative ambiance, but was still totally worthwhile given the hour and quality.
author: dark l.

description: This place is tremendous I honestly can't stop thinking about it! I tried the massive chicken tamale, sopes and guacamole. Portions are big and inexpensive- it is also byob!! Friendly and fast service. I also enjoyed the Mexican art and colorful decor
author: Dylan M.

description: The al pastor tacos - spicy and served with the traditional pineapple pieces a lot of places skimp on here - mean I'll be coming back, but I was under-impressed by the mole tamal which is supposed to be their specialty. Staff are very friendly and the owner comped us a piece of cake which we enjoyed even though we were stuffed to the gills. Would like to try some of their pastries and the flan de cafe too. I give La Oaxaquena one thumb up until we can try more of the menu.
author: Aimee G.

description: Slow and horrible service. Waitress screwed up my order twice. Then they tried to convince me Horchata is the same as Mexican hot chocolate.
author: Barbarella B.

description: Tried La Oaxaquena this past Sunday with some friends. I walked by this place often, but never really thought of going in, but am really glad I went this time. The place has a very casual, basic atmosphere. Don't come if you want fancy ambiance, but for most places in the Mission, you go for the food not for the prettiness of the place. Anyway, on to the food. I ordered a chicken tamale w/mole in a banana leaf and a large taco with chorizo. By the prices, I assumed that the dishes would be really small--I was wrong. The tamale itself was enough to fill my ever-hungry belly and the mole was delicious! The chorizo taco was so-so-good but nothing out of this world. My friend ordered a mexican hot chocolate which was missing the chile and cinnamon, but still very good and not overly sweet. I will definitely be making this place a regular go-to.
author: S A.

description: My new favorite lunch spot! Tamale con mole sooo good. I'm going back tomorrow. I feel like I need to eat though the whole menu
author: Jennifer B.

description:
mmmmm ... sopes!  three with huevos a la dry scambled ... i think that three is enough for two but i didn't know that before i ordered.  these sopes were crisp where they were supposed to be, doughy elsewhere and laden with deliciousness.
the guys here the other afternoon were VERY cool, asking over and over if the food was to our liking, which it was and of which i assured them. the panaderia selections were really good for almost 5 in the afternoon and who doesn't love using the tongs and what amounts to an aluminum pizza pan for self-serve cookie and pastry selection.
author: Kevin M.

description: On our last night of drunken wandering around SF, Mike and I yelped a Mexican spot in the Mission district, and after getting lost a lot, we finally found it. It seemed really authentic - lots of Mexican people eating and in our stupor, we were initially confused on if we sit down and get served or if we go up to them and order. I got a chicken mole tamale wrapped in banana leaf and Mike ordered the tlayuda with spicy pork. When the food came out, I couldn't believe how big everything was. I had never had such a huge tamale- the mole was really good too! The tlayuda was impressive also-almost like a Mexican pizza. Mike really liked the spicy pork and at the time, this was the ultimate food for the drunks. A homeless woman came in while we were eating and was asking Joe (the owner?) for food. After giving her some tortilla chips, Joe eventually kicked her out when she started asking for cheesecake. Cheesecake - wtf??
author: Mel C.

description: Great food and, as everyone else has said, the owner is the nicest guy ever.  Always trying to hook up a free dessert.  Whenever we ask him what we should order he recos the whole fried fish. Haven't taken the plunge yet but something tells me it's good.
author: Peter R.

description: *Excellent* Oaxacan cooking.  Enjoyed a wonderful tamale, a tlayuda with spicy pork, and assorted tacos.  All 3 dishes were fabulous.  The mole was wonderful- smoky and full of depth, not too sweet.  The tacos were sublime (definitely the best I have had in the city)  and the tlayuda was fantastic. As people said, sort of like a Mexican pizza / nacho thing. Yummy.  Almost as good as being in Mexico, except for all the hipsters passing by.  Highly recommended.  Also, no alcohol is served. Fair warning for the lush inside of each of us.  Quick, come here while you can still snag a table.
author: Tristan C.

description:
if i could give this place 6 stars, i would. this is THE BEST mexican food i have had in san francisco, and it is the best value, too! the guacamole is the best guacamole i have had at a restaurant, and they bring you a bucket of it for $6.95. the four of us gobbling it up couldn't even finish half of it!
there are so many vegetarian papusas and tamales and other dishes to choose from, and they have unique, delicious vegetarian options like the sundried tomato and goat cheese papusa! yum yum yum! don't be fooled by the low prices, they don't mean that the portions are small! we ordered 2-3 items each and were brought out plates so large that they were almost a joke!
the neighborhood and the bright lighting almost scared me away, but i will keep coming back! the owner is also very very friendly, my friends from new york couldn't believe this place, they loved it so much and couldn't believe how cheap it was- they took a picture of the receipt and then took a picture with the owner!

i love you la oaxaqueña!!!
author: Renee L.

description: my boyfriend and i just wandered in here while looking for pupusas. it looked like your average mission hole-in-the-wall restaurant, but the food was amazing! great flavors in everything we had we had (3 different pupusas and a tamale). there are things on that menu you just can't seem to get other places. the prices are very reasonable as well. :)
author: Ashley A.

description:
I personally had no idea what a tlayuda was.  I've been to a significant amount of the twelve-thousand taquerias in the Mission and had somehow never come across one.  For the uninitiated, imagine a nacho covered with tasty meat, cheese, etc.  Now take that imaginary nacho and stretch it to the size of a pizza. Literally.

Yeah.  That's a tlayuda.  And they are amazing at La Oaxaquena.  Also try the carne asada tortas (awesome), the guacamole (awesome and served in a stone...dish...thing...) and the banana-leaf tamales.  All top-notch.

The service is very friendly and inevitably slow,  but not in a 'let me speak to your manager' way, rather an 'adorable corner restaurant where you shouldn't be in a hurry for your food anyway' sort of way.

Oh, and their spicy hot chocolate will change your life.
author: Trevor G.

description: meh.  had a carne asada super burrito and beef fajita.  nothing really to write home about -- or on yelp.
author: H. L.

description:
Despite the dicey location, bright fluorescent lighting, and general (lack of) ambiance, the food and staff at this place are amazing! 

I celebrated my birthday there on a Saturday night with seven friends.  The very nice owner reserved a table for us (I had called in advance), and we ate great food.  The pollo verde tamale, wrapped in plantain leaves was delectable--slightly spicy, tender, juicy . . . . It was one of the best meals I have ever eaten anywhere, including in my travels in Europe, Central and South America, etc.  It was perfectly succulent and tasty and more than I could eat.  The guacamole came in two gigantic mole mortars, which were overflowing with mouth-watering fresh guacamole.  

To top it off, when the waiter (owner?) found out my husband didn't bring a birthday cake, he asked the cook to make us one on the spot.  After dinner out came a beautiful cake decorated with fresh papaya and mango and the most melt-in-your mouth creamy frosting I've ever tasted.  My friends said it tasted great, and it sure looked rich and delicious.  I have celiac (gluten intolerance) so had to be satisfied with a rich slice of dulce de leche.  Delicious!

Speaking of celiac, if you too are gluten intolerant, there is plenty to choose from on the menu but avoid the mole, as they put a little flour in it.

Also, the restaurant does not have serve alcohol, but you are welcome to bring your own, and there is a liquor store right next door.

Amazingly, the tab for all 8 of us, for more food than we could eat, was $80.  They didn't even charge for that incredible cake.

These people are so nice, and the food they serve is outstanding.  Go, eat, enjoy, before they figure out that they should triple their prices.  :)
author: Lisa P.

description: Love this place. It's a hole in the wall--limited seating--but very good mole. The Mexican hot chocolate is worth a visit on a rainy, cold day. Sit there and indulge in some of the add ins they have for it! The man who owns the place is super nice and very helpful. If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd be gaining weight simply by coming over and over again!
author: m. S.

description: Fantastic tacos for $3 each: cocoanut chicken, esp. good.  Open late and full of partiers late, but very mellow afternoon and evening hours, no problem just strolling in and getting a seat.
author: Gene T.

description: this place is delicious.  homemade tortillas, good ingredients, authentic menu, great prices and pleasant simple service.  i love this place!
author: shirin a.

description: Deliciously different from the traditional Mexican food. The enchiladas in banana leaves are to-die-for. This hole-in-the-wall place is worth seeking out!
author: Jordan H.

description: I was from out of town visiting San Francisco.  My friend recommended this place.  We ordered a rice drink which was good.  We were also given a complimentary mexican pizza. This was also very good.  We ordered grasshopper tacos, chicken tamale and spicy pork tacos.  The grasshopper taco was the best thing we had by a mile.  They were flavorful and well cooked.  I was very displeased with the tamale and spicy pork tacos.  The tamale was dry and not moist.  Not too much flavor at all.  The spicy pork tacos were bland and the pork was overcooked.  I was expecting good mexican  but the tacos in the east coast are definitely better.  The place has good variety of meats.  The exotic meats such as grasshopper, ostrich, and others seem to be the better items.
author: Sanjib S.

description: tacos are amazing here and it's open late. strictly better than taqueria cancun.
author: R E.

description: This is the real deal! You cannot get better mole negro anywhere else in the city! They use the real stuff from Chocolate Mayordomo from Oaxaca. They even sell the bars! OH BLISS! I lived in Oaxaca, Mexico for an entire winter and dined and all things Oaxacan. They have their own unique blend of spices and sauces that's distinctively Oaxacan, not just Mexican. You MUST try the Mole Negro con Pollo. It's basically a whole chicken leg and thigh simmered in thick delicious chocolate mole sauce for hours! And not sweet chocolate mole. It's very tasty and superb! It's nothing you've ever had in your life! Don't be shy! It's an amazing combination! One plate of Mole Negro con Pollo is going to fill you up! Share it with a friend. Their tamale is the bomb too! HUGE! They make it in big flat servings. HUGE! Again, share it with a friend. The prices are awesome for what you're getting: authentic honest-to-Mayan-gods-so-good Oaxacan food! Their mole negro beats Colibri by the whole 9 yards. The tres leche was standard. Nothing to go whooza about. But their flan! GOODNESS GRACIOUS! Their flan is a thing of perfection! SOOOO GOOOD! And they have authentic Oaxacan cheese strips too! GO GO GO!
author: Pamela L.

description: Excellent, fresh food (but should be if they dare call themselves la oaxaquena).  Some sauces can be a little spicy if you are sensitive, but if you can handle a tingly tongue, the rewards are great.  The spices are melded perfectly so that the heat is definitely not overpowering.
author: sweaterhead x.

description: The owner has recently updated his menu with some of the specials he and his cooks have been trying out. Especially noteworthy is the tilapia in ginger coconut sauce. Unexpected and delicious!
author: Joe S.

description: I thought the hot chocolate was terrible. It tasted like watered down Swiss Miss. Do you have to order a Mexican hot chocolate specifically, instead of just hot chocolate?
author: Hank D.

description: My girlfriend and I found out about La Oaxaqueña from Yelp and stopped by before a show. We were really impressed. We had the guacamole appetiser with chips to start out. It came with tortilla chips that were yellow, red and black. It was tasty and a large quantity. We got some pupusas and a chicken tamale in a banana leaf. To drink we had horchata and limonada. The tamale was terrific and the whole bill was a mere 19 dollars. We also had leftovers and another meal.
author: James K.

description: Mole is to die for! Everything is good. The staff is friendly and the cake guy is justifiably proud of his creations--he'll show you his portfolio.
author: John L.

description:
4.5 Stars - OAXACAN HOT CHOCOLATE - if you love chocolate and cinnamon you will drool over this tasty hot chocolate. I seriously was brought to memories of the best hot chocolate I've ever had in a Chocolate Bar - wow! Of course this isn't the sole reason to go here - cheap food with great service - I mean these guys smile all day. No joke - they don't rush you out or stare you down - they enjoy your company. I will definitely be back for some tacos and tamales, but this time around we had the tlayudas and the chicken mole. Chicken mole was fantastic - perfectly tasty smoky flavor and really nice stewed chicken falling off the bone. Rice and beans were of course delicious. Wish we had more spicy salsa at the table, but not a big deal. I unfortunately wasn't as big of a fan of the tlayudas as others - was something wrong with mine? The thing holding it all together tasted very stale? O_o I figured it needed to be somewhat to hold the yummy toppings - got the pastores and chicken with tequila (DELICIOUS!). In other words, I'll be getting that stuff in a taco next time. Oh they also have this interesting rice drink with cinnamon and chocolate - that was also fantastic, but given I was too full I chose the thinner liquid drink to take home, drink to my heart's content, and pass out on the couch.

Overall a great experience and when I have them cravings for Mexican food, and not to forget their pastries and hot chocolate I'll be back.
author: Jeannette L.

description: This place is awesome. Open late, great food, real guacamole, nuff said.
author: Kevin C.

description: Best Mexican I've had in the bay.  Had the tamales and the enchiladas and some other small things.  Very, very tasty food.  Still thinking about a few days later.  Went there on a saturday for a quick dinner.  There was a three guitar mariachi band playing to a handful of tables.  Everything was very casual and the food portions are large with very reasonable prices.  Highly recommend this place.
author: Sanjiv B.

description:
We saw a review in the Examiner, there were some interesting items so we thought we would give this place a try.  DON"T even try parking in this neighborhood unless you have good parking karma (which I DO have), they have about a half dozen small tables, seating comfy for 2, crowded for 3. More than 3 of you, and you'll need two tables or take it to go. 

When we arrived we greeted by the very friendly staff. Not too crowded, grabbed a window seat and started to look over the menu.  After living in SF for a number of years and having tried many of the burrito joints in the Mission and many other Mexican restaurants we were pleasantly surprised at finding some items we had never seen or even heard of before. Tlayudas?  What's that?   Turns out to be a crispy tortilla like item, 12 or 14 inches across. We ordered the Sin Carne version. First it has beans over the whole thing, some Quesillo cheese from Oaxaca, lettuce, salsa, YUMMMMMMMM.  Think AUTHENTIC Mexican pizza.  The tamale pollo con mole was not only the BEST tamale ever eaten by my dinner partner who is a big tamale afficianado, but also some of the best mole I have ever had. I had a few Sopes, the Longanzina a type of sausage diced up with potato and onion reminded me of a hash and it was okay, but the Tinga de Pollo, pulled chicken in a mildly spicy sauce on top of shredded lettuce and frijoles refritos, topped with the Oaxacan cheese was TO DIE FOR.  
The Oaxacan version of the tamale in a corn husk, a Chicken Mole Negri de Oaxaca en hoja de Platano (in a banana leaf) was freakin' amazing, I coulda, shoulda had 2 or 3 of them to bring home with me....so when I wake up in the middle of the night after dreaming about La Oaxaqena I could just go to the fridge and eat some more. 
Ebverything we tried (there was a pupusa for the 5 year old) and some carne asada tacos (yummmmm also) was top notch in quality and flavor, plated nicely also. Tres leches cake for dessert was above average for this item, but I am not a big dessert fan, would prefer to leave room for more Pollo MoleNegro!
 
La Oaxaquena is on my short list and should be on yours as well. Dinner for 2 1/2 with a dessert and extra entree so we could try more variety was $33
author: Gary G.

description: I had to try the black mole enchiladas, and I really enjoyed them. So much so that I followed the advice of another yelper and ordered some of the plantain-wrapped tamales with mole to-go. I also brought home some of the pan dulce, but I was disappointed with that. The breads were pretty stale and a bit of a disappointment. They still get 4 stars on the balance of their unique tastes, affordable prices, and great service.
author: Vernon S.

description: My favorite place to eat in the Mission.  The menu is very unique and they always have delicious specials.  Just ask them for recommendations (everyone who works here is extremely friendly).
author: Saikat C.

description: Don't be put off by the location or look of the place. This food is tasty! Definitely get the chicken with mole plate (house special!) and the whole fried fish was surprisingly juice. The accompanying rice and beans with quesillo (Oaxacan cheese) was flavorful and satisfying. Even better, grab some pastries, have a hot chocolate, coffee or champurrado with one of their pastries and watch the people walk by....
author: chris k.

description: I went with 3 other friends for lunch, the place was packed, so we decided to try it.  No one greeted us as we walked in, nor did they acknowledge us as we stood by the cash register with menus.  One of the tables got up, so we sat down and waited.  Finally a server/owner came by and cleared the plates (from the previous group of people), but we had to ask for someone to wipe the table down.  As we were waiting at the table, we saw some guacamole and chips pass by - it looked great! When the server came to take our order, I asked for the guac and chips to start.  The server said they were all out.  I was a little confused since it was only 1pm in the afternoon.  He said the chef's didn't have time to make more and there was no more available.  Sadly, we just proceeded to order our lunch.  Two of my friends ordered super burritos, but because there was no guacamole, only a regular burrito came.  After 25 minutes, all of our food came out - 2 burritos, 3 sopes and 1 fajita order.  The steak from both the sopes and fajitas was rubber, the burritos were only warm and lacked cilantro and sour cream (which was specifically ordered), no one checked on us throughout the meal and we had to seek someone out for sauce, drinks and the check.   I only saw 2 servers and 2 chef's and maybe 9 tables in the place, so either they weren't prepared for the busy lunch hour or they didn't have their shift together, but all in all, it was quite a disappointment for us.
author: Nicole S.
